By default, the table number, with a colon after it, and the table title are placed on the same line in regular text. If you need to alter this, after first creating the caption, press the Up or Down arrow to get back into it, and make whatever changes you need using the Font or Paragraph dialogs.

If you have several tables in your document and insert a new one in the middle or reorder them, table numbering in the captions will not automatically adjust. To do this, press Control + A to select the entire document and press F9. This will refresh the captions and correctly renumber the tables.

3.6.3.3 Notes on Sources

The last part of a table is notes on sources, as well as whatever other explanatory notes you may wish to add. Similar to captions, you might decide to “cheat” by simply typing source notes just below the table. However, there is a better way to do this that keeps the notes as part of the table, making it easier to maintain consistent formatting. This involves inserting an additional row at the bottom of the table, merging the cells in that row, and typing in your notes there. You then customize the gridlines to hide them, following steps in Chapter 3.6.3.3 above. On a printed page, the gridlines do not appear to be part of the table, but they actually are. Electronically they appear fainter than the other “non-hidden” gridlines. Steps to add this new row at the bottom of the table with accompanying notes are:

1.    At the bottom right of your table, press Tab once to add an additional row.

2.    Press Alt to open the Upper ribbon and Right arrow to the Table Tools Layout tab.

3.    Tab to the Select submenu and press Enter.

4.    With your cursor still in the row you just inserted, Down arrow to Select Row and press Enter.

5.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Merge cells, and press Enter.

Let’s say your table has four columns. Now if you Up arrow once and Down arrow once to get back into the merged row, JAWS will say “number of columns changed from four to one.” Narrator says “Merged cell, spans four columns.” Unfortunately, NVDA does not clearly indicate the presence of merged cells.

You can now Type in your notes in this merged cell, allowing text to wrap around to additional lines within the row, or pressing Enter to add more notes in the same cell. In both cases, the row height will adjust automatically to accommodate your text.

You are now ready to hide the left, right, and bottom gridlines for this row, but not the top gridline because this will remain the bottom-most visible gridline in your table. To do this:

1.    With your cursor still situated in the merged cell, press Alt to open the Upper ribbon.

2.    Once again select the row by navigating to the Table Tools Layout tab, pressing Tab to the Select submenu, pressing Enter, using the Down arrow to Select Row, and pressing Enter.

3.    Open the Upper ribbon again, and Left arrow once to the Table Tools Design tab along the Upper ribbon.

4.    Tab into the Lower ribbon to the Borders and shading button and press Enter.

5.    Down arrow to Custom.

6.    Tab to Top Border and press Enter to check it.

7.    Tab to Bottom Border and press Enter to uncheck it.

8.    Tab to Left Border and press Enter to uncheck it.

9.    Tab to Right Border and press Enter to uncheck it.

10. Tab to the OK button and press Enter or Spacebar.

The left, right, and bottom gridlines should now be hidden. The top border remains visible, thus making it appear to be the bottom border of the table.

You may ask whether using captions and hiding gridlines is worth all the effort. If you are inserting just one or two tables in your document, perhaps not. However, if you anticipate having quite a few tables, this will ultimately save you work, as well as help avoid formatting mistakes and inconsistencies.

Word tables can be quite complicated to format correctly. Below, we will see how to create styles to make them look more professional.

3.6.4 Table Styles

If your document contains a fairly large number of tables, this feature can save you significant time in ensuring that all your tables are correctly and consistently formatted.

To choose a style from the Styles gallery:

1.    Create a table and place your cursor somewhere inside it.

2.    Open the ribbons and Right Arrow to the Table Tools Design tab.

3.    Press Control + Right Arrow to the Table Styles button or submenu and press Enter (whether you have a button or submenu depends on your version of Word).

4.    A gallery of over 100 table styles appear, varying from extremely plain to very colorful and elaborate. Press Tab to move through them and press Enter on the one you want and your table will now have this style.

Unfortunately, this is a very visual gallery. Sighted computer users can simply hover their mouse over a style and they will see the design. Screenreader users are obliged to Press Enter on a style and use Insert + F and Insert + F1 (this last one in JAWS only) to get an idea of the table style. But its advantage is that it is quicker to use a prefabricated style rather than create your own. The disadvantage is that it is time consuming to explore them without sighted assistance. Also, even though there are over 100 of them, these styles may not meet your specific needs.

To create your own custom style, you should be in a blank, unsaved Word document. Your cursor focus does not need to be in a table. To create a custom table style:

1.    Press Alt H L S. This places focus in the Create new style dialog.

2.    Type a name for your style.

3.    Tab to the Modify button and press Enter.

4.    Tab to the Style type combo box and Press T for Table.

5.    Tab to the Style based on combo box. If you want to base your new style on a style from the gallery mentioned above, Down arrow to that style. If you have no such gallery style in mind, continue Tabbing to Apply format to whole table. Here you can also select specific rows or columns, which is useful if you have already selected a gallery style upon which to base your custom style. But if you are starting from scratch, stick with applying the style to the whole table.

6.    Tab past the various options here (for font, bold, borders, etc.) to the This document only radio button. Trying to change formatting in this series of tabs is very clunky and rather inaccessible using a screenreader program.

7.    On the This document only radio button, Down arrow to New documents based on this template radio button. Selecting this will ensure that you can use this new custom style in future documents.

8.    Tab once to the Format button and press Enter. Here you can Up and Down arrow to Font, Borders and Shading, Paragraph, and other settings. The settings you will most commonly change are the ones for fonts and borders.

9.    Using fonts as an example, Up or Down arrow to Fonts and press Enter. This opens the same Font dialog presented in Chapter 3.2.2. Make your changes and press the OK button at the end of the dialog.

10. Press the OK button a second time if these are the only style changes you wish to register.

11. Otherwise, Press Shift + Tab to get back to the Format button and press Enter to make more changes.

12. If, for example, you want to define gridline styles for your tables, Up or Down arrow to Borders and shading and press Enter. You land on the same dialog discussed in the last section on adjusting gridlines. Make whatever changes you wish here, Tab to the OK button, and press Enter. When finished, Press Enter on the second OK button. Your new table style has been created.

To change the table style to your new custom style:

1.    Place your cursor somewhere in the table.

2.    Press Alt to open the Upper ribbon and Right arrow to the Table Tools Design tab. Be careful here because the first Design tab you encounter (just one to the right of the Insert tab) is the Design tab for the overall document, not the Table Tools Design tab.

3.    Once on the Table Tools Design tab, Tab in the Lower ribbon to the Table Styles button and press Enter.

4.    You may land on the Plain table grid button. Press Shift + Tab and your Custom table style button should appear.

5.    Press Enter on this and you will be returned to your table, now formatted with your custom style.

6.    To verify, move around among the cells and Press Insert + F to check font formatting. Also with JAWS, Press Insert + F1 to check gridline formatting. Remember that this information is spoken just after you hear “table padding.”

3.6.5 Importing Data from Excel to Create a Word Table

If you are already familiar with Excel, this is fairly easy to do, provided that the width of the columns you import from Excel fit within the left and right margins of your Word document. Do not import more than five or six columns from Excel because table size is limited by page size in Word. .

Steps are:

1.    In Excel, select the data range of the table. Limit this strictly to the columns and rows containing the column and row headers and data in the body of the table. Do not select any title you may have created (usually in cell A1). This text is best entered later as a caption.

2.    Press Control + C to copy the selected data range.

3.    Open a Word document and press Control + V to paste the data table with the font formatting from Excel and without gridlines.

4.    If you want to include printable gridlines, do not press Control + V. Instead, press the Applications key, Down arrow to Paste options, Right arrow to Use destination styles, and press Enter. Note that font styles will be consistent with those of the Word document.

In Chapter 3.6.3.1, I discussed how to determine the presence or absence of gridlines by either using Insert + F1 (JAWS only) or searching for the Borders and shading command using Alt Q.

To paste the Excel table into Word keeping it linked so that any updates within Excel also appear in the Word table (which does not occur using the above pasting techniques, select and copy the Excel data as above, press the Applications key, Down arrow to Paste options, and Right arrow to either Link & Keep Source Formatting or Link & Use Destination Styles, and press Enter.

The first of these will link Excel data without gridlines, and the second will link data and add gridlines.

If you revise the data in Excel by changing a few numbers here and there, linking with Word works well. However, if you add or delete rows and columns in Excel, it is less predictable. Checking your work is important here.

What better way to summarize the above than in a table! The first column lists the four paste options. For each of these, the remaining two columns indicate whether gridlines appear, and if font names are imported from Excel or remain the same as in the Word document. If font names are identical in Word and Excel, it does not matter whether you choose original or destination formatting. If they are different, most of the time you will want to choose a destination style option so that table formatting is consistent with your Word document. Here goes!

Paste Option

Gridlines

Excel Font

Simple paste (Control + V)

No

Yes

Use destination styles

Yes

No

Link & Keep Source Formatting

No

Yes

Link & Use Destination Styles

Yes

No

Now do whatever additional table formatting (adding captions, source notes, etc.) you wish, using techniques covered earlier in this section.

3.7 Footnotes and Endnotes

Add footnotes and endnotes when you want to provide additional information in your document, but you feel that it does not belong in the main body. Common examples are additional facts that illuminate the main text, statistical details, and source document citations. Footnotes are situated at the bottom of the page, just above the bottom margin. Don’t confuse these with footers which appear below the bottom margin and serve a different purpose. Endnotes appear at the end of the document or at the end of individual chapters.

I will deal primarily with footnotes, which are more commonly used than endnotes.

3.7.1 Creating and Editing Footnotes

Steps for creating a footnote are:

1.    Place your cursor at the precise point in the main body of the text associated with your eventual footnote. The cursor should be to the immediate right of the text or punctuation mark, with no spaces between.

2.    Press Alt to open the Upper ribbon, and Right arrow to the References tab.

3.    Tab into the Lower ribbon to the Insert footnote button and press Enter. The shortcut key is Alt S F. Oddly, if you navigate there in the ribbons, Control + F is mistakenly identified as the shortcut key.

4.    You land in the Footnote pane at the bottom of the page. A numbered superscript appears at the left side of the Footnote pane.

5.    Type in your text. I have inserted a footnote at the end of this sentence.[12] The audio feedback you hear varies depending on which screenreader you are using and its settings. We’ll see how to navigate to the footnote shortly.

6.    When finished inserting text, Up or Down arrow to exit the Footnote pane and return to the main body of your document. Do not press Enter or Tab, which will instead add a line or tab in your footnote text.

When you create a footnote, a numbered superscript is placed in the main body of the document at the point where you initiated this action.

There are two ways to get back into the Footnote pane if you want to edit the text. One way is to go to the bottom line of the page where you inserted the footnote and continue Down arrowing to get into the Footnote pane, or Up arrow once or twice from the top of the next page. You can now edit it using standard text editing keystrokes.

The second way is through the ribbons. In the References tab, Tab to the Show notes button and press Enter (the ribbon shortcut is Alt S H). You can now Down arrow through all your notes and edit them. If you have a lot of notes to edit or your document is quite large, this may be quicker than trying to find them one by one at the bottom of your document’s many pages.

3.7.2 Navigating to Footnotes in the Text Body and Deleting Them

The Go to next footnote and Go to previous footnote commands are located in the Footnotes group of the References tab. The shortcut keys are Alt S O N to go to the next footnote, and Alt S O P to go to the previous one. This places the cursor in the main body of the document near the footnote’s superscript, not in the Footnote pane. If you want to delete a footnote, use this command. You delete a footnote in the main body of the text by deleting the superscript that is found there. You do not do it by deleting the text in the Footnote pane, which would instead leave a footnote with no text. After deleting a footnote, all following footnotes are automatically renumbered correctly.

Although it does not place your cursor in the Footnote pane, JAWS has a quick way to hear footnote text read. Press Insert + Z to turn on Quick Keys. Now Press O to jump to the next footnote, or Shift O to go to the previous one. JAWS will read the footnote text. However, as with the ribbon shortcuts above, your cursor is actually on the footnote superscript in the main body of the text. If you want to delete the footnote, turn off Quick Keys by pressing Insert + Z again to return to Edit mode, Left or Right arrow to the footnote superscript and delete it.

Also with JAWS, you can open a Virtual Viewer to access a Footnote list. To open the Virtual Viewer, press the Windows and Semi-Colon keys together. This gives you a list of four items to view. The first is Comments. Down arrow once to Footnotes and press Enter. JAWS indicates how many footnotes are in the document. Down arrow and you will hear a numbered link. The text of the footnote appears under the link. Continue Down arrowing and you will hear the link and text for the second footnote, and so on. Press Enter on the link to navigate to the location of the footnote’s superscript in the main body of your document, or press Escape to exit the Virtual Viewer. You can also use this tool for deleting footnotes because it puts your cursor in the vicinity of the superscript in the main body of the text.

Other than the Word ribbon shortcuts mentioned above, NVDA and Narrator have no quick way to navigate to footnote superscripts in the main body of the text.

3.7.3 Footnote Styles

The footnote text format needs to be consistent with that of the main body of your document. To check formatting, go into the Footnote pane and press Insert + F to hear font and paragraph format settings.

The default footnote font that comes from the factory is Calibri 10 point (just slightly smaller than the normal style default of Calibri 11 point). If you change the main body font, you will need to change the footnote font settings too. You should definitely make the footnote font name the same as in the main body. You may elect to have a slightly smaller font size for footnotes relative to the main text. For this book, the main body font is Arial 12 point, and the footnote text is Arial 11 point.

Regarding paragraph formatting, main body and footnote text alignment should be the same. Default footnote line spacing is single. Do not change this even if main body text is double spaced.

To change footnote formatting and make it consistent throughout your document, you will need to change the footnote style. To do this:

1.    Place the cursor somewhere on the text in one of your Footnote panes.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Styles, and press Enter.

3.    You land in an edit combo box. If the words “Footnote text” do not already appear, type in the first few letters and Down arrow to it.

4.    Tab to Modify and press Enter.

5.    Shift + Tab to the Format button and press Enter.

6.    You land on the Font button. Press Enter which opens the same Font dialog as in Chapter 3.2.2. Make whatever changes you wish (font name, style, size, color.

7.    When finished, Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

8.    Press Enter on the Apply button.

9.    Press Insert + F in one of your footnotes to verify that your desired changes have been made. I have added a second footnote here, so you can test this out if you like[13]

If you also want to make paragraph format changes for your footnote style, repeat steps one through five above, and Down arrow to the Paragraph dialog and press Enter.

Finally, you can assign a shortcut key for Footnote text style. I have found this useful because sometimes text contained in the Footnote pane appears there in Normal or some other style, and this makes it easy to change it. Steps are:

1.    Repeat steps one through five above.

2.    Up or Down arrow to the Shortcut key button and press Enter.

3.    This opens an edit box where you type in your shortcut key. I have designated Control + Alt F as my shortcut for footnote text.

4.    Tab to the Assign button and press the Spacebar.

5.    Tab to the Close button and press the Spacebar.

6.    Tab again to the OK button and press Enter or Spacebar.

3.7.4 Customizing How You Hear Footnotes with JAWS

With JAWS, you can customize what feedback you hear on footnotes as you are reading through the document line by line or in Say all mode. Customization is done in JAWS Quick Settings. To access these options, while in Word, press Insert + V to get into Quick Settings. In the edit box where you land, type in the first few letters of the word “footnote.” Now press the Down arrow to “comments, footnotes and endnotes detection” and press the Spacebar to cycle through the four options, which are:

·         Off: No footnote information is provided.

·         On: Says “footnote” only.

·         On with text: Reads the footnote text. With Eloquence voices, JAWS reads this information with a lower pitch (no pitch change for other voices).

·         On plus count: In Say all mode, the same feedback is provided as with On with text. When using the Down arrow to read by line, it will tell you the number of footnote superscripts on the line.

When you have made your selection, Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

If you wish to hear footnote text as you are navigating through the document, On with text is your best choice. Note also that to get a list of footnotes using the JAWS Virtual Viewer mentioned above, Footnote Detection needs to be turned on.

I sometimes prefer to turn off footnote detection because it can be difficult to distinguish where text at the bottom of a page ends, footnotes start and end, and text at the top of the next page begins. This is especially true if I am trying to edit the text at the bottom or top of a page adjacent to a footnote.

NVDA and Narrator have no such customizations for varying audio feedback for footnote text. As you navigate through the main body of the text, NVDA says, “footnote 1, footnote 2, etc.” Narrator says, “footnote reference 1, footnote reference 2, etc.”

3.7.5 Endnotes

Endnotes typically are placed at the end of a document section or chapter. In professional academic journals, they are often preferred over footnotes. They too are created in the References tab. The shortcut key is Alt S E. Once in the Endnote pane, create them the same way footnotes are created.

By default, endnote numbering appears as lowercase Roman numeral superscripts.

With JAWS, you can navigate to endnotes by similar means as footnotes. Press Insert + Z to turn Quick Keys mode on. Press the letter D to move to the next endnote. You can also use the Virtual Viewer. Press Windows + Semi-Colon, Down arrow to Endnotes, and press Enter. In this Virtual Viewer, endnotes are presented the same way as footnotes.

Ribbon shortcuts to navigate to the next and previous endnotes are Alt S O X and Alt S O V, respectively.

It is easy to convert footnotes to endnotes and vice versa. You can do this any time while preparing a document. Steps are:

1.    In the References tab of the ribbon, Tab to the Footnote and endnote dialog and press Enter.

2.    You land on a radio button with Footnotes selected by default. Down or Up arrow to Endnotes.

3.    Tab to the Convert button and press Enter.

4.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

After converting, you can choose if you want your endnotes to be located at the end of the document or the end of a section. You might pick the latter if your document is lengthy, divided into chapters, and you prefer endnotes to appear at the end of each chapter. Press Tab again and you can change the endnote numbering format if you want something other than Roman numerals.

3.8 Citations and Bibliographies

Correctly creating and formatting citations and bibliographies can be time consuming and frustrating. Fortunately, Word’s Citations and Bibliography feature Takes much of the misery out of this process. All relevant commands are found in the Citations and Bibliography group of the References tab.

3.8.1 Creating Citations

The first step in creating your citations is to choose a style type. Appendix III discusses the three most important academic style guides used in the United States. If you are a college student or somebody writing an article for a professional or literary journal, you will want to read that appendix, and choose the style appropriate for you. If choice of style guide really doesn’t matter to you, sticking with the default APA style should be OK.

To choose a style, in the Citations and Bibliography group, Tab to the Styles combo box (shortcut: Alt S L). These are listed alphabetically, with APA first. Press the Down arrow and you will find Chicago, MLA, and several others. Down arrow to your choice and press Enter.

The next step is to create your citations. Don’t wait until the end of your project to do this. Ideally, add citations as you encounter them while doing background research and drafting your document.

Regardless of the citation style you use, there are important pieces of information to collect in order to create complete citations. For books and/or journals, you need to collect: The author name (or names if multiple authors); title of publication; article title (if using a journal); date of publication; place of publication; publisher; volume number of a journal, magazine, or encyclopedia; and page number (s).

For websites, you will need to collect: The author and/or editor name; title of the website; company or organization that owns or posts to the website; URL (website address); and date you visited the site or when the content was first posted there.

You can create citations with your cursor focus on the point in your document text where you want it to first appear. You can also save citations in a separate file reserved exclusively for listing references, and later Insert them in your document towards the end of the report preparation process.

When you insert a citation into the body of your document, the last name of the author and the date of the publication will appear between parentheses. For example, for a book, you might see (Salinger, 1949). There is a comma between the author name and the year.

Assuming you are inserting citations into the body of a document, the process for adding a citation is as follows:

1.    Place focus at the precise position of your document body where you want to insert the citation. If, for example, you wish to place the citation at the end of a sentence, just between the last word of the sentence and the period, press the Spacebar to put one space after the last word of the sentence and just before the period.

2.    Navigate to the Citations and Bibliography group in the References tab. The first stop in the group is the Insert Citation submenu (shortcut: Alt S C). If you navigate there via the ribbons, Press Enter to open the submenu. Press Enter on Add new source, which opens a dialog.

3.    In the combo box, Down arrow to your source type (book, journal article, and many more). I will use a book as an example.

4.    Tab to Author and, if a person, type in the author name as you would normally type a name (first name followed by last name). The last name will automatically appear in the citation and in the alphabetical ordering of the bibliography.

5.    Or Tab once to Corporate author and check this checkbox if appropriate. Then Tab to an edit field where you type in the name of the company.

6.    Tab to Title and Insert the book title.

7.    Tab to Year and enter the year of publication.

8.    Tab to City and enter where the book was published.

9.    Tab to Publisher and enter the name of the publishing company.

10. Tab to Tag Number. A tagging code is assigned to the reference by Word, usually based on the first few letters of the author’s last name. You can change this, but only do so if you have already devised a citation classification system of your own. Otherwise, do nothing here.

11. Tab to the OK button and press Enter. Your citation has been created in the body of the document.

3.8.2 Inserting Existing Citations Into a Document

Steps for inserting previously created citations are different depending on whether you are inserting them elsewhere in the same document where they were initially created, or in a different document. To insert a citation in a document where that citation already exist in at least one other place:

1.    Place your cursor precisely where you want the citation to appear in the body of the document.

2.    Navigate to the Insert citations dialog in the References tab and press Enter.

3.    Down arrow or first-letter navigate by author last name to the citation you wish to insert and press Enter.

When you create citations, they are automatically saved to a master list of citations. You can use this master list to insert previously-generated citations in other documents on your computer. Steps are:

1.    Place your cursor where you want the citation to appear in the body of your document.

2.    Navigate to the Manage sources dialog in the References tab and press Enter.

3.    Down arrow or first-letter navigate by author last name to the citation you wish to select.

4.    Tab to the Copy button and press Enter. Then press Escape to exit this dialog.

5.    Return to the References tab, tab to the Insert citations submenu, and press Enter to open it.

6.    Your focus should be on the citation you just selected although you may not hear it. To be sure, Down and Up arrow once to hear it, and then press Enter to Insert the citation in the document.

3.8.3 Creating a Bibliography

After inserting several citations into your document, you can now generate a bibliography. Don’t worry if you are not completely finished. As we will see below, It is easy to edit and update your citations and bibliography.

To generate a bibliography:

1.    Go to the end of your document. The bibliography must start at the top of a new page. Press Control + Enter to insert a page break. Your cursor is now at the top of the last page of your document.

2.    Navigate to the Bibliography submenu in the Citations and bibliography group of the References tab. Press Enter on this. The shortcut is Alt S B.

3.    In the submenu, Down arrow to move through the three choices and press Enter on the appropriate choice, depending on the style you are using: References for APA; Works Cited for MLA; or Bibliography for CMOS.

A bibliography is now generated with a level one heading at the top. The citations are listed alphabetically by author underneath.

3.8.4 Editing and Updating Citations and Bibliographies

Use the Manage sources dialog (shortcut key: Alt S M) to edit individual citations. Steps are as follows:

1.    Navigate to and open the Manage sources dialog in the References tab.

2.    Down arrow or first-letter navigate by last name to the author whose citation you wish to edit.

3.    Tab to the Edit button and press Enter.

4.    Tab through the options, making desired changes.

5.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

6.    You are asked to confirm that you want to update the citation in both your master list and within this document. Press Enter to confirm.

If you changed either the last name or year of publication or both, this will be reflected in the citation appearing in the body of the document. However, if you have already generated a bibliography in the document, you will need to update the bibliography as follows:

1.    Navigate to the bibliography you created, and make sure your cursor is placed somewhere in the bibliography field. When you Down arrow into it, Your screenreader will say “bibliography” and the first citation. If you Down arrow too far, your screenreader will say “end bibliography.”

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Update field, and press Enter.

If you changed the author’s last name, the citation will sort itself properly so that it appears in the correct alphabetical order, Any other revisions will also appear.

If you want to delete a citation from a document, you will need to find it in the body of the document and manually delete it. To quickly locate the citation you want to delete, use the Find command (Control + F), type in the author’s last name and press Enter. I prefer backspacing out the text until I am sure it is gone.

If you now want to update the bibliography so that this reference no longer appears, the Update field command mentioned above will not work for removing it. The easiest thing to do is to delete the entire text of the existing bibliography and recreate it.

3.8.5 Bibliography Styles

If you are required to follow one of the academic style guides,, you will need to make some font and paragraph format changes to make the bibliography consistent with the overall document. See Appendix III.3.3.1 on how to make these changes.

When you generate a bibliography, there will be a level one heading at the top, saying either Bibliography, References, or Works Cited, depending on the choice you made above. The first letters of these words will be capitalized. Do not change this.

The heading will have the default heading 1 formatting for Word. Unless you have already changed it, the heading will have the factory settings. Font format settings are Cambria or Calibri 16 point bolded, with a blue color. Go into the Font dialog (Control D) and change this to the font formatting of your overall document.

Regarding paragraph formatting of the reference documents, the following should already be in place:

·         Left alignment

·         Hanging indentation of 0.5 inches (found in the Special combo box)

·         Above paragraph spacing of 0 point

If these are set differently, change them to the above settings. If you only want to make these changes once, you are now done. However, you can set this as a custom bibliography style so that you can quickly generate new bibliographies that incorporate these changes. To do this:

1.    Select the heading 1 text and the entire bibliography.

2.    Open the Bibliography submenu (shortcut: Alt S B).

3.    Shift + Tab to the “save selection to bibliography gallery” button and press Enter.

4.    Type a name for your custom bibliography style in the Building block edit field (for example: APA References or MLA Works Cited).

5.    Tab to the Description edit field and put in a description if you wish. This is optional, but useful if you create several styles and need to keep them straight in your head.

6.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

Your custom bibliography style is now added to the list under the existing three options. To verify that it works, delete the initial bibliography and generate a new one using your new style. Press Insert + F on the heading and the bibliography text to see that font and paragraph format changes have registered.

Note that even though you have changed the level one heading style for the bibliography, this does not change the heading 1 style for the overall document.

3.8.6 Exporting Your Master List of Citations to Another Computer

The file containing your master list of citations is stored locally on your computer. To be able to use it on another computer, you will either want to save it to a cloud app folder so you can access it on other computers where you are using one of those apps, or you will want to copy and paste the relevant file to a thumb drive and paste it to the other computer.

To copy the master list file:

1.    In the References tab, open the Manage sources submenu.

2.    Shift + Tab once to Browse and press Enter.

3.    Shift + Tab until you hear “Style,” and Down arrow to Sources.xml. This is the default name of the master list file.

4.    Press Control + C to copy it to the Clipboard,

5.    Navigate to where you want to paste the file. If in a cloud app folder where you intend to access the citations on one of your other shared computers, press Control + V to paste it.

6.    Or open a thumb drive, paste it there, and then paste it somewhere on the other computer you are using.

You may wish to rename the file so you don’t get confused by having it with the same generic filename on different computers. Also, you can rename if you want to have several master lists for different projects you are working on.

The first time you want to insert a citation in a document on the new computer using this master list:

1.    Place focus where you want the citation to appear in the body of your document.

2.    Navigate to the Manage sources dialog in the References tab and press Enter.

3.    Shift + Tab to Browse and press Enter.

4.    Shift + Tab to the tree view and navigate to the folder where the file is located.

5.    Tab once to the list view, Down arrow to the master list file, and press Enter.

You can now use the master list to add citations to documents on this computer, as well as add new citations to the master list on this computer. If you use a cloud sharing app like Dropbox, be sure to save the file there on all your shared computers. That way, any revisions to your master list will be reflected on other shared computers, and you won’t need to repeat the steps above to keep your citations consistent between them.

3.9 Some Special Topics

The items in this sub-section may be needed for more complex documents. Word is a very powerful application, so the topics covered here only scratch the surface of all the things you can do with Word.

3.9.1 Inserting Pictures

You can insert pictures and other graphic elements into a Word document. The easiest way to do this is with a simple copy and paste method. First, select the image file (common file extensions are.JPG,.PNG, and .TIF) from your list of files and folders. Then press Control + C to copy the file. Now navigate to your Word document, place focus where you want to Insert the image and Press Control + V to paste it there.

After you paste a picture into a Word document, there are a number of formatting issues you need to consider. These include adding descriptive text (most commonly referred to as “alt text”), resizing, positioning, and captioning.

The first step is to select a picture, or as it is generically referred to in Word—a “graphic.” There are several ways to select graphics. I will cover a universal way and a JAWS-specific way. The universal way is to press Control + Alt + 5 and then Tab to select graphic by graphic through your document. In theory, it is possible to select multiple graphics, but I have not been successful in doing this with any screenreader, so I will stick to individual graphics.

Regarding the JAWS-specific way to do this, graphics are referred to as one category of “objects.” To select an object with JAWS:

1.    Hold down Control + Shift and O together. This brings up a list of objects in your document.

2.    Up or Down arrow to the object you wish to select, and press Enter to select it. Note that you must Press Enter - the Spacebar will not work. JAWS indicates that the object is selected.

Once a graphic is selected, you can add descriptive text (commonly referred to as “alt text”), resize, and add captions. How to add these elements is discussed below.

After inserting a graphic, to make it accessible, you need to add alternative text, or alt text for short. This is text that you will hear with your screenreader program, but is not visible to the sighted user. For screenreader users with Word 365, artificial intelligence (AI) – generated text is spoken. JAWS also tells you the image’s dimensions. NVDA and Narrator both indicate that a picture is present, but do not indicate dimensions.

If AI-generated alt text is present, it is very generic and often inaccurate. If no AI-generated alt text is present, you need to add it. If it is already there, you will usually need to revise it.

To add or revise alt text:

1.    Select the graphic using the keystrokes outlined above.

2.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow to Edit alt text, and press Enter. Your screenreader program should now say “Description edit.”

3.    If no AI-generated alt text is present, type in your alt text here. If AI-generated alt text is present, you must manually delete this text if you do not want it, and then type in your own alt text. I usually press Control + A to select all of it, and type my replacement text over it.

4.    When finished typing in your alt text, Press Escape (not Enter or Tab) to lock in the alt text and return to the document. Your screenreader should now announce the alt text whenever you encounter the graphic in the body of your document.

When you paste an image into a Word document, it is inserted with dimensions that you may want to change. As mentioned above, when you select an object with JAWS, the dimensions will be announced. To detect dimensions with NVDA and Narrator:

1.    Select the image and press the Applications key.

2.    Up arrow to Size and position, and press Enter.

3.    Tab several times to first hear its width and then its height.

4.    Press the Escape key to exit this dialog.

To resize an image:

1.    Select the graphic.

2.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow to Size and position, and press Enter.

3.    Tab to the Absolute height edit spin box. A couple of tabs past this is the Absolute width edit spin box. In one or the other (but not both), either type in the number of inches you want for height or width, or Up or Down arrow to the value you want (these are 0.1 inch increments). The value should automatically adjust in the other spin box to ensure that the picture is not distorted.

4.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

Various options are available for positioning the graphic within a page. These are referred to as “text wrapping” options. By default, a picture is inserted in line with text. This means that it is tied to the position within the document where it is inserted. Also, and even if it does not fill the entire width of the page, no text appears to its right or left, only above and below. It is also left-aligned. However, you may prefer that text within a paragraph flows to the left or right of the graphic so it is more visually appealing. Or you may wish to change the alignment, or make other adjustments. For further information on how you can make these and other adjustments to the position of a graphic, visit this Microsoft Support page: Wrap text around a picture in Word.

As with tables, you will often want to include captions (see Chapter 3.6.3.2 on how to add these). Graphics are referred to as “figures” in the Captions dialog. As a general rule, figure captions appear below the picture. The same Captions dialog is used for both tables and figures. To add a caption to a graphic:

1.    Select the graphic.

2.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow to Insert captions, and press Enter.

3.    Type in a title for the graphic. By default, they are numbered with the labels Figure 1, Figure 2, etc.

4.    Tab to the Labels combo box, where your choices are Table or Figure. If it does not already say Figure, Up or Down arrow to it.

5.    Tab to Position, where your options are Above selected item or Below selected item. Up or Down arrow to Below selected item.

6.    Tab to the Exclude label from caption checkbox, which is unchecked by default. Uncheck this if you do not want the labels Figure 1, Figure 2, etc., to appear.

7.    Tab to New label, and press Enter if you want to change the label from Figure to something else like Picture, Diagram, or Chart.

8.    Tab to Numbering. Here you can change the numbering style (Roman numerals, add chapter numbers, etc.).

9.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

3.9.2 Sections

Section breaks are most frequently inserted when you wish to change some aspect of page formatting in a document. Section breaks are more common in longer and more complex documents. Situations where you would insert section breaks include:

·         When repaginating inside a document (see the example of tables of contents in Chapter 3.9.3 below).

·         When changing page number formatting. One example could be if you have created an executive summary which uses small Roman numeral formatting (i, ii, iii, etc.) and Arabic numbering (1, 2, 3, etc.) for the main body of the text.

·         When changing header or footer text within the document.

·         When temporarily changing from portrait to landscape orientation. You might need to do this if you are inserting a table that is too wide to fit on the page with portrait orientation.

·         When inserting columns in the text (see Chapter 3.9.4 below).

There are several types of section breaks. I will use Next page section breaks for describing how to insert a new section in a document:

1.    Place your cursor at the top of the page where the main body of your text begins.

2.    Open the Upper ribbon and Right or Left arrow to the Layout tab.

3.    Tab into the Lower ribbon to the Break submenu (shortcut: Alt P B) and press Enter.

4.    Down arrow to the Next page button and press Enter.

Now if you Up arrow once and Down arrow once, both JAWS and NVDA will say the page number and indicate that you are in section 2 of the document. Listen carefully here to the page numbering. In some versions of Word, the default is that page numbering continues from the last page of the previous section, while in other versions, it restarts on page one. Depending on your reason for adding a section break, you may need to adjust repagination. The next section on adding tables of contents covers this.

3.9.3 Tables of Contents

A table of contents is a useful tool for navigating a document, as well as for giving readers a quick glimpse of document organization and content. They can be quickly generated once you have inserted headings into your document. See Chapter 3.4.2 on how to add headings.

If you are creating a table of contents for a newsletter that will be sent to readers by email, page numbering will not be an issue, and it can be placed just beneath whatever introductory text you generate. It is not possible to generate a table of contents in Outlook. Create your document and accompanying table of contents in Word and copy and paste the final version into the body of an email.

If the table of contents is intended for a report or book, it should begin on a separate page after your title page and before the text of your manuscript. Follow steps three through five below to generate it.

To properly situate the table of contents for a manuscript and then generate it:

1.    At the bottom of your title page, press Control + Enter twice to create a page break after the title page and another one just before the beginning of your text.

2.    Place your cursor on the space between these two page breaks.

3.    Open the Upper ribbon and Right or Left arrow to the References tab.

4.    Tab into the Lower ribbon to the Table of contents submenu (shortcut: Alt S T), and press Enter.

5.    Press Enter a second time on the Automatic table one button. A table of contents is now generated with all headings up to level three and corresponding page numbers listed. At the top, the title “Contents” is also inserted.

You can easily update a table of contents. Do this for any of the following reasons:

·         You add or remove text that will change the page numbers.

·         You add or remove headings.

·         You change the text in any of the existing headings.

·         You change the format of the table of contents.

To update the table of contents, your cursor can be anywhere in the document. Pressing Tab twice past the Table of contents submenu in the References tab gets you to the Update table button (shortcut: Alt S U). When you get into this dialog, you land on a set of radio buttons with two choices: Update page numbers only, or Update entire table. Up or Down arrow to the one you want, and press Enter

A few adjustments are now needed. Generally, it is a good idea to limit your table of contents to just level one and 2 headings. Level three headings can be included if they are not too numerous. The default is three levels. Level 4, 5, and 6 headings should not appear. In the single file containing this entire book, I have limited the table of contents to just the first level because including lower-level headings would make the table of contents very long.

To limit the number of heading levels:

1.    Open the Table of contents submenu.

2.    Tab to the Custom table of contents dialog and press Enter.

3.    Tab to the Show levels edit combo box, and Up or Down arrow to the last heading level you want appearing in the table of contents.

4.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

5.    If you have already created a table of contents, you will be asked if you want to replace the existing table. Press Enter or Spacebar to confirm. If you have not yet created it, do so now, using the steps outlined above.

6.    In your document, navigate to the Table of contents and Verify that only the correct heading levels are shown.

In addition to the Show levels edit combo box, there are two checkboxes worth mentioning in the Custom table of contents dialog:

·         Show page numbers checkbox: This is turned on by default. Uncheck it if your table of contents is intended for an electronic newsletter to be contained in the body of an email message. It will not include page numbers.

·         Use hyperlinks instead of page numbers checkbox: This is checked on by default, and you should always keep it checked. Note that the wording is a bit deceptive. If you keep the Show page numbering checkbox checked, page numbering will still be displayed.

For manuscripts, an additional adjustment is required. Because your table of contents follows the title page, and the table of contents also takes up at least one page, your manuscript text will begin on page 3 or 4. This page numbering will be reflected in the table of contents. Consequently, you will need to repaginate the document so that the main text starts on page 1. The first step for doing this is to insert a section break. Thus, insert a Next page section break as outlined in the previous section.

Depending on your version of Word, after adding this new section, page numbering may continue from the previous section, or it may restart on page one. Up and Down arrow where you have added the new section to determine this.

If you need to repaginate, do the following:

1.    With your cursor situated at the top left corner of the first page of this new section, open the Upper ribbon and go to the Insert tab.

2.    Press Control + And Right Arrow to the Header and footer group.

3.    Tab to the Page number submenu and press Enter (shortcut: Alt N N U).

4.    Down arrow to Format page numbers and press Enter.

5.    Tab to the Continue from previous section checkbox and Press the Spacebar to uncheck it.

6.    Tab to the Start at edit combo box and Up arrow to 1.

7.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

Now Up arrow once and Down arrow once, and for the newly created section, your screenreader should say, “page 1, section 2.”

Regardless of whether you needed to repaginate this new section or not, remember to update the table of contents so that correct pagination is displayed.

3.9.4 Multi-Column Formatting

You may wish to use multi-column formatting to prepare a newsletter or flyer. You can use it for an entire document or a section of a document. Because text navigation and editing can be a bit complicated in a multi-column environment, it is better to convert your text towards the end of the document preparation process.

Steps for converting standard text to multiple columns are:

1.    Select the text that you wish to convert. Assuming this is a fairly large amount of text, use the Extended text selection process (see Chapter 3.10.6 below) to select it.

2.    Navigate to the Layout tab of the Upper ribbon.

3.    Tab to the Columns submenu (shortcut: Alt P J) and press Enter.

4.    To accept default formatting, Down arrow to the number of columns you want, and press Enter.

The default formatting includes automatically calculated column width, and blank space between columns. For example, if you select two columns on a standard 8.5 by 11-inch page with one-inch left and right margins, each column will be three inches wide with one-half inch blank space between columns, totaling 8.5 inches. If you wish to alter any of these parameters, repeat steps one through three above, and then:

1.    Down arrow to More, and press Enter. This opens a dialog.

2.    Up arrow to the number of columns you want.

3.    Tab to Line between and press the Spacebar if you want a narrow line to appear between the columns.

4.    Tab to Width and change it if you want.

5.    Tab to Spacing (this is the space between columns), and change it if desired.

6.    Tab to the checkbox which is checked by default. If you uncheck this, you will need to press Shift + Tab to go back an manually adjust the various column widths. Probably, you will rarely uncheck this checkbox.

7.    Tab to Apply to, where your choices are Entire document, Selected text, or Section, depending on how you have highlighted the text. Up or Down arrow to the appropriate selection.

8.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

A few other important points to highlight. First, if you select text (rather than the entire document) and insert columns, section breaks will automatically be inserted at the beginning and end of the multi-column text. If you want the multi-column text passage to appear on separate pages than the text before and after it, press Control + Enter where the new sections begin and end to insert page breaks.

Within the multi-column text, you can insert a column break if you want to start a new column before it would naturally wrap back to the top of the next column to the right. To do this:

1.    In the Layout tab of the ribbons, Tab to the Breaks submenu and press Enter. The shortcut key is Alt P B.

2.    Down arrow to the Column button and press Enter.

JAWS has a few keystrokes that are helpful when formatting columns. With your cursor in one of the columns, press Insert + F1 for JAWS Screen-Sensitive Help. JAWS will say something like: ”The cursor is in text column 1. The section contains 2 newspaper style columns which are 3 Inches wide. The columns are evenly spaced. The gap between columns is 0.5 Inches wide. There is a vertical line between the columns. The document has 3 sections. The cursor is in section 2.”

Also, be sure that breaks are set to be revealed in JAWS Quick Settings. This is a default setting, but it is good to verify. To do this:

1.    While in Word, press Insert + V to access Word Quick Settings.

2.    In the edit box where you land, type in “break.”

3.    Down arrow once to the Page, section, and multiple column breaks checkbox and check it.

4.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

JAWS will now detect page, section, and column breaks while reading through the document. This is particularly helpful in revealing when a new column starts, and verifying that section breaks are correctly inserted at the beginning and end of multi-column text passages.

NVDA reveals this information by default as you Up and Down arrow through the document. When NVDA encounters the beginning of a multi-column text section, it will say something like “Section two, one of two columns.” At the end of the multi-column section, it will say “Section 3, one of one columns,” indicating a return to standard text.

Narrator does not announce any information when you enter or exit multi-column text passages.

You can also quickly navigate to section breaks by using the Windows special character. Press Control + F to open the Find command, type in the special character which is “^B” minus the quotes, and press Enter. Press the Spacebar to proceed to the next section break. The keystroke for the caret symbol is Shift 6 on the number row.

Unfortunately, none of the screenreaders have keystrokes for toggling between columns. Just use standard navigation and reading keys for moving by paragraph and Say all mode. Note that if you Down arrow to read line by line, when you reach the bottom of a column, Down arrowing again will not move you to the top of the next column. It will instead move you to the first line of the next section in standard text. Only paragraph and Say all navigation will move you to the top of the next column.

Finally, you may wish to put a border around your columns. This is especially appropriate if you choose to put a line between columns. It would look strange to have only a line between the columns but not around them. To add borders:

1.    With your cursor situated in the section with the multi-column text, go to the Design tab of the Upper ribbon.

2.    Tab into the Lower ribbon to Page borders and press Enter.

3.    Down arrow to the Box radio button.

4.    Tab through and you should hear that the top, bottom, left, and right borders are checked.

5.    Tab to Apply to and Down arrow to “This section.”

6.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

You can also select various customizations in this dialog, such as changing the line format, width and color.

3.10 Additional Tools for Text Reading, Selection, and Editing

You may already be familiar with the above keystrokes. However, you might be less familiar with some of the tricks and tips in this section, so read on.

3.10.1 Find, and Find and replace

The Find command is useful for searching for specific pieces of text. Press Control + F and type in the word or words you want to search for. Your screenreader will announce how many results have been found. Press Enter and Word will jump to the first occurrence of the word from your cursor position, as well as remind you to press the Spacebar to jump to the next occurrence. Press Escape to return to the text if this is the occurrence you were looking for. If not, press the Spacebar to jump to the next one, and each subsequent occurrence. If your cursor is no longer situated in the Find dialog, you can press Control + Page down and Control + Page up to navigate to the next and previous occurrence of your search text, respectively.

Because invoking the Find command changes the behavior of the Control + Page up and Control + Page down keystrokes, these no longer perform their original functions of navigating to the previous and next page. This can be annoying. To remedy this, press Control + G to invoke the Go to page command, type in a page number, and press Enter and Escape. Control + Page up and Control + Page down will once again work for navigating to the previous and next page in your document. This same issue is experienced with the Find and replace command below.

The Find and replace command is a great time-saver if you have to replace numerous occurrences of a word, phrase, or special character with something else, or you need to delete it. The shortcut key is Control H. A few examples help to illustrate its utility.

The screenreader program “JAWS” should be written in all caps. But if you have mistakenly written it with only the first letter capitalized, and you have repeated this many times in your document, it will be tedious to find every occurrence and manually correct it. Instead, do the following:

1.    Press Control H, which lands you in the Find edit field. Type in the incorrect “Jaws” (minus the quotes).

2.    Tab once to the Replace field and type in the correct “JAWS” in all caps, minus the quotes.

3.    Tab several times to the Replace all button, and press Enter or the Spacebar. Your screenreader will say “All done. We made 46 replacements,” or whatever the correct number is.

4.    Your focus is on an OK button. Press the Spacebar to finish.

5.    Press the Escape key to exit the Find and replace dialog.

Here’s another example, and one I use frequently. If you copy and paste text from the Internet into Word, it often comes in with lots of unwanted hard returns between lines. The special character for the hard return is caret P. Press Shift 6 on the number row to type the caret symbol. To remove the extra hard returns, type in “caret P” twice in the Find field, type it in once in the Replace field, Tab to Replace all, and press Enter or the Spacebar. This will remove the unwanted hard returns while preserving those for separating paragraphs. Repeat this until you are down to zero replacements. Press the Escape key when finished.

To entirely delete multiple occurrences of some text, type the text in the Find field, leave the Replace field empty, Tab to Replace all, and press Enter.

Additional special characters that I have sometimes found useful to find, and sometimes also replace include:

·         ^B: Section break.

·         ^G: Graphic image.

·         ^l: line break, also known as a vertical tab.

·         ^M: Manual page break.

·         ^t: Tab.

A complete list of special character symbols can be found at:

Twenty Helpful Search Strings for Finding Special Characters in Word

3.10.2 Skim Reading Text

Often, it is not worth your time to read every word in a document. You may want to get a quick general sense of a document’s content before reading it in-depth. You can save yourself a lot of time and be more efficient if you have a skim reading strategy.

Sighted readers often skim read by glancing in a few key places on the page and moving on. How can screenreader users accomplish the same thing? The basic idea is to jump from paragraph to paragraph, listening to just enough text to get a general idea of the content. There are several ways you can do this. Below are a few of them.

The keystroke to jump to the next paragraph and read it is Control + Down arrow. To skim read, hold down Control + And don’t let it up. Now Down arrow to hear the first few words of the next paragraph. Once you have a quick sense of its content, Down arrow to move to the next paragraph, listen a bit, and so on. Obviously, when you arrive at an important paragraph, listen all the way through. Because Control + Down arrow is a Windows keystroke, it works with all three screenreaders.

With JAWS and Narrator, another way to achieve the same result is to use a combination of Quick Keys mode and Scan mode, respectively and P (for paragraph). With JAWS, press Insert and Z together to turn on Quick Keys mode. Now press the letter P to jump to the next paragraph, read a bit, press P again, read some more, and so on.

With Narrator, press Insert + Spacebar to turn on Scan mode. Now press the letter P to jump to the next paragraph, and proceed the same way as mentioned in the previous paragraph.

NVDA does not support first letter paragraph navigation with P, so only the Control + Down arrow technique will work.

JAWS also has a useful Skim Reading utility. Access it in the JAWS Manager by pressing Insert + F2, and then the letter S several times to navigate to the Skim Reading tool. Press Enter to open this dialog. You first land on a list of radio buttons. The first option in the list is Read the first line of every paragraph. The second one is First sentence of every paragraph. Up or Down arrow to your choice. The advantage of this tool is that you can start it up with a single keystroke and listen continuously without having to press any other keys. It can be a very nice way to skim through a document while sitting back in your chair and munching on a bag of Doritos. However, if you do not want to hear each entire line or sentence, you can press the Right Shift key to interrupt speech and immediately move to the first line or sentence of the next paragraph and continue skim reading. Press the Left Shift key to interrupt speech and return to the previous paragraph and read its first line or sentence.

The JAWS Skim Reading tool is quite versatile and does other things too. See Chapter 3.10.5 on using it to quickly find and navigate to format changes in Word documents, including highlighted text.

3.10.3 Go To Command

If you are in a large document with many pages, the Go To command will help you to quickly navigate to a given page. Press either Control + G or F5 to open the dialog, type in the page number you want to navigate to, and press Enter. Now press Escape to exit the dialog and you will now be situated at the top of that page.

The Go to command default is page, but you can also use it to navigate to other elements in your document, including bookmarks, discussed in the next section.

3.10.4 Bookmarks

Insert bookmarks in documents so you can quickly navigate to important passages in the text. You need to know how to create bookmarks, as well as how to navigate to and manage them once you have created them. To add a bookmark:

1.    Navigate in your document to the place where you want to Insert the bookmark.

2.    Press the shortcut key Alt N K. The Bookmarks command is situated in the Lower ribbon of the Insert tab, but is difficult to find. Alternatively, you can press Control + Shift + F5.

3.    You land in an edit field. Type in the name of your bookmark. The name cannot have any spaces between words. Type in a single word, or if you want it to have more than one word, place an underscore between the words or use camel case (examples: world_news or WorldNews). You also cannot repeat the same name in your document - each name must be unique.

4.    Press Tab once to the Add button and press Enter or Spacebar.

Once created, use the Go To command to navigate to your bookmarks. Steps are:

1.    Press Control + G or F5.

2.    By default, the Go To command is set for Pages. To change this, press Shift + Tab once, and Down arrow to Bookmarks.

3.    Press Tab once and you land in a combo box with your list of current bookmarks.

4.    Down arrow or first-letter navigate to your bookmark choice, and press Enter.

5.    Press Escape to exit the dialog and land on your bookmark location.

With JAWS, there is another way to navigate to bookmarks which is quicker than the above method. Turn on Quick Keys mode by pressing Insert + Z. Now press B and Shift B to go to the next or previous bookmark.

To delete bookmarks if you no longer want them:

1.    Press Alt N K or Control + Shift + F5 to get into the Bookmarks dialog.

2.    Up or Down arrow to the bookmark you want to delete.

3.    Tab to the Delete button and press Enter or Spacebar.

3.10.5 Highlighting Text and Accessing It With the JAWS Skim Reading Tool

An alternative to bookmarking is highlighting. Many sighted students use a colored marker (usually yellow) to highlight text that they want to refer back to while studying. Unlike with bookmarks, you can highlight large segments of text. And then use the JAWS Skim Reading tool to quickly navigate to those passages, as well as create a summary document containing all or some of the highlighted text. This is just one use of the Skim Reading utility. It is also a versatile tool for finding and quickly accessing format changes in Word documents. Neither NVDA nor Narrator have a comparable tool.

I will first discuss how a student can highlight text as a study aid, and then access it efficiently. After that, I will discuss an example where one of my clients needed a way to find text passages where sighted work colleagues had changed the font color to draw attention to those passages. The first example involves changing the background color of selected text, while the second one involves changing the foreground color.

To change the background color, first select the text you want to highlight. Then navigate to the Text highlight split button in the Font group of the Home tab. The default color is yellow. Press enter or Spacebar to accept the default, or Press Alt + Down arrow to expand the split button and pick another color. The ribbon shortcut key is Alt H I (my mnemonic device is Alt followed by the first two letters of “highlight).

From here on, I will assume you choose the yellow default background. If you Press Insert + F to check formatting, it should say “black on yellow” rather than the “black on white default. Note that it may not say this immediately, but after a few tries, JAWS will eventually indicate the new background color.

After highlighting text, you can now use the JAWS Skim Reading tool to quickly access your highlights as follows:

1.    With your cursor located anywhere in the Word document, press Insert + F2. This opens the JAWS Manager where a number of JAWS utilities are found.

2.    Press the letter S several times to the Skim Reading tool and press Enter.

3.    Down arrow to the Use rule type: attribute and color rule radio button.

4.    Tab to the Color or attribute rules: background color” combo box and press Y to first-letter navigate to yellow.

5.    Tab to the Speak unit combo box and choose between lines, sentences, or paragraphs containing text. Which of these you choose depends on how you have highlighted the text. If you have primarily highlighted individual lines or sentences, choose one of those in the combo box. If you have tended to highlight entire paragraphs, choose that one. Experiment a bit for best results.

6.    Tab to the Start skim reading button and press Enter to have the highlighted text read back to you in Say all mode.

7.    Or probably more useful, Tab one more time to the Create summary button and press Enter.

Activating the Create summary button generates a Skim reading results window with each of the highlighted text segments appearing as links. Press Enter on any of these links to get back into the Word document at that point. The Skim reading results window remains open as a separate window, so you can Alt + Tab back and forth between it and the Word document, activating other links to return to the document at their corresponding locations.

After you have skim read highlighted text, JAWS saves the rule so you don’t need to repeat the steps above to specify your skim reading parameters. From now on, when you open the Skim Reading tool you will immediately land on the Rules history combo box. Up or Down arrow through the rules you have created. For the above example, JAWS says, “star slash yellow,” minus the quotes. The star before the slash signifies the default foreground color )black). Yellow after the slash indicates this to be the background color.

You can then Tab to the Create summary button or the Start skim reading button to perform these actions again.

You might find it useful to create a new file where you can save the highlighted text. To do this:

1.    In the Skim reading results window, press Control + A to select all the text.

2.    Press Control + C to copy it to the clipboard.

3.    Press Control + N to open a new Word document.

4.    Press Alt H V T to paste the text only. Don’t do a simple paste because this will keep the link formatting which is no longer useful when saved in a new document. Each former link will be numbered.

To delete rules if you no longer need them, return to the JAWS Skim Reading tool and Tab a number of times to the Delete rule button or Delete all rules button, and then press Enter to activate it.

To see how JAWS reads highlighted text, several blocks of text have been highlighted in this section (including this paragraph). Try the various tools above to check it out. First, verify that the font coloring has changed by pressing Insert + F anywhere in this paragraph. You should hear that font colors are black on yellow.

Now let’s create another rule, this time to detect changes in the foreground color. The issue is that sighted colleagues have changed the font color to red for text that they want you to review. Here too, I have changed the foreground color to red in a few places, this sentence included, where if you press Insert + F, you should hear “red on white.” If this is your first time creating a Skim Reading rule, do the following:

1.    Press Insert + F2 to open the JAWS Manager.

2.    Press S several times to the Skim Reading tool and press Enter.

3.    Down arrow to the Use rule type: attribute and color rule radio button.

4.    Tab to the Color or attribute rules: text color” combo box and press R to select red.

5.    Tab to the Speak unit combo box and choose between lines, sentences, or paragraphs containing text.

6.    Tab to the Start skim reading button and press Enter or Spacebar to have the highlighted text read back to you.

7.    Or Tab again to the Create summary button and press Enter.

You can now navigate the red-colored foreground text in all the same ways as outlined earlier.

This rule will be sabed with JAWS saying, “red slash star,” minus the quotes. JAWS is indicating red as the foreground color against a default white background.

If you have previously used rules and have not deleted them, JAWS remembers this, and it is quicker to create a new rule. Steps are:

1.    Press Insert + F2 to open the JAWS Manager.

2.    Press S several times to the Skim Reading tool and press Enter.

3.    This time you immediately land in the Use rule type combo box with your focus on the last rule that you used.

4.    Up arrow to “Less new greater.”

5.    Tab through all the choices, making your selection or selections. You can make rules for detecting the full array of font attributes (bold, italics, superscripts, etc.), as well as combinations.

6.    Tab to either the Start skim reading button or the Create summary button and press Enter to generate the list of results and create the new rule.

Finally, what if you want to remove the color formatting changes discussed above. You could manually remove them individually. But if there are a large number of them, this will be tedious and time-consuming. You can instead use the Find and replace command covered in Chapter 3.10.1. However, there will be a few twists and turns. The process can be finicky, but if you can make it work, it will be less tedious than removing color changes one at a time. It involves a lot of tabbing, and there are several places where it really matters whether you press Enter or Spacebar. Press the key I specify.

I will first cover removing the red font foreground color, reverting it back to the black default. From anywhere in the document:

1.    Press Control + F to open the Find dialog.

2.    Tab once to the Search split button and press Alt + Down arrow to expand it.

3.    Down arrow to Advanced find and press Enter.

4.    Tab to the More button and press Enter. If it instead says Less button, continue tabbing.

5.    Tab to the Format menu button and press Enter.

6.    You land on the Font tab. Press Enter again.

7.    Tab to the Font Color button and press the Spacebar to open it.

8.    If using Word 365, you should be able to Left arrow several times to red. With other versions, you may need to arrow around a bit more to find it. Press Enter.

9.    Tab several times to the OK button and press Enter.

10. Press Alt P until you hear that the Replace tab is selected.

11. Tab to the Replace all button and press Enter. Because you are replacing with the black default foreground color, there is no need to repeat the process of selecting a replacement color.

12. Rerun the red foreground color rule with the JAWS Skim Reading tool to confirm that no red font coloring remains.

Most of the steps for removing yellow text highlighting are identical to those listed above. However, after completing step five above (that is, pressing Enter on the Format menu button), when you land on the Font dialog, Up or Down arrow to Highlight and press Enter. Now skip steps six through nine, and repeat steps ten through twelve. The background color for all text should be returned to the white default.

3.10.6 Extended Text Selection

Sometimes you need to select a large block of text, perhaps several pages, and repeatedly pressing keystrokes for selecting smaller segments of text is inefficient. Both JAWS and NVDA have an Extended text selection command that makes this process much quicker and easier than trying to select a large number of lines or paragraphs.

To perform Extended text selection with JAWS:

1.    With your cursor situated at the beginning of the text you wish to select, press Control + Windows + K, which is the keystroke for creating a temporary placemarker. JAWS will say “marking place.”

2.    Place your cursor at the end of the text you wish to select, and press Insert + Spacebar, and then M. Be sure to hold down the Insert and Spacebar together until you hear a click. Then press M. Don’t try to hold down all three keys together. JAWS will say “selecting between marked place and current position.”

3.    The text is now selected, and you can copy it with Control + C, cut it with Control + X, or delete it with the Delete key. If you copy or cut the selected text, you can then navigate to where you want to paste it and press Control + V.

With NVDA:

1.    With your cursor situated at the beginning of your text selection, press Insert + F9. NVDA will say “start marked.”

2.    Place your cursor at the end of your text selection, and press Insert + F10. NVDA will tell you how many characters have been selected.

3.    You can now copy, cut, paste, or delete your selection.

Here’s another way that works with all three screenreaders because it is a Windows process. However, audio feedback may not be very good.

1.    At the beginning of your text selection, press F8. JAWS will say “extended selection mode on.” Narrator won’t say anything, but it is on.

2.    Navigate to the end of the text you want to select.

3.    Use standard keystrokes to copy, cut, or delete the text.

3.10.7 Paste Text Only

Often when you copy and paste text from one application to another, simply pasting with Control + V will import undesired formatting from the original source. This frequently happens when copying text from a website into a Word document. You may very well import font styles, sizes, and colors that are very strange. Using the Paste text only command can help avoid problems like this.

Let’s say you are on a web page and wish to copy text from there and paste it into a Word document. First, select the text and copy it as you normally would by pressing Control + C. Now press the Applications key, Down arrow twice to Paste options, Left arrow once to Paste text only, and press Enter. Alternatively, use the shortcut key, which is Alt H V T.

3.10.8 Word Count

Teachers often require a word count limit on class assignments. Newspapers specify word limits for article submissions.

There are several ways to get a word count. One way is to go to the Review tab of the Upper ribbon, Tab several times into the Lower ribbon to Word count, and press Enter. This reveals the number of pages in the document, the word count, and several other statistics. The ribbon shortcut is Alt R W. You can also press Control + Shift G to get the same information.

With JAWS, you can also get a word count by opening the Status bar with the keystroke Insert Page up. You will first hear the page you are on, the total number of pages in the document, and then the word count.

To get the word count for a segment of text rather than the entire document, select the text and repeat any of the keystrokes above to get statistics for just that text.

3.10.9 Customizing the Status Bar

You can quickly access some useful information about the status of your document on the Status bar. Visually, the Status bar is a horizontal window at the bottom of your screen. To access it:

·         With JAWS, press Insert + Page down.

·         With NVDA, press Insert + Shift + End to access it if using Laptop keyboard mode or Insert + End if using Desktop mode.

·         With Narrator, press F6 until you hear Status bar. Then Down arrow line by line to hear document status information.

To customize what information appears in the Status bar:

1.    While in an open document, press F6 until you get to the Status bar pane.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow through the list, and press the Spacebar to check those options you would like listed in the Status bar.

3.    Press Escape when finished.

There are many options. I find that the most useful are page number, vertical position on page, and word count. If you have some usable vision, information related to zoom levels may also be useful.

Using similar procedures, it is also possible to customize the Status bar in Excel and PowerPoint. However, I don’t find the Status bar information available for those applications particularly useful.

3.10.10 Inserting Special Characters
