·         If your primary email client is Outlook, consider adding your Microsoft account to Outlook to preserve your contacts in the Cloud and to be able to access them on your iPhone.

4.10.2 Syncing on the iPhone

To successfully sync with your iPhone, you need to add the email account you have decided to use with Outlook to your Mail, Calendar, and Contacts settings.

To add an account to Mail, open Settings/Mail/Accounts/Add accounts. Then choose the correct account type. Choices include Microsoft Exchange, Google, and several others. Then type in your email address and password. Once added, you can toggle on or off Mail, Contacts, Calendar, and a few other things. This step must be done first.

If you toggle on Contacts, you can now find them in one of the lists appearing in the Contacts app, as well as in the Contacts tab of the Phone app.

Assuming you toggled on Calendar above, To add the account to the native iPhone Calendar app, open this app and double tap on the Calendars button at the bottom of the screen. If the account appears here, double tap on it to select it. If it does not appear, there is an Add Calendar button near the bottom of the screen. Double tap there and add it.

If you are like me, preferring to quickly add events to your iPhone using Siri rather than going through the tedium of opening the Calendar app and typing in the information, go to Settings/ Calendar/Default Calendar, and select the same email account as above. When you ask Siri to schedule events, they should now appear on all your devices. On your iPhone, the account used for creating the event is identified for each meeting.

After completing these steps, experiment by adding test events and contacts to Outlook and seeing if they show up on your iPhone. Then add test events and contacts in the other direction. Ask Siri to create events on your iPhone and see if they show up in both the iPhone and Outlook Calendars.

4.10.3 Other Syncing Issues

·         If you have multiple accounts in Outlook, and you receive and accept an invitation, but the meeting information is not moved to your preferred Outlook Calendar folder, go to the Trash or Deleted items folder of the email account from which you accepted the invitation, find the deleted invitation message,, copy and paste it into the Inbox of the account associated with your preferred Calendar, and accept the invitation from there. The meeting information should now be properly synced across your devices.

If you have both work and personal accounts in your Outlook, Just be careful to prepare and send meeting invitations from the correct account to keep work and personal affairs separate. Also, if syncing problems seem to involve a work account, ask your network administrator for assistance. There may be issues related to granting permission to view and edit Calendars and how work and personal Calendars are managed.

Here are two useful articles for learning more about the ins and outs of syncing and account data backup.  First, from Microsoft Support:

Sync basics - what you can and cannot sync

And a comprehensive blog authored by Svetlana Cheusheva:

How to back up Outlook emails automatically or manually

4.11 Other Useful Tools and Commands

4.11.1 Detecting the Number of Messages in a Message List

It used to be consistently possible to open the Status bar and hear the number of messages in your Inbox or other folders containing a list of messages. This still might work for some people, but is unreliable for others. I have found that the easiest and most dependable way to do this is to place your focus on a message in the message list, and press the following keystrokes:

·         JAWS and Narrator: Insert + Up arrow, Insert + Tab, or Insert + Numpad 5. With the last of these only Caps lock works with Numpad 5.

·         NVDA: Insert + Tab or Caps lock Numpad 5 (as with Narrator, Insert does not work as a modifier key). .

With one exception, you will first hear all the typical information you hear when Down arrowing through a message list (name of sender, subject, and date and time). You will then hear the message number and finally the total number of messages in the list (example: one of 150).

The one exception is when you press Insert + Numpad 5 with JAWS. In this case, you hear only the read/unread status and number of the current message, and the number of messages in the list (example: message read, 10 of 405).

4.11.2 Turning Off the Reading pane

The Reading pane causes message lists to misbehave in a couple of ways. It can visually hide parts of messages, causing them to read incorrectly. Down arrowing can make the unread message labels disappear even if you have not opened them. If you encounter either of these problems, you will want to turn off the Reading pane. To do this:

1.    Press Alt to open the Upper ribbon, and Right arrow to the View tab.

2.    Tab to the Reading pane submenu and press Enter (the shortcut key is Alt V P N).

3.    Down arrow to Off and press Enter or the Spacebar to uncheck it. If it is already unchecked, pressing Enter or the Spacebar will not uncheck it.

4.11.3 Turning Off New Message Notifications

By default, whenever a new message arrives in your Inbox, your screenreader will announce the sender and subject. This may be distracting and can hinder your privacy if people nearby hear the announcement. To turn this off:

1.    Press Alt F T to open the Options categories menu

2.    In the Category list, Down arrow once to Mail (do not press Enter).

3.    Tab several times to the Message arrival sound checkbox which is checked by default. I like to keep this one on. You will hear a “boing” when messages arrive.

4.    Tab to Show an envelope icon in the Taskbar checkbox and press the Spacebar to uncheck it.

5.    Tab to the Display a desktop alert checkbox and press the Spacebar to uncheck it.

6.    Shift + Tab back to the OK button and press the Spacebar. You could Tab instead, but this is an extremely lengthy dialog box. Shift + Tabbing is much faster.

4.11.4 Message Preview 

Outlook’s Message Preview  mode allows you to go through a message list and hear the first several lines of message text in addition to standard message header information (sender, subject, date and time, and message size.), thus giving you a quick idea of message content. It can also save lots of time because you no longer need to open short messages to read them. Nor waste time opening messages that you would otherwise have deleted as soon as you heard a bit of the text.

Enabling Message Preview  involves adding a new column to the table where the list of messages are arrayed. Steps for enabling Message Preview  are:

1.    While in the message list for the folder you want to enable preview mode, open the View tab, Tab to the Add columns button, and press Enter. The ribbon shortcut is Alt V A C.

2.    Tab to Auto-forwarded which is the first item in a list of message fields.

3.    Press M a few times to first-letter navigate to Message.

4.    Tab twice to the Add button and press Enter, thus adding an additional column to each line in your message list.

5.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

The new column wit Message Preview  is now added, but when you listen, you will notice a problem. Message Preview  is last in the reading order, meaning you will have to first hear all the rest of the message header information before hearing the preview. If you keep it this way, it will take an annoyingly long time to hear the preview, thus defeating the whole purpose. To resolve this, return to the Add columns dialog and move the preview up in the reading order. My preference is to have it read third, after sender and subject. Steps for making this change are:

1.    Press Alt V A C to open the Add columns dialog.

2.    Tab to “Not selected Importance,” the first item in the list of currently displayed columns. (Message is now present at the bottom of this list because we added it earlier).

3.    Down arrow or press M to first-letter navigate to Message. It will probably be the tenth item in this list of ten items.

4.    Tab once to the Move up button and press Enter. If you Shift + Tab back once, you will notice that it is now the ninth of ten items.

5.    Tab once and press Enter to move it up again once in the sequence. If you Shift + Tab back once, you will notice that it is now the eighth of ten items.

6.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

Now listen to a message in the list, and reading order should now be sender, subject, Message Preview , date and time, and message size.

A Move down button is also present in the dialog. You can also find a Remove button just before this list if you want to delete a field. Experiment a bit to figure out your preference.

If you want to apply this view to additional folders, steps are:

1.    While in the folder where you added Message Preview , go to the View tab, Tab to the Current View submenu, and press Enter.

2.    Down arrow to Apply current view settings to other folders,  and press Enter.

3.    This opens a tree view of your folder structure with checkboxes for each folder and subfolder. Press the Spacebar on those folders to which you wan to apply this new view which includes Message Preview .

4.    The next tab allows you to apply this view to all subfolders of any folders you have checked. But see below on why you should not do this.

5.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

6.    Navigate to one of the folders you think you have chosen and verify that the preview now appears.

Do not choose the apply current view to all subfolders option because you are presumably starting this process in your Inbox where the From field is the first header field. Applying your Inbox view to other account subfolders will mess up your Sent items folder. The From field will replace the To field, and you will only see that all messages are sent from you, which is useless. Therefore, either judiciously check the correct checkboxes in the tree view, or add the Message Preview  column one folder at a time.

If you decide you no longer wish to use Message Preview  in a folder where it is enabled, remove it as follows:

1.    Press Alt V A C to open the Add columns dialog.

2.    Tab to “Not selected Importance,” and press M to first-letter navigate to Message.

3.    Shift + Tab once to the Remove button and press Enter.

4.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

Message Preview  is a real game changer because anything you can do to save time and keystrokes when plowing through your email inbox every day is worth trying out.

4.11.5 Flagging Messages

Like me, you may be guilty of sometimes telling yourself that a message is important for reading later or taking some follow-up action, but then forgetting to do it. Flagging messages and later filtering them when you have more time to find them can help you break this bad habit. Relevant keystrokes can be found in the ribbons and Applications key.

To flag a message for follow-up later, with your focus on it in the Inbox, press the ribbon shortcut key combination Alt H U M. Alternatively, press the Applications key, Down arrow to the Follow up submenu, and press Enter twice (twice because Flag message is the first item in this submenu). Now when you Up or Down arrow through your Inbox, your screenreader will announce “red flag.”

To unflag a flagged message, the ribbon shortcut key combination is Alt H U E. If using the Applications key, open the Follow-up submenu mentioned above, Down arrow once to Clear flag, and press Enter.

Getting a list of flagged messages in your Inbox involves using the Filter command in the Home tab of the ribbon. The ribbon shortcut key combination is Alt H L F. When finished with this filtered list, press Escape to return to your unfiltered Inbox.

4.11.6 Creating Signatures

A signature is text that appears at the bottom of every message you send, or in other words, a footer. In a job setting, signatures are commonly used to display contact information. People sometimes add signatures with a few lines of a favorite song lyric or some catchy quote. I don’t much care for this latter type of signature, being usually too smarmy for my taste. Constant repetition from the same person gets old fast. Never use such signatures in professional and academic settings. Contact information is the only acceptable type of signature in these contexts.

While it is possible to format text and insert it into the Signature dialog box, it is much easier to first prepare it in Word. Here are the steps:

1.    Prepare your text in Word, press Control + A to select all, and press Control + C to copy the text to the clipboard.

2.    Open Outlook, and press Alt F T to open the Options category list.

3.    In the Category list, Down arrow once to Mail.

4.    Tab several times to the Signatures button and press the Spacebar. This opens the Signatures dialog, landing you on an OK button that you do not want to activate yet.

5.    Tab to the New button and press the Spacebar. Focus is placed in the Name edit field.

6.    Type in a name for your signature (for example, “Work” if you are creating it for your job), and press enter.

7.    Tab to the 'new messages' combo box. Down arrow to the name of your new signature. There is often a delay here, so you may need to Down arrow several times until you hear it. This will add the signature at the bottom of all new messages you prepare.

8.    Tab to the 'replies and forwards' combo box. Down arrow to the name of your new signature. Here too, there might be a slight delay. This will add the signature at the bottom of all replies and forwarded messages you prepare.

9.    Tab multiple times to the Edit Signature edit field, ignoring all the formatting options. It is just before the OK button.

10. Press Control + V to paste your signature into this edit field.

11. Tab to the OK button and press the Spacebar. Focus will be back in the Options dialog box.

12. Press Escape to exit this dialog.

To test that your signature has been added, press Control + N to prepare a new message. Tab to the body of the message and Down arrow. The signature should now appear at the bottom of the message.

To delete a signature that you no longer want:

1.    Press Alt F T to open the Options category list.

2.    Down arrow once to Mail, tab several times to the Signatures button, and press the Spacebar.

3.    Tab to the Select signature to edit list box, and place focus on the signature you want to delete.

4.    Tab to the Delete button and press Enter. Confirm that you want to delete it.

5.    Press Escape to exit this dialog.

6.    To test that this signature has been deleted, press Control + N to prepare a new message. Tab to the body of the message and Down arrow. The signature should no longer appear.

4.11.7 Saving Messages

For those messages you consider especially important, it is a good idea to save them to your computer, somewhere external to Outlook. While custom Outlook folders are also a good place to store messages for later use, I don’t entirely trust messages to remain there permanently. Too many times, messages have inexplicably disappeared from my custom folders. Saving them elsewhere is the best way to avoid these unpleasant surprises.

You can save messages in different file formats, the most common being .MSG and .TXT. The MSG format saves only the message body text in HTML format. In contrast, the TXT format saves the complete message, including the message header (sender and recipient email addresses, time stamp, and subject line), as well as the message body. This is my preferred format for saving Outlook messages. Steps for doing this are:

1.    With focus either in an open message or on it in a message list (inbox, sent items, etc.), press F12 to open the Save as dialog.

2.    You land in the Filename edit field, where the message subject line followed by the default .MSG Outlook file extension appears.

3.    Tab once to the Save as type combo box, and Up arrow to Text Only (*.txt).

4.    Shift + Tab once to verify that the file extension has changed.

5.    Press Enter to save to the default folder location, or Shift + Tab back to change the save location, as explained in Chapter 2.10.1.2.

When you navigate to the TXT file and press Enter, it will open in Notepad, which is the default app for opening this file format. If you would rather open it in Word, use the Open with command accessed via the Applications key.

4.11.8 Automated Out of Office Messages

People often prepare Out of Office reply messages when they are going to be absent from work due to vacation, sick leave, or some other reason. There are several ways to do this, and this depends in part on the type of email account you have at work:

·         If your workplace operates in the Microsoft environment, your work email account is a Microsoft Exchange account, and you will do it through the Info tab in Outlook.

·         If your workplace operates in the Google Workspace, you can set this up online. This method is covered in Chapter 12.6.6.

·         You can set it up in Rules and Alerts. Use this method for other account types.

·         I will cover the Microsoft Exchange account and Rules and Alerts methods in this section.

·         Before starting the process of creating your auto-reply message, it is easier to draft the text of your message in Word, and copy it to the Clipboard for eventual pasting.

·         In the Auto-reply dialog. Here’s a typical example: “I will be out of the office until [insert date] an unable to respond to your message until then. If your message is time-sensitive, please contact [colleague name and contact information].”

·         You may wish to save this text in Word so you do not have to retype it the next time you need to prepare an out of office reply.

4.11.8.1 Microsoft Exchange account Method

·         Steps for creating an out of office reply with a Microsoft Exchange account are:

1.    Starting in one of the folders in your Exchange account, press Alt + F + I to open the Info tab.

2.    Tab to the list of accounts where your work account is selected.

3.    Tab to the Automatic replies button and press Enter.

4.    You land on the Do not send automatic replies radio button, Down arrow once to the send automatic replies radio button.

5.    Tab once to the Only send during this time range: checkbox and press the Spacebar to check it.

6.    Tab to the Start date edit box, and type it in MM/DD/YYY format.

7.    Tab to the Start time edit box and type it.

8.    Tab to the End date edit box and type it.

9.    Tab to the End time edit box and type it.

10. Tab to the Auto-reply message for people inside my organization edit box and paste your message from the Clipboard.

11. To add a message for people outside your organization, press Control Tab. If this option does not appear, you will need to contact your network administrator.

12. Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

13. Press Escape to exit the Info tab.

·         The auto-reply message will be disabled on the end date and time that you specified when creating it. If you want to disable it before then, return to the Info tab and tab to the Turn off button and activate it.

4.11.8.2 Rules and Alerts Method

This method involves first creating a message template and then creating a rule for it to be automatically sent. Delete the rule when it is no longer needed. As mentioned above, draft the text first in Word and save it.

To create an Outlook message template:

1.    Starting in the account inbox for which you wish to create the out of office message, prepare a message, copying and pasting text from the Word file in the Subject field and body of the message. Do not address the message.

2.    Press F12 to open the Save as dialog where you land in the filename edit field pre-filled with the text you just inserted in the Subject field, and a.MSG file extension.

3.   Tab once to the Save as type combo box, and Up or Down arrow to Outlook Template (*.oft)

4.    Shift Tab once back to the Filename edit field, and press Enter to save it.

an.OFT extension (standing for (“Outlook file template), is saved in the default folder for templates, a rather long and convoluted file path which starts in your user folder.

After creating the template, you need to create a rule for using it. Steps are:

1.    Starting from the account from which you want to send an auto reply message, press Alt F I to open the Info tab, tab to Manage rules and alerts, and press Enter.

2.    You land where it identifies the folder to manage which should be the folder where you started from. Tab to the New rule button, and press Enter.

3.    You land in the Step 1 Select a template combo box. Down arrow to Apply rule on messages I receive.

4.    Tab to the Next button and press Enter.

5.    You land on Select a condition with a list of checkboxes. Down arrow to Sent only to me, and check this checkbox, or to the Where my name is in the To box and check this one, depending on your preference. You may decide to check additional checkboxes if you like.

6.    Tab to the Next button and press Enter.

7.    Under Step 1: select action, Down arrow to the Reply using a specific template checkbox and check it.

8.   Tab to Step 2 edit the rule description, Down arrow to Tab to the Select a Reply Template Combo box, and press Enter.

9.    You land in a Look in combo box. Down arrow to User templates in file system and press Enter.

10. You should hear the file path to your template. For example, I hear “ reply using C:\Users\david\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\Out of Office Reply.oft.”

11. Tab to the Finish button and press Enter. You then land on an OK button. Press Enter on this too.

If you have added multiple accounts to your Outlook, check that you have successfully created this rule by sending a message from one of your other accounts to this one. Hopefully, you will receive the autoreply message in this other account within a few seconds. If you don’t have multiple accounts, ask a colleague to send you a message and confirm that they receives the auto reply.

Steps for deleting the rule when you have returned to the office are:

1.    Starting from the account where you created the rule, press Alt F I to open the Info tab.

2.    Tab to Manage rules and alerts and press Enter.

3.    Tab to the Delete button and press Enter. If this is the only rule you have created for this account, you will land on it. Otherwise, Up or Down arrow to it.

4.    This opens a deletion confirmation dialog which says, “Delete rule where my name is in the To box,” or whatever the rule type is that you selected earlier.

5.    Press Enter on the Yes button to confirm.

6.    Tab a number of times to the OK button and press Enter.

Be sure to verify that you actually deleted the rule. If you have more than one account in your Outlook desktop client, send a message from a different account to the account were you created the rule. Wait a minute or two and be sure you no longer receive the out of office message. If you don’t have multiple accounts added to your Outlook, confirm with a colleague. If you do not verify, you risk continuing to send out of office messages to people trying to contact you.

If it is now time to leave the office again, and you have saved your message text in a Word file as advised above, replace the initial template with a revised one as follows:

1.    Copy and paste the original text into the subject and Message body fields, making whatever modification you need, presumably at least changing the return date.

2.    Press F12 to open the Save as dialog where you land in the filename edit field pre-filled with the text in the Subject field.

3.   Tab once to the Save as type combo box, and Up or Down arrow to Outlook Template (*.oft)

4.    Tab to the Save button and press Enter.

5.    This will open a Confirm Save as dialog which says, “Out of Office Reply.oft already exists. Do you want to replace it?”

6.    Tab to the Yes button and press Enter.

Repeat the above steps for creating a new rule.

4.11.9 Reverse Sort

By default, message lists like those in your Inbox or sent items folder are arranged chronologically with the newest messages at the top of the list and the oldest ones at the bottom. However, you may open your Inbox some day and discover that the order is now “upside down” for some mysterious reason. If this happens, you can quickly fix it by using the Reverse sort command which is found in the View tab of the ribbons. Press Alt to open the Upper ribbon, Right arrow to the View tab, Tab to the Reverse Sort button (shortcut key: Alt V R S), and press Enter. Some people prefer having their oldest messages arranged at the top of the list. If you are one of these rare individuals, use the Reverse sort command to get them in your preferred order.

4.11.10 Expanding and Collapsing Groups

It is useful to know about this command for two reasons. First, if you open Outlook one day and find that today’s messages are “collapsed,” you will want to know how to undo this so you can access them. Second, it can be a useful housecleaning tool for speeding up the chore of deleting large numbers of unwanted messages.

It sometimes happens that you open your Inbox and hear “today collapsed.” You then Down arrow, and only find messages from the day before or earlier. Fortunately, this is easy to fix. Press either Enter or the Spacebar to expand it. You can now Down arrow through today’s messages and read them.

The Expand/collapse groups command can be useful for speeding up the process of clearing unwanted messages out of your folders. By default, message lists are expanded.

To collapse groups:

1.    Press Alt to open the Upper ribbon, and Right arrow to the View tab.

2.    Tab to the Expand/collapse groups submenu (the shortcut is Alt V E) and press Enter. The four submenu choices are: Collapse this group, Expand this group, Collapse all groups, and Expand all groups.

3.    Down arrow to Collapse all groups and press Enter.

How collapsed groups appear depend on how they are initially sorted. If sorted by date and today happens to be Tuesday, collapsed groups are listed as follows: today, yesterday, Sunday, last week, two weeks ago, three weeks ago, last month, and older.

If you are OK with deleting all messages in a particular folder that are more than one month old, this can be quickly done by Down arrowing to the Older collapsed group, pressing Delete, and then Enter to confirm moving them to the Deleted items or Trash folder.

If a message list is initially sorted by sender (See Chapter 4.5 on how to do this), they are collapsed alphabetically with the name of the sender, number of total messages, and number of unread messages in the group indicated. For example, as you Down arrow, you will hear: From: Amazon.com: 6 item(s), 5 unread; From: Andrew Jones: 11 items; and so on.

My favorite example concerns a student I had several years ago who had allowed about 20,000 messages to accumulate in his inbox. We first sorted his messages by sender and then collapsed all the groups. He then navigated to the collapsed Facebook group which contained about 8,000 messages. With one or two keystrokes, he moved all those messages to his trash folder. The process took about ten minutes because it takes time to move such a massive number of messages from one folder to another, but that was much better than deleting them one by one.

When finished sorting by sender, and/or collapsing all groups, repeat the above steps to return to the default with all groups expanded and sorted by date.

On occasion, people find that the Expand Collapse submenu command is grayed out or unavailable. If this happens to you, do the following to make it appear:

1.    Open the Arrange by submenu in the View tab (shortcut: Alt V A B).

2.    Up arrow twice to Show in groups and press the Spacebar to check it.

4.11.11 Changing the Outlook Start (or Default) Folder

If you are using more than one email account with Outlook, and want to change the inbox that initially appears when you open the app (called either the “start” or “default” folder), do the following:

1.    Press Alt F T to open Outlook options.

2.    Down arrow or press A to the Advanced category.

3.    Tab to Outlook Start and exit browse, and press Enter.

4.    You land in the tree view of your Outlook folders. Using the same keystrokes outlined in Chapter 4.3 above on navigating your folder tree view, navigate to the desired folder, and press Enter.

5.    Shift + Tab back several times to the OK button and press Enter.

6.    To verify that Outlook opens in the new folder, press Alt + F4 to exit Outlook and reopen the app.

4.12 Exploring the New Outlook

Microsoft has been developing a new version of Outlook since 2023. While it initially had serious accessibility problems, as of early 2025, it is now mostly accessible. It is called the “New Outlook” while the existing version is called “Outlook Classic.” The Windows 10 and 11 native Mail app is no longer available. It too is rather confusingly called “Outlook.” This new native version will not be covered here.

Because of initial accessibility problems, many screenreader users who have heard of the New Outlook have been worried. Will Outlook Classic suddenly go away? Will screenreader users no longer have access to the familiar Outlook they have been using for years, forcing them to learn how to use Gmail online or some other unfamiliar application? The answer to both of these questions is a definitive no. Microsoft will continue to support Outlook Classic until 2029, and has fixed all major screenreader accessibility problems while continuing to address minor ones.

The first question you might ask is, “Should I switch to the New Outlook and abandon Outlook Classic?? There is no imperative to do this any time soon. Do it when you are ready or come to the personal conclusion that it fits your needs better than the classic version. This might not be the case right now, but as Microsoft continues to refine the New Outlook, you might find that there are advantages to switching over. Or you can go back and forth if you think the New Outlook handles some functions better than Outlook Classic.

The purpose of this section is to allay the above fears and provide guidance to those who wish to explore the New Outlook. It is not meant to be exhaustive, but can help you in getting your feet wet. I only discuss its use with Microsoft 365 because that is the only license type to which I have access.

4.12.1 Switching Between Classic and New Outlook

It is quick and easy to switch between the two versions. While preparing this section, I went back and forth many times.

To switch to the New Outlook:

1.    In Outlook Classic, press Alt to open the Upper ribbon.

2.    Tab once or twice to the Try the New Outlook button and press the Spacebar.

3.    You land on the Switch button. Press the Spacebar again.

4.    Press Insert + T to hear the title of the window, which is “Mail” and your email address. You are now in your default inbox for the New Outlook.

5.   To switch back to Classic, press Alt which opens the New Outlook Upper ribbon. The first tab is the Home tab. In the Home tab, tab several times to the Try the new Outlook Toggle switch which is on. Press the Spacebar here.

6.    A feedback dialog opens asking why you want to switch back. Tab a bunch of times to the Skip feedback button and press Enter and you will be back in Outlook Classic. For me at least, the first ten or so tabs are silent, so don’t worry as long as you eventually hear something.

4.12.2 Ribbon Menu Navigation and Initial Settings You Should Change

Like Classic Outlook, the New outlook has ribbon menus. However, Lower ribbons are navigated differently. Starting from the Inbox message list and similar to Classic Outlook, press Alt to open the Upper ribbon. Right and Left arrow to move from tab to tab along the Upper ribbon. Down arrow once to the first item in the Lower ribbon, and then Right arrow through the Lower ribbon commands for that tab.

You can also tab a few times to find a number of commands that will e the same, regardless of which Upper ribbon tab you are starting from. More on some of these commands later.

Your New Outlook experience will be better if you change two settings right off the bat. Steps are:

1.    Starting from your Inbox, press Alt to open the Upper ribbon and Right arrow to the View tab.

2.    Down arrow once to the View settings button, but do not activate it.

3.    Right arrow once to the Conversations button menu and press the Spacebar.

4.    Down arrow to Show each message separately and press the Spacebar to check it. This registers your change and exits you out of the ribbons.

5.    Press Alt again, landing you back on the View tab. Similar to Outlook Classic, it remembers which tab you were last on.

6.   Down arrow once to the View settings button, Right arrow to the Reading pane button menu, and press the Spacebar.

7.    Down arrow to the Hide Reading pane radio button and check it.

Similar to Outlook Classic, Upper ribbon tabs differ depending on the window you are in. Here is a quick listing of several of these tabs and commands appearing in their Lower ribbons:

While in a message list like your Inbox:

·         Home tab: New, Archive, Delete, Reply, Reply all, Forward, Flag

·         View tab: Settings (for accessing all settings), Conversations, Preview, Sync, Ribbon (for switching between Simplified and Classic ribbons), Reading pane.

·         Help tab: Help button, Tips, Support, Feedback. These same options appear in Help tabs for all folders.

While in the Message preparation window after pressing Control + N:

·         Insert tab: Attachments, Links, Signatures,

·         Format tab: Fonts.

·         Options tab: Editor (for spell check), Check accessibility, Show BCC, Show CC, Request receipt, Importance, Save draft.

I will cover the Lower ribbon options for the Calendar folder in the subsection on the Calendar.

I will also say more below about how to access the full array of Settings, as well as how to access some of the more useful ones.

4.12.3 Accessing Keyboard Shortcut Lists

A good place to begin your exploration of the New Outlook is checking out the lists of keyboard shortcuts. If you are familiar with Classic Outlook, you will find that many keystrokes are the same. Different lists appear depending on what folder you are in when you open the lists. To do this from your Inbox:

1.    Toggle off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor (Insert + Z) or the NVDA Browse mode (Insert + Spacebar).

2.    Press the question mark. You will hear that a modal dialog opens.

3.    Toggle back on the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or the NVDA Browse mode.

4.   Down arrow to read the keystroke combination line by line. You can also navigate by heading to hear categories. For example, from the Inbox, heading three categories include: Write email, Email list, Read email, Go to, and Email actions.

5.    When finished, activate the Close button. You can also Alt Tab away from the window and return to it. You will land back in the Inbox.

6.   Toggle off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or the NVDA Browse mode if that is your preference. Otherwise, leave it on.

If starting from your Inbox, keyboard shortcuts listed are only for Inbox actions. To explore shortcuts for the Calendar, press Control + 2 to open that folder and repeat the steps above to access keyboard shortcuts for Calendar actions. To access keyboard shortcuts for the Contacts or People folder, press Control + 3 and repeat the above steps.

4.12.4 Message and Folder Basics

Many keystrokes are the same in New Outlook and Outlook Classic. Most of the time you can keep the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode on, but there will be times when you will be required to toggle them off. When required, I will note this below. You can also experiment to see which works best for you. Remember that these toggles are Insert + Z for JAWS and Insert + Spacebar for NVDA.

Once you switch screenreader cursor modes as above, it is useful to then press Control + Shift + I so your inbox behaves correctly. Focus will be on the top message in the inbox and you can Down arrow to other messages. Or if you begin pressing the Tab key instead, it will move you through various buttons near the top of the window.

In the inbox, try the following keystrokes:

·         All basic keystrokes for reading, preparing sending, replying to, and forwarding messages are the same as with Outlook Classic.

·         Down and Up arrow to move within message lists. Press Control + Home to get to the first message in the list and Control + End to go to the last one.

·         Control + Y for opening the folder tree view, and the various arrow keys for moving between and within tree view levels.

·         Moving between folders: Control + 1 to go to the last folder you were in with a list of messages, Control + 2 to go to the Calendar, and Control + 3 to move to the People or Contacts folder.

·         It is easy to Attach files to a message you are preparing. Similar to Outlook Classic, first select and copy the file or files you wish to attach, using standard file management keystrokes. Then paste them while in the body of the message you are preparing. As with Outlook Classic, from the message body, Shift Tab once to verify that the attachment or attachments are there. Then send the message.

·         Opening attachments you have received, as well as saving them to your PC is a bit more complicated than in Classic where you can copy and paste. To save an attached file you have received:

1.    Open the message, Shift Tab to the More actions button menu, and Spacebar to open it. Alternatively, you can shift tab to the filename to select it and press the Applications key to get the options below.

2.    Down arrow to Save as and press Enter. This opens the standard Save as dialog.

3.    Choose where you would like to save the file, and after saving, access it from there.

·         One of the options is Copy, but as of early 2025, this did not work for me.

·         To open an attachment from within Outlook:

1.    Open the message, Shift Tab to the More actions button menu, and Spacebar to open it.

2.    Press Enter on Open. If an Office file like Word, it will specify the correct app. If some other file type, it will only say Open.

·         There is also a Preview option, but this involves several clunky steps. Opening the file is more straightforward.

4.12.5 Settings

Earlier, I covered a couple of initial settings you should change. Here I will discuss accessing the full array of Settings, and some of the more useful ones you may wish to change. To access Settings:

1.    Starting from your Inbox, press Alt to open the Upper ribbon and Right arrow to the View tab.

2.    Down arrow once to the View settings button, and press The Spacebar.

3.    Tab once past a Search box to a list of settings. Settings are organized in a list of higher level tabs and lower level subtabs. Down arrow through the six tabs which include Accounts, General, Mail, Calendar, People, and Premium. Spacebar to select the desired tab.

4.    Tab once to a list of subtabs, Down arrow through them, and Spacebar to select a subtab.

5.    You can now tab through the settings included in the selected subtab.

6.    If you make a change, tab to the Save button and activate it. A Discard button is also present.

Listed below are where you can find various settings you may be interested in changing:

·         Accounts tab: add and sign into email accounts here, Google calendar and contacts sync across devices (unlike with Outlook Classic).

·         Mail tab: In the Display subtab, includes Focused inbox (off by default), Message organization and Reading pane (both of which were discussed above), Message preview (off by default), In the Compose and reply messages subtab, Show BCC field.

·         General tab: under Accessibility, Set Keyboard to set to Outlook for Windows. You can also let people know you prefer accessible content.

·         The next subsections provide step by step instructions for two important settings.

4.12.5.1 Syncing Google Accounts

A big advantage of the New Outlook over Outlook Classic is that you can sync Google calendars and contacts. This is only possible With Classic if you pay for a syncing utility.

If you have already added an account to Outlook Classic, it will show up in the tree view in the New Outlook, but you need to go through an initial syncing process. Steps are:

1.    Press Control + Y to open the tree view.

2.    Navigate to your Gmail account at level 0 and Right arrow to open it.

3.    Down arrow to where you can start the sync process.

4.    In the window that says you are already partially synced in with 9 categories, activate the button for seeing this list. Down arrow to the Done button and press Enter.

5.    Activate the Open New Outlook button and the list of inbox messages for this account should now appear.

You can also add new accounts in the Your accounts subtab of the Accounts tab in Settings.

4.12.5.2 Changing the Outlook Start Folder

To change the account inbox where Outlook first lands when you open the app, and assuming the account has already been added to the New Outlook (see above), do the following:

1.    In Settings, select the Accounts tab and then the Your Accounts subtab.

2.    Tab to the Manage button labeled with the account you want to designate as the start account and press the Spacebar.

3.    Tab to the options which include remove and Set as primary account, and activate this last one.

4.    Confirm in the “are you sure?” popup by pressing the Continue button,

5.    You may need to go through the dialogs related to optional data sharing and applying settings, or you may just hear, “Gettings thing ready.”

6.    When finished, the new default start inbox will open.

7.    Press Alt + F4 to close the apt and reopen it to verify that the start inbox has changed as desired.

4.1.6 Custom Folders

For creating and managing custom folders with Classic Outlook, refer to Chapter 4.4 Above.

Steps for creating a folder in the New Outlook are:

1.    Press Control Y to open the tree view and navigate to the folder for which you want to create a custom folder (referred to from here on as a subfolder).

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Create new subfolder and press Enter.

3.    Type the name of the new subfolder and press Enter.

TO move or copy messages into a subfolder:

1.    Select the message or messages you wish to copy or move.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to either the Copy submenu or Move submenu, and press Enter.

3.    You encounter a Search box. Type in the name of the subfolder where you want to place the messages and press Enter. This pastes them in the subfolder.

To perform the four actions you can do on an existing subfolder:

1.    Press Control Y to open the tree view and navigate to the subfolder.

2.    Press the Applications key and Down arrow to the same actions as in Outlook Classic, including rename, copy, move, and delete.

4.1.7 Calendar

Press Control + 2 to go to the Calendar folder.

With the JAWS Virtual PC cursor off and NVDA Focus mode on, keystrokes that are the same as in the Outlook Classic Calendar include:

·         Tab and Shift + Tab to the next and previous event, respectively.

·         In the Day view, Up and Down arrow to move by 30 minute increments within a day, and Left and Right arrow to go back and forward one day, respectively.

·         Useful commands found in the Calendar Ribbons are:

·         Home tab: New event, Day, work week, Full week, and Month views, Filter (for viewing selected event categories only), Share calendar.

·         View tab: Same four Calendar views and Filter as above.

·         To create a new event you must first be in the Calendar folder. Press Control + N. This dialog is used both for creating appointments (events for just you) and meetings (which generate an email to invitees). This is pretty much the same as the Classic Outlook Create meeting dialog opened with Control + Shift + Q (you can also use this shortcut in the New Outlook as long as you are already in the Calendar folder). There is no separate dialog for creating an appointment.

·         In the New event dialog, you first land in the Add details for the event edit field where you give the event a title. Tab once to the Invite attendees edit combo box to add attendees. Tab once to the Optional field if you want to CC somebody about the meeting. Skip these two fields if you are just creating an appointment for yourself. All remaining fields (start date and time, end time, recurring, etc.) are the same as with the Classic dialog covered in Chapter 4.8.3 above. Pres Control + Enter or Alt + S to send a meeting invitation or save an appointment.

Chapter 5 Excel

Excel is a powerful application for organizing, manipulating, and analyzing data. It is an essential tool in work and academic environments, and can be used for managing lots of personal information. Just a few examples of common uses include:

1.    Budget preparation and monitoring

2.    Tracking inventory

3.    Tabulating and analyzing survey data

4.    Maintaining contact lists

I often advise my trainees to use Excel for anything that involves crunching numbers or making lists. While it is possible to do these things in Word, Excel is far more flexible and powerful for performing these tasks.

While reading this chapter (as well as when working in Excel), you should set your screenreader punctuation level at most or all. Setting it at some or none will fail to detect a number of punctuation marks like parentheses, colons, and a few more that are important in the syntax for creating functions. To change punctuation levels for the three screenreaders, see Chapter 8.1.1 for JAWS, 8.2.2 for NVDA, and 8.3.1 for Narrator.

5.1 The Basics

5.1.1 Terminology

A spreadsheet is a document that stores data in a grid of horizontal rows and vertical columns. Rows are usually labeled using numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.), while columns are usually labeled with letters (A, B, C, etc.). Individual row/column locations, such as C3 or B12, are referred to as cells, and each has a cell coordinate. For example, cell A3 is located in the first column and third row, cell E10 is located in the fifth column and tenth row, and so on. “Spreadsheet” is a generic term for any such document or file, including, but not limited to Excel.

An Excel file is called a workbook and may be composed of a single worksheet or many worksheets. Think of a sheet as a page.

Until you rename them, they are assigned the generic names “Sheet1, Sheet2, Sheet3, etc.” Worksheets are where information is entered and manipulated in a workbook.

When you first open a new blank Excel file, and press Insert + T to hear its title, you will hear “Book1, Sheet 1, A1.”

A blank spreadsheet is a vast area with thousands of columns and over one million rows. Columns and rows are labelled with letters and numbers, respectively. A cell reference or cell coordinate is expressed as its letter and number combination. For example, cell A1 is located in the first column and first row, cell C5 is located in the third column and fifth row, and so on. A “data range” is a group of contiguous cells. For example, the data range from B2 through B9 refers to the cells containing B2, B9 and all the cells in between in this column. A data range can also be a rectangular block of cells. The data range of B2 through F9 includes the rectangular block of cells with B2 located at the top left, B9 at the bottom left, F2 at the top right, and F9 at the bottom right.

Four types of data can be entered in cells: text, numbers, formulas, or functions. Numbers may be expressed as simple numbers, currency, dates, percentages, or in several other formats.

A formula is an expression that calculates the value of a cell, and is created by combining cell references with mathematical operators such as the symbols for adding, subtracting, multiplying, or dividing. An example is “=A1+A2” minus the quotes, for adding the values in cells A1 and A2.

Functions are predefined formulas in Excel that perform specific calculations using a set of values, called arguments, and in a particular order. They are written with a specific syntax, starting with the function name followed by parentheses. An example is “=SUM(A1:A10)” minus the quotes for summing up all the values in cells A1 through A10. Functions can be very simple or quite complex.

Most formulas and functions contain cell references or numbers from elsewhere on the spreadsheet. For example, if numbers are contained in columns A and B, a formula or function can be typed in column C to total the numbers in the respective rows of columns A and B. However, in composing the formula or function, you would not type in the actual numbers in those cells, but rather the corresponding cell coordinates.

The distinction between formulas and functions can be a bit fuzzy, and people often use the two terms interchangeably. Don’t worry too much about it. There will be much more on formulas and functions below.

5.1.2 entering Data and Navigating Spreadsheets

Use the arrow keys to move one cell at a time among the column’s and rows of the spreadsheet. The Up and Down arrows move up and down columns. The left and Right arrows move across rows.

After typing data in a cell, pressing any of the arrow keys will conserve that data in the cell and move the focus to the next cell in the direction that you just arrowed. You can also press the Tab key to move one cell to the right, equivalent to pressing the Right arrow key. In addition, pressing the Enter key will conserve the data and move the cursor one cell below. If you type in data and press the Escape key, none of the data you just typed will be conserved. If you sense that you have made a typing error, immediately press the Escape key to prevent replacing correct data with the mistaken keystroke. Failing to do this is a common frustration for beginners.

From anywhere on a spreadsheet, pressing Control + Home moves the focus to cell A1, the top left corner of the spreadsheet. Pressing Control + End places the focus on the cell that is the intersection of the right-most column with at least one cell containing data, and the bottom-most row with at least one cell containing data. For example, if the right-most cell with data is F32 and the bottom-most cell with data is A 47, pressing Control + End will place focus on cell F47. This keystroke is especially useful for exploring a spreadsheet that you did not prepare yourself. If pressing Control + End lands the cursor in cell F47, you know that all data in the sheet are located somewhere between A1 and F47. There are no data to the right of column F, nor below row 47.

While using the four arrow keys to navigate one cell at a time is useful for moving around in small areas, navigate quickly over large blocks of filled and unfilled cells by pressing the Control key in combination with the four arrow keys. This is referred to as “navigating by region.” A region is a range of cells that contain data and are bordered by blank cells. It is synonymous with a data range.

5.1.3 Simple Formulas

There are three categories of formulas:

·         Those containing operators which are the keys for adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing data from two or more specified cells.

·         Those containing functions for making calculations over a range of data.

·         And those containing a combination of operators and functions.

Let’s begin by typing the numbers 1000 in cell A1 and 250 in cell A2. Don’t type in a comma separator in 1000. Under this data, we will input several of the simplest and most common formulas.

All formulas begin with the equal sign, signaling to Excel that a formula is being entered in the cell. The equal sign is located two keys to the right of the zero key on the number row of your keyboard. When you type the equal sign, your screenreader will say “type in a formula and press Enter.” We will start with simple formulas using operators for adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing two numbers.

1.    Addition: In cell A3, type “=A1+A2,” minus the quotes, and press Enter to go down one row. Press Shift Equal (again, two keys to the right of zero on the number row) to make the plus sign. Up arrow once and you will hear “1250 has formula A3.” Your screenreader first says the result, then indicates this is a formula so you know it is not just a typed-in number. Then you hear the cell coordinate.

2.    Subtraction: In cell A4, type “=A1-A2,” minus the quotes, and press Enter. The dash is one key to the right of zero on the number row. Up arrow once and you will hear “750 has formula A4.”

3.    Multiplication: In cell A5, type “=A1*A2,” minus the quotes, and press Enter. Press Shift 8 on the number row to make the asterisk sign. Up arrow once and you will hear “250000 has formula A5.”

4.    Division: In cell A6, type “=A1/A2,” minus the quotes, and press Enter. The Slash key is just below the semicolon on the Home row. Up arrow once and you will hear “4 has formula A6.”

Now we will cover a few of the most frequently-used functions, including those for calculating the sum and average of values in a column, and finding the minimum and maximum values in that column. These functions have a three-component structure: the equal sign, short text indicating the function to be calculated, and the data range upon winch that function will be performed. Because we have data in all the cells from A1 through A6, we will use this data range. To make it easier to read the text, I will put the function on its own line and then explain it on the next line.

In cell A7, type:

=sum(A1:A6)

This totals the values in the column from cell A1 through cell A6. The three components of the function are:

·         The equal sign indicating that this is a function or formula.

·         The text of the function “sum” indicating that this is the calculation to be executed.

·         The data range, written beginning with a left parentheses, the first cell in the data range, a colon indicating “through,” the last cell in the data range, and a right parenthesis ending designation of the data range.

In cell A8, type:

·         =average(A1:A6)

This calculates the average value (also known as the mean) of the data range from A1 through A6.

In cell A9, type:

·         =min(A1:A6)

This identifies the minimum value in the data range from A1 through A6.

In cell A10, type:

=max(A1:A6)

This identifies the maximum value in the data range from A1 through A6.

Excel has a vast variety of available functions that can be used to make calculations. A good starting point for learning more about functions and formulas is:

Overview of formulas in Excel

Here you can find introductory information on formula basics, descriptions of the most commonly used functions, how to construct more complex or advanced formulas and functions, and additional reference materials and tutorials.

5.2 Constructing a Table

5.2.1 Building Blocks for a Basic Data Table

Let’s put together a table with monthly expenses for the Smith family. You usually start by putting in a name or title at the top left of the worksheet in cell A1. Then you put text down column A and across row 2. Then you enter data in the middle of the table. Let’s get started.

1.    In cell A1, type “Monthly Expenses for the Smith Family for the Year,” minus the quotes.

2.    Type “Expense” in cell A2, minus the quotes.

3.    In column A, from cells A3 to cell A10, list the following eight expense categories: Water, Electricity, Groceries, Cell phone, Cable, Rent, Transportation, and Entertainment.

4.    In cell A11, type “Monthly Total,” minus the quotes. We will eventually sum the monthly columns along row 11.

5.    In row 2, starting in cell B2, type in the months of the year across this row, with January in cell B2, February in cell C2, and so on until December in cell M2.

6.    In cell N2, type “Annual Total,” minus the quotes. We will eventually sum the rows to calculate the annual amount for each type of bill

Not counting the name of the table at the top, most basic data tables are composed of three parts:

·         Row headers: Text going down the left column. In this case, the types of bills. “Electricity” is a row header because all data across that row relate to electricity bills.

·         Column headers: Text going across the top row of the table. In this case, each of the twelve months and the last column totaling the year. “January ” is a column header because all the cost data down the January column relate to bill costs for that month.

·         Table body: To the right of the first column and under the top row is where data appear. If data are numeric (simple numbers, dollars, percentages, etc.), they are referred to as “values.” In this table, each monthly bill expense will be entered.

5.2.2 Define name – A Feature That Makes Using Excel Much Easier

After you have typed in your row and column headers, it is time to introduce an Excel feature that greatly improves readability of tables for screenreader users on the PC. When I show this feature to a screenreader user who has been struggling with Excel for a long time, he or she usually has one of those head-slapping “I wish I had known about this years ago” moments.

Sighted users can easily interpret Data in the body of a table. Let’s say the number 750 appears in cell E8 of this table. With a quick glance, a sighted user can determine that this number corresponds to the cost of rent for April. However, a screenreader user would need to Up arrow several times to the top of the column to find April, Down arrow back to 750, and then Left arrow back to column A to figure this out. This is time-consuming in even a small table like this one. It is much worse with larger tables.

Using the Define name feature largely eliminates this problem. As you move cell by cell along a row, you will hear the column header and content for each cell,. As you move cell by cell up or down a column, you will hear the row header and content for each cell. With the JAWS Eloquence voice, column and row headers are spoken in a lower pitch than the cell data. Also with JAWS, headers are read first, followed by cell content. The order is reversed with NVDA. And as of the writing of this book, this feature did not work with Narrator.

To make this feature work correctly, it is critical that you start with your focus in the cell that is the intersection of the row and column headers you want read as you move around in the body of the table. Most of the time, this will be the cell in the top left corner of your table. This does not mean the name or title you gave the table, located in the row above in cell A1.

In this table, the types of expenses are listed down column A and the months of the year are listed along row 2. The intersection of the row and column headers is therefore cell A2, and this is where you will place focus before proceeding to the next steps, which are:

1.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow twice to Define Name, and press Enter.

2.    Type in the word “title,” minus the quotes, and press Enter.

3.    To test it out, move around inside the table. As you move right and left, you should hear the column headers and cell content. As you move up and down, you should hear row headers and cell content.

This is an Excel feature designed for accessibility, so steps are no different between screenreaders. When you save the file, title reading will also be saved.

While you can activate this feature at any time, I get it going as early as possible when constructing a table. It makes all subsequent actions (data entry, navigation, creating formulas and functions, editing, etc.) much easier and less prone to error.

For some tables, you may not want to hear both column and row headers as you navigate, but just one or the other. For example, think of a bus schedule where the stops are listed along row 2,and down column A are the times of the first bus in the morning. In this case, hearing the row headers (that is, the time of the first bus) and times in the middle of the table as you up and Down arrow, would only be confusing. In this case, you would only want column headers read to you as you move left and right along rows. To hear only column headers:

1.    Navigate to the leftmost cell in the row where the column headers are located (usually the top row of the table, not counting the row with the table name).

2.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow to Define Name, and press Enter.

3.    Type in the single word “columntitle,” minus the quotes and with no spaces between column and title, and press Enter. Note that this is not case-sensitive. If you like, you can instead write it as “ColumnTitle,” with the C and T capitalized so your screenreader speaks it normally.

4.    To test it out, move around inside the table. As you move right and left, you should hear the column headers and cell content. As you move up and down, you should only hear cell content, and no row headers.

To only hear row headers:

1.    Navigate to the cell just above the topmost row header you want read, usually near the top of column A.

2.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow twice to Define Name, and press Enter.

3.    Type in the single word “rowtitle,” minus the quotes and with no space between row and title, and press Enter. Here too, use upper case for R and T if you prefer it to read normally.

4.    To test it out, move around inside the table. As you move up and down, you should hear the row headers and cell content. As you move left and right, you should only hear cell content, and no column headers.

You also need to know how to delete these for a couple of reasons. First, if you mistakenly start the above steps from the wrong cell, table reading may become incomprehensible. You must first delete any previous title reading designations before you can redefine them. Second, sometimes in the course of editing spreadsheets, you may delete some rows or columns. This may cause title reading to no longer work. Here too, you will need to delete whatever you first put in before you can redefine them. You can start the deletion process from anywhere in the spreadsheet. Steps are:

1.    Press Alt to open the Upper ribbon, and Right arrow to the Formulas tab.

2.    Tab into the Lower ribbon about ten times to the Name manager button and press Enter. The shortcut key is Control + F3.

3.    You land in a combo box where any Define name settings you have created for that file are listed. Assuming you only have one, your focus lands on it.

4.    Press the Delete key. You are asked for a deletion confirmation.

5.    Press the Spacebar to confirm, and Escape to return to your spreadsheet.

It is also possible to define column and row headers for several tables on the same sheet. You will need to do this to avoid confusion. If, for example you have defined names for a table beginning near the top left of the sheet, and you then add more tables below or to the right of this first table, the column and row headers of the first table will be read as you navigate within these other tables. You will then hear the wrong column and row headers read for these tables.

To Define name for the first table on a worksheet with two tables, you need to specify the data range of that table. The column and row headers specified will only be operative within this data range, and will not interfere with reading column and row headers for any tables outside this data range.

Using our current table as an example, the top left corner of the data range is cell A2. Because the furthest right column is column N, and the bottom row is row 11, cell N11 is the bottom right cell of the data range. Steps for defining names for this data range are:

1.    Navigate to cell A2, the top left cell of the data range.

2.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow to Define Name, and press Enter.

3.    Type in “title..N11” here. After the word title, you type in two periods and then the bottom right cell coordinate of the data range. Now press Enter.

4.    To test it out, move around inside the A2-N11 data range where you will hear column and row headers. Now move the cursor outside this data range (to the right of column M or below row 11), you will no longer hear these column and row headers spoken.

Let’s now say there is a second table on this worksheet whose top left corner is in cell A15 and bottom right corner is in cell G23. To use the Define name feature to read this table’s column and row headers, repeat the above steps, substituting A15 as the start point in step 1, and cell G23 as the bottom left cell coordinate in step 3.

The same name cannot be repeated in a single file. If you are working with multiple sheets, you cannot use the word “title” on more than one of these sheets. If you attempt to do this, you will hear the following error message: “This name already exists. Names should be unique.” To get around this, instead type in “title1, title2, etc.” without the quotes or any spaces.

If you start the Define name process in the wrong cell, as you navigate through the sheet, the verbal feedback you hear will be extremely confusing. There are also times when you may have initially started the Define name process in the correct cell, but after having edited the sheet by inserting and deleting some rows or columns, it might have become messed up. In such cases, you will need to delete the title or titles you created. To do this:

1.    Press Control + F3 to open the Name Manager (this is found in the Data tab of the ribbons).

2.    You land in a combo box where the titles you have created are listed. Up or Down arrow to the title you want to delete, and press the Delete key.

3.    You are asked to confirm the deletion. Press Enter to confirm.

You can now repeat the Define name process beginning in the correct cell.

In conclusion, the Define name feature is a great tool for making Excel sheets more readable. Use it whenever you create tables yourself, as well as when you receive a file from somebody else. The only piece of bad news is that they don’t always work well for files you get from sighted people. This is because sighted folks sometimes insert lots of blank columns and rows to visually separate data categories. This makes it hard or impossible to find a cell at the top left corner that forms the intersection of the column and row headers you want to designate as titles. QuickBooks, a popular financial management application, generates balance sheets, profit and loss statements, and other standard accounting reports in Excel format that have this problem. Chapter 5.10 offers strategies for dealing with difficult spreadsheets, including identifying the best cell for initiating the Define name process.

5.2.3 Entering Data and Summing Columns and Rows

Now it’s time to add some numeric values in the body of the table. Beginning in cell B3, and going down to cell B10, type in numbers for each of the January expense types. Just type in numbers. Don’t worry about typing in dollar signs. That will come later.

Remember that after typing in a number, you can either press Enter or the Down arrow key to go to the cell below.

When finished, make sure your focus is on cell B11, just one cell to the right of where you typed “Monthly total.”

In cell B11, we will sum the January column. When new to Excel, it can be challenging to enter functions. You should type slowly because you may not be accustomed to using several keys (left and right parentheses, the equal sign, and a few others). Excel is pretty unforgiving about typing errors. Also note that there are never any spaces in formulas and most functions. Even if you are a proficient typist, entering these can be a painstaking process. However, the good news is that you won’t have to type too many of them. As we will soon see, for the current table, you will only need to type in two functions. All the remaining ones will be copied and pasted.

First, be sure you know the addresses of the first and last cells of the data range you want to sum. Here the first cell is B3 and the last one is B10. In cell B11, type:

=sum(B3:B10)

And press Enter.

5.2.4 Copying Formulas and Functions Using Relative and Absolute Cell References

When copying formulas and functions, there are two types of cell reference or address types to consider: relative and absolute. They behave differently when copied and pasted to other cells. When a cell containing a formula or function is copied and pasted to another cell, the formula or function will adjust “relative” to the original formula. In contrast, absolute references remain constant regardless of where they are pasted.

By default, all cell references containing formulas or functions are relative references. When pasted across multiple cells, they change based on the relative position of rows and columns. For example, if you copy the formula =A1+B1 from row 1 to row 2, the formula will become =A2+B2. These are very convenient whenever you need to repeat the same calculation across multiple rows or columns, saving the time and effort you would need to expend if you had to type in each formula individually.

There are times when you don't want the address of a formula or function contained in a cell to change when copied and pasted to other cells. Absolute references do not change when pasted to other cells. You can use an absolute reference to keep a row constant, a column constant, or both when composing a formula or function. To do this, type the dollar sign (the keystroke is Shift 4 on the Number row):

·         Before the column letter if you want the column to remain constant (example: $A1).

·         before the row number if you want the row to remain constant (example: A$1).

·         Or before both the column letter and row number if you want a cell held constant (example: $A$1).

Now let’s get back to our monthly expenses table for the Smith family and use relative cell references to copy and paste the sum function in cell B11 across row 11 to sum the columns for the other months, and the annual total column.

As we saw in earlier chapters, when copying and pasting files, folders or text, the order of operations is select, copy and paste. When copying formulas and functions in Excel, the order is slightly different – copy, select, and paste. First, you copy the formula or function. Second, you select a range of cells. And third, you paste the formula or function to those cells. So, do the following:

1.    In cell B11 of the Smith table, press Control + C to copy the function created to sum the January column data.

2.    Right arrow to C11, the cell for summing the February column.

3.    Press and hold down the Shift key and Right arrow to N11, the bottom cell of the last column in the table.

4.    Press Control + V to paste the function.

Because you are using relative cell references, Excel adjusts the function’s cell coordinates correctly as you paste across the row. For example, Right arrow a couple of times to cell D11 which is the function for summing the March column. Press F2, the keystroke for editing individual cells, and press the Up or Down arrow key to read the function. It should say:

=sum(D3:D10)

After pressing F2, you can also use the Left and Right arrows to read individual characters within the cell. When finished, press Escape to exit the cell edit mode. More on F2 later in this chapter.

You can follow a similar process to sum a row and then copy and paste functions down the relevant column. Once again, be sure you know the addresses of the first and last cells of the data range you want to sum. This time, we will start by summing the first bill category row (water), inputting the function in cell N3. The first cell for this data range is B3 and the last one is M3. In cell N3, type:

=sum(B3:M3)

And press Enter.

Now do the following to copy the function in cell N3 and paste it down column N to sum each bill category row for the year:

1.    In cell N3, press Control + C to copy the function.

2.    Down arrow to cell N4.

3.    Press and hold down the Shift key and Down arrow to N11, on the last row of the table.

4.    Press Control + V to paste the function.

When you are constructing a simple rectangular table like this one, and want to total all the rows and columns, it is this quick and easy. And you can do this early or later in the process of putting the table together. As data is inputted in the body of the table for each bill, the totals in the bottom row and furthest right column will automatically be recalculated.

Now we will add a new column O to the right to explore how to use absolute cell references. In cell O2, type in “Percent of Total.” Down this column We will calculate the contribution of each expense item to the grand total for the year.

Row 3 is the row for water. Here we will calculate the percent share of water to overall total annual expenses. If we type in a relative cell reference here, the formula would be =N3/N11, dividing annual water expenses by the annual grand total. However, if we copy this formula and paste it down the column using relative cell referencing, this will create a problem because the denominator will automatically adjust as follows: =N4/N12, =N5/N13, and so on. Because there are no data in cells N12 and N13, and you can’t divide by zero, you will hear, “#DIV/0! contains errors.”

To calculate correctly, we need to hold row 11 constant by typing a dollar sign before row 11. Do the following:

1.    In cell o3, type =N3/N$11, and press Enter.

2.    Up arrow back to cell O3, and press Control + C to copy the formula.

3.    Down arrow to cell O4.

4.    Press and hold down the Shift key and Down arrow to cell O11, on the last row of the table.

5.    Press Control + V to paste the formula.

Using absolute cell references, the numerators adjust while the denominators do not, which is what we want (=O4/O$11, =O5/O$11, etc.).

You may not use absolute cell references very often when copying and pasting formulas and functions, but anybody who creates simple spreadsheets will sum columns and rows using relative cell references all the time.

5.2.5 Number Formatting In Cells

There are various ways that simple number formatting can be converted to other formats such as currency, percentages, dates, and time. We will use the Smith budget table as an example and format its numbers as dollars with two decimals. Initially, we will only do this for cell B3 – the top left cell of the data range containing numbers. Steps are:

1.    With focus on cell B3, press the Applications key, Up arrow to Format cells, and press Enter.

2.    This opens a multi-page dialog box where you land on the Numbers tab.

3.    Tab once to the Categories combo box, and Down arrow to Currency.

4.    Tab once to the Decimal place Edit spin box whose default setting is two decimals. If you wanted to change this to zero, you would type this in. While in theory, you can arrow to zero, I have found that this works poorly, so it is better to type it in if you wished to change the number of decimals.

5.    Tab once to the Symbol combo box to select the type of currency. While there are more than 500 symbols to choose from, you land on dollars most of the time. If you land elsewhere in this combo box, press the Home key to get to the top of the list and Down arrow once to Dollars.

6.    Tab to the Negative numbers list box which has four options: preceded by a minus sign; displayed as red; surrounded by parentheses; or both displayed as red and surrounded by parentheses. Sticking with the default (preceded by a minus sign) is best for accessibility.

7.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter to make changes.

Obviously, it would be very laborious to make this change one cell at a time. To do it for multiple cells, here are two alternatives. One way is to select the data range of cells for which you want to change the number formatting. For this spreadsheet, the top left cell of the data range with numbers is cell B3, and the bottom right one is cell N3. Here’s a super quick way to change the number formatting of this data range to dollars with two decimals:

1.    With your cursor in cell B3, press Shift + Control + End. This will select all cells from B3 to N11, as well as all cells within this rectangular block.

2.    Press Control + Shift + 4 on the number row to change the cell format to dollars with two decimals. This is a convenient shortcut key that I use all the time.

Even faster, if all the cells with number values in the sheet are to be converted to dollars with two decimals, and are all contained in a single data region starting in cell A1, you can simply press Control + A to select all cells from A1 to the bottom right cell in that data region. Then press Control + Shift + 4 to convert to dollars with two decimals. This will not affect the formatting of cells in this data range which currently contain words rather than numbers. If you later insert numbers in currently empty cells in this data range, they will appear as dollars with two decimals.

There are twelve number format categories listed in the Category combo box of this dialog. Other than Currency which I already covered, the most commonly used ones and options for changing their formatting are:

·         Numbers: decimal places, adding comma separators between thousands, and negative number formatting.

·         Date: numerous options for displaying month, day, and year.

·         Time: numerous options for displaying hour, minute, second, and A.M. or P.M.

·         Percentage: number of decimal places.

·         Special: Use this for columns containing ZIP codes to make them read properly. If you do not, the ZIP code will read like any other five-digit number (for example, “forty-four thousand three-hundred and thirty two”) rather than as individual numbers. Also, for any ZIP code beginning with zero, the zero will disappear from the cell. For example, my ZIP code is 02072. Without this special formatting, only 2072 would appear in the cell, even though I typed a zero at the beginning.

Below is a summary of shortcut keys that can help you out:

·         Control + 1: Open Cell format dialog.

·         Control + Shift + 4: Format as dollars with two decimals.

·         Control + Shift + 5: Format as percentages with no decimals.

·         Control + semi-colon: Format cells with todays date in MM/DD/YYYY format.

5.2.6 Merging and Centering Cells

We now come to what I consider to be the last step in creating a simple data table in Excel. Centering the name of the table just above its top row is something you may wish to do if you are planning to share the file with sighted users. This involves merging cells, that is, converting two or more cells into a single one. To merge and center the name of this table, do the following:

1.    Go to cell A1 where the name of the table appears: “Monthly Expenses for the Smith Family for the Year,.”

2.    Hold down the Shift key and Right arrow to cell O1, the rightmost column of this table.

3.    Press Alt H M to open the Merge submenu. You land on the Merge and center button. Press Enter on this.
