·         A checkbox for not displaying this screen in the future. Checking this will use the options set in the Reading Preferences when you first installed Acrobat Reader.

·         A Confirm button to initiate processing.

Unless you have a specific reason for wanting to change any of the default settings for processing documents, either press Enter when the dialog opens or Tab to the Confirm button and press Enter. Regarding the checkbox for not displaying this dialog again, I prefer not to check it because I want to know if a PDF is untagged.

When processing begins, your screenreader typically informs you of progress in terms of pages, percentages, or both. When finished, reading automatically starts from the top of the document.

I will go through a set of examples using some of the files contained in the Practice Files folder accompanying this book. To follow along, open them in a separate window and press Alt + Tab to switch between this text and the PDF.

10.4.1 Fully Accessible PDF Files

PDF’s can be designed to be fully accessible in much the same way as web pages on the Internet. You can navigate as follows:

·         By heading, by pressing H.

·         By heading level, by pressing 1, 2, 3, etc. on the number row.

·         By table, by pressing T, and within tables, by pressing Control + Alt and the four arrow keys.

·         To form fields, by pressing E to get to edit fields, X to get to checkboxes, and so on.

You can also open lists of headings, links, and form fields using the same screenreader keystrokes used on the web.

If the PDF is an accessible form (referred to as a “fillable form”), after having partially or completely filled it out, you can save the revised file.

The standard two-page Internal Revenue Service (IRS) tax form is a good example of a fillable PDF form. Open the file entitled “Form 1040.pdf.” All the keystrokes mentioned above will work with this file.

To save the revised file after filling some of the form fields, press Control + S. To save it with a new filename or in a different folder, do the following:

1.    Press the Alt key to open the menu bar. This lands you on the File menu.

2.    Down arrow to Save as and press Enter.

3.    You will first hear a long folder path sequence. Ignore this and press the Spacebar to land in the Filename edit field of the standard Save as dialog (see Chapter 2.10.1.1 for the full discussion of the Save as dialog). If you are revising a previously blank form, you may want to rename the file here to create a new file and preserve the original blank form.

4.    Press Enter if you want to save it in the same folder as the original blank PDF. Otherwise, Shift + Tab back several times to designate a different folder location.

Unfortunately, you will often encounter unfillable forms. These are PDF’s that have not been created with accessible edit fields and checkboxes. They are inaccessible because you will not be able to fill them out independently. Instead, you will have to print them in hard copy and have a sighted person fill them out for you with a pen or pencil.

10.4.2. Changing Reading Order

For PDF documents, “reading order” refers to the sequential presentation of content by screenreaders and other assistive technology. Ideally, the screenreader reads the content as it appears on the screen, and in a way that is comprehensible. However, reading problems occur from time to time in untagged or improperly tagged PDF’s. Text may sound jumbled or garbled. Words sound like they are running together without spaces between them. If you are using Eloquence voices with your screenreader, reading may even switch to a foreign language accent or syntax.

Most of the time, changing to a different reading order will quickly fix the problem. To change reading order, press Control + Shift + 5 (on the number row). You land in the Change reading options dialog, and on the Read the entire document radio button. Tab once to the Reading order combo box. Focus is on the current reading order.

From the top of the list, reading order options are:

·         Infer reading order from document.

·         Left-to-right, top-to-bottom.

·         Raw print stream.

·         Tagged reading order (this fourth option is not always present).

Up or Down arrow to any option other than the problematic one you started with and press Enter. My experience has been that any option other than the initial one resolves the reading order problem. Press Control + S to save the file with its new reading order.

In the Practice Files folder accompanying this book, the file “What Is Mixed Reality.pdf” is an example where reading is garbled. Changing reading order to one of the other choices will make it read clearly.

If using an Eloquence voice with JAWS, the file “Team Viewer.pdf” reads with a German accent, even though it is an English language document. Somehow, a foreign language tag has been inserted into the PDF. Here too, changing the reading order resolves this problem.

If you are using an English Vocalizer Expressive voice with JAWS, you will not experience this language-related reading order problem unless you have also installed a Vocalizer Expressive voice in the “offending” language. The “Team Viewer.PDF” file will only read the document with a German accent if you have installed a Vocalizer Expressive German voice on your computer.

10.4.3 Accessing Scanned Images and Other Problematic PDF’s with JAWS Convenient OCR

If a PDF has been created from a scanned image, it is not directly accessible with a screenreader. JAWS uses Optical Character Recognition (OCR) technology to access these types of PDF’s. The JAWS utility is called Convenient OCR. It only works with Acrobat Reader.

Convenient OCR is very easy to use. Assuming Acrobat Reader is your default, just open the PDF. Because scanned images are all untagged, you will first get the dialog that comes up when you open untagged documents. Just press Enter.

JAWS will now say the following: “Alert: empty document dialog. This document may be a scanned image which makes it difficult or impossible for JAWS or Fusion to read without first scanning the document with OCR. Would you like JAWS to OCR the document now?”

Press the Spacebar on the Yes button, and the scan will begin. If the PDF is only a single page, processing takes just a few seconds. If it is several pages long, you will hear “tick-tock” intervals (the same sound you hear when installing JAWS updates) while being processed.

Once processing is finished, JAWS will read the PDF to you in Say all mode.

You can also Tab once and press Enter to open the document in Word. Here, you can save the text if desired. Note that there may be errors in the output, especially if the quality of the original scanned image was poor. If you import the text into Word, it is likely that you will need to edit and modify formatting to make the document presentable to others.

Convenient OCR may also be successful in accessing other types of PDF’s which would be otherwise unreadable with screenreaders. One such example is the untagged file entitled “Ascentria NSTs Journeys and Choices.pdf,” which can be found in the Practice Files folder. When you first open this file, You encounter a total of 26 completely unreadable graphics. However, if you close the file and reopen it through a context menu, you can read the text. Steps are:

1.    Press Alt + F4 to close the file.

2.    Place focus on the file in the Practice Files folder.

3.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Convenient OCR to Word with JAWS, and press Enter.

4.    Wait for the document to be processed. If it is large, you will hear “tick-tock, tick-tock” while it is being processed.

When processing is finished, the document opens in Word. In all likelihood, formatting will be very messy. Any tables will probably be scrambled. However, text will be readable, and you will be able to get a sense of the document’s content.

NVDA has an OCR feature, but I have never been able to make it work, so will not cover it here. There are several ways to perform OCR with Windows. I have never tried any of these, but if you wish to find out more, activate the following link:

Five OCR Ways to Extract Text from Images on Windows 10

10.5 Adding Placemarkers

Similar to web pages, you can add placemarkers to PDF’s to enable quick navigation to important text in the document. You can do this with JAWS and NVDA, but not with Narrator. As on the web, you first mark a point in the document as a temporary placemarker and then mark it as permanent.

With JAWS, steps for inserting placemarkers in PDF’s are as follows:

1.    For the first placemarker you wish to insert, navigate to the text in the PDF that you want to mark, and press Control + Windows + K to mark it as a temporary placemarker. JAWS will say “temporary placemarker set.”

2.    Press Control + Shift K. This opens the Placemarker list dialog where you land on “temporary document.”

3.    Tab to the Add button and press Enter. You land in an edit box populated with the text of the line that you marked as a temporary placemarker. Edit this to make it shorter, or leave it unchanged, and then press Enter.

4.    To create additional placemarkers during the same session, it is not necessary to first create a temporary placemarker. Navigating elsewhere in the PDF automatically marks the new position as a temporary placemarker.

5.    At this new position, press Control + Shift K to open the Placemarker list dialog, previously created permanent placemarkers are listed here. Up or Down arrow to “temporary document” and repeat step three above to make it permanent.

6.    Press Control + S to save the PDF with these placemarkers. Note that if you use the Save as command to rename the file, the placemarkers will not be carried over to this renamed file.

Similar to placemarkers on web pages, to navigate to the next and previous placemarker, press K and Shift K, respectively. You can also press Control + Shift K to open the list of placemarkers. Then arrow up or down, or first-letter navigate to the one you want, and press Enter to navigate to it in the PDF.

To delete a permanent placemarker:

1.    Press Control + Shift K to open the placemarker list.

2.    Up or Down arrow to the placemarker you want to delete.

3.    Tab to the Remove button and press Enter.

There is also a Remove all button in the placemarker dialog for deleting all permanent placemarkers at once.

To try this out, open the file entitled “college microwave cooking.pdf.” Create three or four placemarkers, navigate through them, and remove one or two. If you now press Control + S to save the updated file, and then reopen it, the previously-created placemarkers should still be there.

To create placemarkers with NVDA, see Chapter 7.11.2.2.

10.6 Saving Word and PowerPoint Files as Accessible PDF’s

Many files you create in Word or PowerPoint can easily be saved as PDF’s. Taking a little time to create accessible source files will yield more accessible PDF’s. To make Word documents and corresponding PDF’s as accessible as possible, add headings with appropriate levels. Any tables created will also be accessible. Graphics should all have accompanying alt text. For PowerPoint presentations, make sure that each slide has a title placeholder and that alt text is provided for graphics. When saved as a PDF, each slide title becomes a heading, making the PDF more easily navigable and its content and structure understandable. Before saving the PDF, run the Accessibility checker for Word or PowerPoint to identify any accessibility issues that may be present (see Chapter 13.3.5). Address these issues before converting the Word document or PowerPoint presentation into a PDF.

Creating fillable PDF’s can only be reliably done using Adobe Acrobat Pro DC. Unfortunately, the Pro version of this software is expensive and the process for creating fillable forms is not accessible. Although it is possible to create forms in Word, it is neither easy to create such forms, nor is it easy to fill them out.[20]

To save a Word file as a PDF:

1.    In Word, press F12 to open the Save as dialog.

2.    You land in an edit field where a filename with the default .DOCX extension is proposed.

3.    Press tab once to navigate to the File type combo box, and press P to select PDF.

Shift + Tab once to return to the filename edit field. A PDF file extension should have replaced the.DOCX file extension. Press Enter to save the file as a PDF.

10.7 Options for Opening PDF’s in Word

There are various ways to open a PDF file in Word, but one important caveat needs to be mentioned. Rarely will the imported PDF come into Word cleanly formatted. Text will be preserved, but you will almost certainly encounter unwanted font and paragraph formatting. Form fields will not be preserved. There may be ways to tidy this up with the pro version of Adobe Acrobat, but I am only discussing the free version here.

As mentioned above in Chapter 10.4.3, if you encounter a scanned image and process it with the JAWS Convenient OCR feature (available beginning with JAWS 2021), press the Tab key for a prompt to open the file in Word, and press Enter. You can now view, edit, and save it in Word.

You can also open PDF files while in Word. To do this:

1.    Press Control + F12 which opens the standard Open file dialog.

2.    Shift + Tab to open either the list view or tree view to find your file and press Enter on it. You will receive the following prompt: “Word will now convert your PDF to an editable Word document. This may take a while. The resulting Word document will be optimized to allow you to edit the text, so it might not look exactly like the original PDF, especially if the original file contained lots of graphics.”

3.    Press Enter to confirm conversion.          

4.    If the file is a fillable form, after confirming that you want to convert it in the previous step, you will also hear: “This PDF contains interactive features that are not supported by PDF Reflow. Word will not display this content.” This text is then followed by identification of the file path. Here again, press Enter to confirm.

5.    The file now opens in Word, and if you press Insert + T, the window title is the PDF file name (example: John’s Resume.PDF Word).

Spot check formatting with Insert + F and you will usually detect some unwanted font and paragraph formatting. The most efficient way I have found to clean this up is to do as follows:

1.    Press Control + A to select the entire document, and then Control + C to copy it to the Clipboard.

2.    Press Control + N to open a new Word document.

3.    Press Alt H V T to paste text only. Text will come in with your Word default font and paragraph formatting.

4.    If you want to save the Word file, press F12 to open the standard Save as dialog, and follow steps outlined in Chapter 2.10.1.1.

Another way to open a PDF file is to use a free application called Doxillion. The easiest way to download it is to place focus on a PDF in one of your file folders and then press the Applications key. Down arrow to Convert file and press Enter. You will be prompted to download and install Doxillion. Follow the steps for download and installation. The next time you press the command a dialog for converting with Doxillion will appear.

Results between these approaches are variable. As mentioned above, they will be complicated by the presence of graphics, tables, and form fields in the original PDF. Use trial and error to arrive at best results.

10.8 Opening and Downloading PDF’s from the Internet

PDF files are often encountered on the web. In the past, you could open PDF files in Acrobat Reader while on the web, provided you made the necessary adjustment in the Acrobat Reader Accessibility Settings. This is no longer possible. These files now automatically open in the web browser’s PDF viewer and are not consistently accessible. Therefore, it is advisable to save the PDF to your computer and then open it in Acrobat Reader. There is of course no airtight guarantee that the PDF will be accessible when opened on your PC. But that will be an accessibility issue with that particular PDF, not with the web viewer.

With each browser, you can download the PDF to your PC by using the standard Save As Dialog. With your focus in the open PDF window, press Control + S to open the Save As dialog. In the edit field where you land, a filename with a PDF ending is proposed. Rename it if you like. Then press Enter to save it to your default Downloads folder. If you wish to save it somewhere other than your default downloads folder, follow standard steps in the Save as dialog to do this (see Chapter 2.10.1.1.

Sometimes when you access an online PDF, you may hear “Open Parent Document button.” If this happens, press the Spacebar to activate it. Then press Control + S to open the Save As Dialog, and repeat the steps above to download it to your computer.

Chapter 11 Cloud Storage with Dropbox and OneDrive

Cloud storage is a way to save files and folders online so they can be accessed on multiple devices, as well as shared between those who have been given permission to access them. It is also a great way to automatically back up your files and folders to a safe online location. This can help you avoid catastrophic losses if your computer melts down and files are only saved locally on your hard drive.

How does cloud storage work? Think of a triangle where your computer is at the bottom left, your smartphone or another computer you use is at the bottom right, and your online account is at the top center. If you save a file or folder in your cloud storage folder on your computer (bottom left of the triangle), that file or folder will immediately be uploaded to your online account (top of the triangle). Then when you turn on your other device, the file or folder will be downloaded there (bottom right).

For most free cloud storage accounts (including those covered here), you can use them on up to three devices. I use them on my home computer, my work computer, and my iPhone. Any changes I make on one device is synchronized with the other two.

Among the most popular cloud storage services are Dropbox, OneDrive, and Google Drive. This chapter will cover Dropbox and OneDrive. Google Drive will be covered in the next chapter, together with other Google applications.

11.1 Dropbox and OneDrive Pricing Plans

There are various personal plans for Dropbox and OneDrive. As of the time this book was written, a free Dropbox account entitled you to two gigabytes (GB) of storage on up to three devices. For two terabytes of storage, Dropbox Plus costs $9.99 per month, and a family plan (up to six members) costs $16.99 per month. For more details on the various options, including additional features, visit:

Buy your Dropbox plan for Personal or Professional Use

When you purchase a computer with the Windows operating system, five gigabytes of free storage with OneDrive are included on up to three devices. You just need to sign up with your Microsoft account to access the OneDrive folder located in your user folder. If you purchase a Microsoft 365 annual license ($69 for an individual account and $99 for up to six people), one terabyte of storage (that is, 1000 gigabytes) of OneDrive storage is included in this package. This is a great deal. For more details, visit OneDrive Cloud Storage Pricing and Plans

11.2 Creating a Dropbox Account and Installing the Desktop Version

You will first need to create a Dropbox account, and if you want to manage files in the familiar Windows environment, install the desktop version on your computer. This involves several steps and can be a bit clunky. To create a free account, start by going to How to download and install Dropbox.

Under the first level two heading, you can follow the instructions for downloading and installing the software, and signing up for a free account. You will also need to be on the lookout for an email asking you to verify your identity.

Once the program is installed on your computer, a Dropbox shortcut appears on your Desktop. The Dropbox folder is located in your user folder.

With the paid accounts for both programs, you can select folders to download to your computer, and others to be stored only in the cloud. If you anticipate using a significant amount of this storage space, considering which folders you want to take up space on your computer may be an important issue.

For individuals, there are four categories of sharing: between your devices, with other people without editing rights, with other people with editing rights (also known as sharing collaboratively), and between apps on your smartphone. Each will be discussed below.

11.3 Sharing Between Your Devices

If you work on more than one device, you will derive benefits from cloud sharing because you can share files and folders between them. I work on a personal computer, a computer at work, and an iPhone. With these cloud storage applications installed on my three devices, I can effortlessly share files and folders between them. If I add, delete or revise a file on one device, these changes will be synchronized across my other devices. Before cloud sharing became commonplace, I spent a lot of time carting around files on a thumb drive so I could copy and paste them between my work and personal computers. Nowadays, any changes I make on one computer are reflected on the other computer, and vice versa. All without the hassle of constantly copying and pasting between computers and a thumb drive.

If you want to use a cloud sharing application on your work computer, check first with your organization’s information technology manager about whether this is allowed. For security and privacy purposes, such sharing is not allowed in many state and local government agencies, health care and finance companies, and educational institutions.

When you purchase a Windows PC, a OneDrive folder is already placed in your user folder. However, you will need to sign in with your Microsoft email and password to allow syncing between your devices. You should add a desktop shortcut to the OneDrive folder. It is not included as part of the initial setup. Use the procedures in Chapter 2.8.1 to do this. You can now add folders and files to these folders and manage them using the same procedures and shortcut keys that you use in any other folder on your PC. The only difference is that these folders and files will automatically be backed up to the Cloud, and be available on any of the other devices where you have Dropbox and OneDrive installed, including your smartphone.

The three other forms of sharing are discussed below. These are: sharing with other people without editing rights; sharing with other people collaboratively; and sharing with other apps on your smartphone.

11.4 Sharing Without Editing Rights

With both Dropbox and OneDrive, it is quick and easy to share files and folders with other people without granting editing rights. Recipients of your shared files and folders can download these to their computers, but whatever they do with them will not modify your own files in any way. Recipients are not required to have their own Dropbox or OneDrive accounts when you share without granting editing rights.

11.4.1 Dropbox

Steps for sharing without granting editing rights are:

1.    In your Dropbox folder, place focus on the file or folder you wish to share. Do not open it.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Copy Dropbox link, and press Enter. This generates a hyperlink and places it on the Clipboard.

3.    In the body of an email message, paste the link from the Clipboard by pressing Control + V. A URL appears.

4.    Send the email message to those recipients with whom you wish to share the file or folder.

When recipients press Enter or click the mouse on the URL in the email, they will be redirected to a web page. The title of this page will say the name of the file or folder, and the name of your default web browser. Exact steps for downloading the file or folder change periodically when Dropbox revises its website. As of the writing of this book, after landing on the web page, press B several times to navigate to the Download button and press Enter. The file or folder will now be downloaded to your PC’s Downloads folder.

If you have shared a folder, the name of the folder will have a zip extension. All folders that you download from the Internet have this extension. This is called a Zip file. If recipients press Enter on the zip file, they will now have access to all the folders and files contained in the shared folder. They can open them here. They can also copy or move them elsewhere on their PC. But as mentioned above, none of the recipients’ actions will affect the folders and files on the computer of the person who originally shared.'

Here's a great little trick to simplify sharing Dropbox files and folders without editing rights. It’s how I do it all the time. You can edit the hyperlink so that the shared file or folder downloads directly to the recipient’s Downloads folder. This saves them time. It also saves you the effort of having to explain how to perform the download from the Internet if they don’t know how to do it already. Steps are:

1.    Repeat steps one through three above for copying and pasting the hyperlink.

2.    On the line containing the URL, press End to place focus just after it.

3.    Left arrow back into the URL and stop on the zero, the last character of the URL.

4.    Type the number 1 to insert  that character just before the zero.

5.    Press the Delete key once to remove the zero.

6.    Down arrow out of the URL.

7.    Send the email message.

When email recipients press Enter on the URL, the file or folder should download directly to their Downloads folder. There is no equivalent technique for simplifying the sharing process with OneDrive or Google Drive.

 11.4.2 OneDrive

To share without editing rights in OneDrive:

1.    In your OneDrive folder, place focus on the file or folder to be shared.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Share, and press Enter.

3.    Tab several times to the Copy link button and press Enter. This generates a hyperlink and places it on the Clipboard.

4.    In the body of an email message, paste the link from the Clipboard by pressing Control + V. A URL appears.

5.    Send the email message to those recipients with whom you wish to share the file or folder.

When recipients press Enter on the URL in the email, they will be redirected to a web page. The title of this page will say the name of the file or folder, and the name of your default web browser. As with Dropbox, exact steps for downloading the file or folder change periodically. As of the writing of this book, steps were:

1.    After landing on the web page, Down arrow several times to the folder name.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Download, and press Enter.

As with Dropbox, the file or folder will now download to your PC’s Downloads folder. Folders will have a zip extension, and can be accessed in the same way as with Dropbox.

Unlike with Dropbox, there is no way to simplify the downloading process by editing the URL. Consequently, whenever I share files and folders without granting editing rights, I always do it in Dropbox.

11.5 Sharing Collaboratively

Use this sharing method for team projects where you need to work collaboratively, jointly editing files and storing folders in a place where all team members can access and revise them. All those granted permission to edit files and folders must have Dropbox or OneDrive accounts. While these processes are accessible, they can be a bit finicky and may require a bit of Tabbing and Shift + Tabbing around to gain focus on the field where you insert recipient email addresses. Also remember that recipients must already have Dropbox or OneDrive accounts to become collaborators. Confirm this with them before sending a request to collaborate.

11.5.1 Dropbox

To share folders collaboratively with others:

1.    In your Dropbox folder, place focus on the folder you wish to share.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Share, and press Enter.

3.    You land in the Contact name edit field. However, you may not hear this. Tab and Shift + Tab back to it to verify. Type in the email addresses of those you want to share with. If you are going to share with several people, it may be better to type the email addresses in Word first, and then copy and paste them into this edit field because text editing works poorly here. Be sure to type a semi-colon between email addresses if you intend to share with multiple recipients.

4.    Tab to the Can edit combo box. “Can edit” is the default. This means that those you share with can edit files and folders within the shared folder, including adding and deleting files and subfolders, revising and renaming them, and commenting.

5.    Otherwise, Down arrow to the second choice in the combo box, which is “can view, download, and comment.” If you Up or Down arrow in this combo box, press the Spacebar to make the selection.

6.    Tab to the Add a message edit field, where you can insert an optional message that will appear in the body of the email sent to recipients.

7.    Tab to the Share button and press Enter. You may or may not hear a confirmation that the file or folder has been shared.

If you are a recipient of a request to share with editing rights, you will receive an email message with a link. Procedures for adding the folder to your Dropbox and becoming a collaborator are subject to change. Don’t be surprised if they are different when you try. Steps as of early 2023 were:

1.    Press Enter on the link which brings you to a web page with the title “Claim Invitation - Dropbox.”

2.    Down arrow or press B several times to the Add to Dropbox button and press Enter. You may or may not hear a confirmation that the folder has been added to your Dropbox.

3.    Open the Dropbox folder on your PC where it should now appear.

11.5.2 OneDrive

To share folders collaboratively with others:

1.    In your OneDrive folder, place focus on the file or folder you wish to share.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Share, and press Enter.

3.    You land in the Enter the name or email address for people to share with edit field. Here too, as in Dropbox, you may not initially hear this. Tab and Shift + Tab back to hear it. Type in the email addresses of those you want to share with. Be sure to place a semi-colon between email addresses if you intend to share with multiple recipients.

4.    Tab to the Can edit combo box and Down arrow to your choice. The two options are: can edit, delete, comment, and add the folder; or can view, download, and comment.

5.    Tab to the Add a message edit field, where you can insert an optional message that will appear in the body of the email sent to recipients.

6.    Tab to the Send button and press Enter.

If you receive this type of sharing request, the same caveats mentioned above for Dropbox about the frequency of changes apply. When last checked in late 2022, the process was not accessible with JAWS, only with Narrator and NVDA. Also, because the cursor mode did not dependably remain in Browse or Scan mode, I had to repeatedly press Insert and the Spacebar to return to these modes, as well as press F5 numerous times to refresh the screen.[21] Steps are:

1.    Press Enter on the link in the message. This will bring you to a web page where the list of files in the folder appears.

2.    Down arrow quite a few times to the fifth item in the command bar submenu which is labeled Add shortcut to my files, and press Enter.

3.    Navigate to the OneDrive folder on your PC to verify that the folder now appears there.

11.6 Checking Storage Space

It is important to know how much storage space you are using, especially for free accounts with limited storage capacity. If you have installed the Dropbox and OneDrive apps on your iPhone and signed into them, this is the easiest place to do it. Also, steps are less subject to change than on your PC.

For the Dropbox iPhone app, open the Settings tab which appears at the bottom right of your screen. The amount of storage you are currently using and your total storage capacity is displayed on this screen.

For the OneDrive iPhone app, open the Home tab which appears at the bottom left of your screen. Then at the top left of your screen, open the menu button with your account name on it. The amount of storage you are currently using and your total storage capacity is displayed at the bottom of the screen.

11.7 Sharing with Other Apps On Your Smartphone

When you install the Dropbox and OneDrive apps on your smartphone, these will synchronize with your Dropbox and OneDrive folders on the PC. This is also the case for Google Drive. Not only can you access these files and folders there, but you can export them to, or import them from, other apps on your smartphone.

It is beyond the scope of this book to provide detailed instructions on how to use the various iPhone apps, as well as for popular apps used in conjunction with them. However, below is a short discussion of some of my favorite iPhone apps with links to iPhone App Store pages where you can find out more about them.

11.7.1 RecUp (Dropbox Only)

Developed by Irradiated Software, this app costs only $1.99. It’s easily the best two bucks I’ve ever spent! RecUp is an easy-to-use voice recorder that automatically uploads MP3-formatted audio recordings to a folder in Dropbox (but only Dropbox). You can listen to the recordings on your phone or on your computer. You can efficiently manage uploaded files on your computer, deleting, renaming, and moving them elsewhere. The quality of the audio is also quite good. Find out more at:

‎RecUp - Record to the Cloud in the App Store

11.3.2 Drafts

Developed by Agile Tortoise, this app is free, but also has an in-app purchase option. With the paid version, you can do extremely elaborate things to organize and manage notes. However, I use the free version to simply create notes and export them to one of my cloud sharing apps as text files. I absolutely hate editing text on my iPhone, so the big advantage with Drafts is that I can dictate a note and quickly get it into Dropbox, OneDrive, or Google Drive, and deal with the text on my PC where I am far more efficient.

While this can be done with other apps, including the native Notes app on the iPhone, you can accomplish this with far fewer finger flicks with the Drafts app. You can also share text in emails, text messages and copy the text and paste it in an edit field of some other iPhone app. You can also customize the list of sharing options, deleting those you are not interested in using, as well as moving the ones you want to use higher up the list to save on finger flicking.

To learn more, go to Drafts in the App Store.

11.7.3 Voice Dream Reader

Developed by Voice Dream LLC, this used to be a one-time only purchase. However, in early 2024, ownership changed and the new owners introduced a subscription model. Those who previously purchased the app can continue to use it for free. However, new users as well as previous purchasers who want to use new features, must pay a annual subscription of $79.99.

With this app, you can import files in various text and audio formats (Word, PDF, ePub, MP3, WAV, and several others). You can also download books from Bookshare. While it is possible to read or listen to files on your iPhone directly in Dropbox, OneDrive, or Google Drive, navigation is more flexible with this app. In ePub format, it is very easy to navigate by heading. I listen to this book using ePub files that I have imported from Dropbox. You can also adjust the speed of audio files in Voice Dream. This is not possible in Dropbox, OneDrive, or Google Drive. The developer is very attuned to accessibility concerns. Find out more at:

‎Voice Dream Reader in the App Store

11.7.4 Cloud Music App Pro

Developed by Mymacapps.com, this app costs $3.99. It is an easy-to-use alternative to iTunes and the iPhone’s native Music app for syncing music stored in cloud sharing apps. Syncing steps are straightforward. Playlists are automatically created by artist and album. It is completely Voiceover accessible, and on those rare occasions when I have contacted the developers about problems, they were very responsive.

11.8 Comparing the Cloud Sharing Apps

I have covered Dropbox and OneDrive in this chapter, and will cover Google Drive, which is Google’s cloud sharing app, in the next chapter. Should you try to figure out which is the best for you, and just use that one? Or use two of them? Or all three?

I will first summarize the main strengths and weaknesses of each one.

For free accounts, Google Drive provides a maximum of 15 GB of storage. OneDrive allows 5 GB, and Dropbox just 2 GB. So, when it comes to free storage, Google Drive is the clear winner.

Regarding paid accounts (and I can only speak about prices in the United States), with a Microsoft 365 account, you are entitled to one TB of storage as part of the overall $70 annual license package. Google Drive has several pricing options, starting at $20 annually for 100 MB, and costing more for larger storage capacities. For $9.99 per month, Dropbox allows up to 2 TB of storage. If you already have Microsoft 365, OneDrive is the best deal. For me personally, that terabyte of storage is an important reason why I prefer Microsoft 365 over other ways of purchasing the Office Suite. Google’s flexible pricing structure is a big advantage if you don’t have Microsoft 365 and need more than a bare minim amount of storage capacity.

Beyond pricing, also consider which cloud sharing apps most of your friends and colleagues use. Remember that it takes two to tango. If you are going to collaborate with others, you will need to work in an environment that is familiar to them. To some extent, this is generational. For personal use for those older than 30 or 40, Dropbox often wins out on this score because it has been around longer than the others. That said, both OneDrive and Google Drive have been adopted by many organizations, not just for file storage, but also as part of a larger package which includes their array of software products. Microsoft and Google compete to promote SharePoint and Google Workspace, their respective enterprise-level content management systems. For personal use, my impression is that Google Drive is more commonly used among those under 30.

If you often share files and folders without editing rights, Dropbox is the best for sharing in this way if you use the “Equals one” trick discussed in Chapter 11.1.2.1 above. This eliminates the need for recipients to visit a website where the download process is subject to change, and some recipients may have difficulty figuring out how to do it. Using the Dropbox Equals one Technique, upon activation of the link, files and folders are immediately sent to the recipient’s Downloads folder, thus cutting out the step of going to a web page.

Sometimes with Dropbox, this “equals one” trick does not work, but you are instead redirected to a web page where pressing B a few times to get to the Download button and Enter works. The process is also pretty easy with Google Drive. Unfortunately, it is problematic with OneDrive. If I want to share in this way, I will copy and paste from OneDrive to Dropbox and share from there.

Regarding sharing collaboratively, steps for inviting others to share can be a bit finicky, but generally are OK. Yet when it comes to agreeing to become a collaborator, this process is absolutely horrendous with OneDrive, and often simply cannot be accomplished. With GDFD, steps for adding a shortcut to your My Drive folder are a bit complicated, but work consistently. That said, I have occasionally encountered a glitch when on the receiving end of a sharing invitation. After creating a shortcut to the My Drive folder. It only shows up in GDFD after a delay of several hours. With all cloud sharing apps, the process of accepting an invitation is subject to change when updates occur.

If you regularly use a smartphone app that works better with one cloud sharing app than with the others, or works exclusively with one cloud sharing app, this might be a reason to keep using that particular cloud sharing app. As mentioned above, one of my all-time favorite iPhone apps is RecUp for making audio recordings. It only works with Dropbox. This, plus the nifty “equals one” download trick, are two important reasons why I really like Dropbox.

For what it’s worth, let me describe my own cloud sharing practices.

I do all my day-to-day work in Dropbox. Consequently, I have changed my Word and Excel settings so that all files I create in those applications are saved to Dropbox. Many of my friends and work colleagues also use Dropbox, although they are also using OneDrive with greater frequency. I realize now that I could just as easily do my daily work in OneDrive or GDFD, but as a creature of habit, I am still doing it in Dropbox.

Although my storage capacity is limited in my free Dropbox account, I have a Microsoft 365 account with plenty of storage space there. I am using about 150 GB of OneDrive storage for documents, music, BARD books, and other audio. I also move folders initially created in Dropbox to OneDrive that I am no longer actively working with, but that I still want to retain.

However, whenever I want to share some of those OneDrive files or folders stored there without granting editing rights, I temporarily copy them to Dropbox and share from there, using the “equals one” Dropbox trick.

Regarding sharing collaboratively, something that I do not do very often, I have tended to use Dropbox. But with the advent of GDFD, I anticipate using this more frequently in the future, at least with those collaborators who have Gmail accounts. Because of the serious problem mentioned above, I do not share collaboratively with OneDrive unless I cannot avoid it.

For many years, I have used the RecUp app to make audio recordings which I then manage from Dropbox. I have also created a folder in Dropbox where I copy and paste audio files that I then export to the Voicedream Reader app on my iPhone. After exporting the files, I delete them from Dropbox to free up space.

With increasing frequency, work colleagues share folders with me in Google Drive or individual Googledocs or Googlesheets. I also create registration forms and other types of forms in Googleforms, one of a small number of apps that are accessible for creating forms. I access both my work and personal My Drive folders with GDFD. If colleagues want me to edit or update a Googledoc or Googlesheet, I usually take the lite approach, revising in Word or Excel, and converting back to the Google format.

That’s how things have evolved for me. Everybody’s situation is different, Figure out what works best for you based on your own needs. One thing is clear: cloud sharing can be a valuable tool in your digital toolbox, allowing you to efficiently back up, store, and share your files and folders in multiple ways. For me and many others, it has become an absolutely essential file management tool.

Chapter 12 Google Workspace Applications

Formerly referred to as the Google Suite, the Google Workspace is the array of free online software products available from that company. Among the most commonly used Google apps are:

·         Google Drive: where files and folders are stored and managed. Similar to Dropbox and OneDrive, you can share files and folders with other people with and without editing rights from here.

·         Google Docs: For document preparation, the Google equivalent of Word.

·         Google Sheets: For spreadsheet preparation, the Google equivalent of Excel.

·         Google Slides: For preparing presentations, the Google equivalent of PowerPoint.

A few more products include Google Mail (or Gmail) for emailing; Google Calendar for creating appointments and meetings; and Google Forms for creating questionnaires, surveys and other types of forms. All of the above-mentioned applications will be covered in this chapter.

When you work with Google apps, you are operating in an online environment. As we will see below, Google Drive for Desktop is a partial exception. Why do I say “partial?” The answer is that when you download and sign into this app in your desktop environment, as is the case with other cloud sharing apps like Dropbox and OneDrive (discussed in the previous chapter), folders and files on your PC are synchronized with your Google Drive account which is stored online.

12.1 Some Initial Considerations

Before discussing each of the Google applications, it is useful to lay out some initial information about where the Google apps exhibit consistent and less consistent behavior. While this information will be repeated for each app, first talking about it in a central location helps to understand patterns where they exist. Also available for some of the apps are quick and convenient ways to get listings of native Google keyboard shortcuts.

1.1.1 Opening Apps, New Files, and Menus

There are consistent patterns for opening each of the apps online, as well as opening new files. To open an app in your browser’s address bar, simply type in the shortened name of the app, followed by google.com. Here they are for each of the apps covered in this chapter:

·         Drive: drive.google.com.

·         Docs.google.com.

·         Sheets.google.com.

·         Slides.google.com

·         Mail.google.com (gmail.com also works).

·         Calendar.google.com.

·         Forms.google.com.

For apps not covered here, the same pattern exists. For example, type meet.google.com to open Google Meet, and groups.google.com to open Google Groups.

To open a brand new file, you don’t have to open the app first. In fact, opening the app first and attempting to create a new file is surprisingly complicated. There are easier ways to do this. As long as you have signed into your account at some point in the past, in your browser’s address bar, type in the shortened name of the app, followed by dot new. For example, docs.new, sheets.new, slides.new, and forms.new. While there are other ways to open new files in these apps, this is the quickest way.

The pattern for opening and navigating menus is the same for Docs, Sheets, and Slides. After turning on required accessibility settings (see below), press Alt and single letters together to get on the menu bar for an app. Alt + F works for all of these to land on the File menu on the Menu bar. Right and Left arrow to other menus (Edit, Format, etc.). Down and Up arrow to access commands. The File menu is quite important and contains similar commands for these three apps. Among the most useful are: share, new, open, make a copy, email, Add shortcut to Drive, move, send to trash, download, rename, and print.

These three apps also have a Main toolbar which centralizes a number of important formatting and editing commands.

For the remaining apps covered in this chapter, ways to access menus and commands vary.

1.1.2 Accessibility Settings Across Apps

The most important area where things are less consistent relates to accessibility settings. With each of the Workspace apps, you will need to make at least one adjustment to make the app work properly with your screenreader program, thus enabling you to access Google’s native keystrokes. In such situations, the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or the NVDA Focus mode must be toggled off. Adjustments vary from one app to the next. While I will repeat them in my discussion for each app below, as well as how to make these changes, I will also list them here:

·         Drive: Turn off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor and NVDA Browse mode by pressing Insert + Z and Insert + Spacebar, respectively.

·         Docs: Enable both screenreader and Braille support. The shortcut keys for these are Control + Alt + Z and Control + Alt + H, respectively.

·         Sheets: Enable both screenreader and Braille support with the same keystrokes as for Docs.

·         Slides: Enable both screenreader and Braille support for most actions with the same keystrokes as for Docs. But disable Braille support when reading presentations.

·         For editing Docs, Sheets, and Slides files, you must toggle off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode. Chances are good that you will wind up toggling these on and off quite a bit.

·         Gmail: Enable keyboard shortcuts, and turn off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode most of the time because native Google keystrokes are used a lot.

·         Forms: No additional changes. Keep the JAWS Virtual PC cursor and NVDA Browse mode enabled for most actions.

1.1.3 Keyboard Shortcut Help

For the apps discussed in this chapter, listings of keyboard shortcuts are readily available for all except Forms.

For Drive, Docs, Sheets, Slides, and Calendar:

1.    With the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode toggled off, Press Control + Slash, after which you will hear “Keyboard Shortcuts.”

2.    Toggle the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode back on.

3.    Keyboard shortcuts are presented in tables under level three headings for various categories. Use standard table navigation keystrokes to read them.

4.    When finished, press Escape to return to the file you are working on.

To access the Gmail Keyboard shortcut listings, press the question mark instead of Control + /.

12.2 Google Drive, Including Drive for Desktop

12.2.1 Google Accounts

With Google Drive, you get 15 GB of space for free. There are several personal account pricing tiers for additional storage with what the company calls Google One. As of January 2025, two plans and their subscription prices in the United States were:

Basic: 100GB, $2 a month or $20 annually

Premium: 2TB, $10 a month or $100 annually

Discount offers may be available for the first three months of the above plans. Additional plans are available to access Gemini, Google’s AI tool. Prices and plan features are subject to change.

You are required to have a Gmail account to use the Google Workspace.

If you do not already have a Gmail account, you will need to get one to be able to operate in the Google Workspace environment effectively. Without one, you will not be able to use Google Drive for Desktop. In addition, Gmail account holders will only be able to share files with you in read-only mode. You will not be able to edit them. If your primary account is with another email service (Microsoft, Comcast, Verizon, etc.) and you want to keep it that way, use your new Gmail account just for Google applications.

12.2.2 Google Drive for Desktop

While it is possible to manage files and folders solely in Google Drive online, I much prefer doing most of this work using Google Drive for Desktop (GDFD). GDFD is a free app that you can download to your computer. It creates an additional drive on your PC that behaves pretty much the same as any other folder on your PC. It allows you to access and manage your Google Drive files and folders in the familiar Windows environment, rather than in the more challenging online environment. When it comes to sharing, you will still need to understand a few things about the online environment, but using GDFD greatly flattens the file management learning curve.

To download and install GDFD:

1.    Go to: Use Google Drive for desktop at Home, Work, or School.

2.    Press B to go to the Download & install Google Drive for Desktop button, press the Spacebar to expand, Down arrow to Google Drive for Desktop and press Enter to download the installation file.

3.    In your Downloads folder, activate the file entitled “Google Drive setup.exe,” and follow the instructions. At some point in the process, you will need to enter your Gmail account address and password.

4.    Once installed, a new drive and folder with your Gmail address as its name appears. It contains a subfolder entitled “My Drive.”[22] This is the same My Drive folder accessed online (more on this later). To navigate to the My Drive folder and create a desktop shortcut for it:

1.    For Windows 10 users, press the Windows key and type “This PC” in the search box. Usually, typing just the first one or two letters suffices. For Windows 11, see the options outlined in Chapter 2.5.9 for accessing This PC. Press Enter.

2.    Depending on how your folder view is set up here, either Right arrow or Down arrow to Devices and drives. If it says “collapsed” here, press the Spacebar to expand it.

3.    Down arrow or Right arrow to the name of your Gmail account, and press Enter.

4.    Press the Spacebar to select the My Drive folder.

5.    Press the Applications key. Down arrow a number of times to the Send To submenu and press Enter or the Right arrow to open it.

6.    Down arrow twice to Desktop create shortcut, and press Enter.

7.    To verify that the shortcut is now on the Desktop, press Windows + D or Windows + M to go to the Desktop and first-letter navigate to the new shortcut whose name is “My Drive – shortcut.”

8.    Press F2 to rename the shortcut if you wish. I have two My Drive desktop shortcuts: one for my work account, and another for my personal account, and have renamed them to differentiate them.

File management procedures are nearly identical to those for other folders on your computer such as your Documents folder. The only caveat is that if you move files or folders around that are shared collaboratively with other people, this can break the sharing link. Other than that, procedures for creating folders, selecting, copying, cutting, pasting, renaming and deleting are the same as those listed in Chapter 2.6.2 and 2.6.3 on file management basics.

GDFD is a file repository like Dropbox or OneDrive: you can save any Windows-compatible file type here. There is only one difference: you can store and share Google Workspace file types here, while you cannot store these file types in Dropbox or OneDrive.

Basic file management commands are exactly the same in the My Drive folder as in other PC desktop folders like the Documents folder. Differences relate to collaborating with other people.

12.2.3 Overview of the Google Drive Online Environment

It is useful to first give an overview of the Google Drive online environment and folder structure. This makes it easier to understand how file sharing and collaboration work.

To open Google Drive online, type drive.google.com in the Address bar of your browser,  and then press Enter. You may need to log into your Google account. Once you are in, the Window title should be My Drive, your name, and the name of your browser.

Google apps, including Drive online, have an array of what are referred to as “native keyboard commands,” quick keys developed by Google for navigating and executing commands in the Google Workspace environment. These will not work if your screenreader is in its default cursor mode when you open a web page: Virtual PC cursor mode with JAWS, Browse mode with NVDA, and Scan mode with Narrator. If you are not sure about what I am talking about here, see Chapter 7.1.5 for more on the various screenreader cursor modes used on the web.

When you open a Google app such as Drive or Googledocs on the web, to use Google’s native online keyboard commands for editing, navigating and accessing commands, it is necessary to toggle off your screenreader default cursor mode that operates when you open a web page. To do this:

·         With JAWS, press Insert + Z. JAWS will say, “Use Virtual PC cursor off.”

·         With NVDA, press Insert + Spacebar to turn off Browse mode. NVDA will make a sound. If you prefer that NVDA says words instead, see Chapter 8.2.3 on how to switch off sounds. If you change this setting, NVDA will now say, “Focus mode.”

·         With Narrator, press Insert + Spacebar to turn off Scan mode. Narrator will say, “Scan off.”

When you toggle off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor mode, if you Alt + Tab away from the Googledoc or sheet, and return to it, the Virtual PC cursor may be still toggled off. Just press Insert + Z again to be sure. With NVDA and Narrator, Browse mode and Scan mode remain switched off for these apps. When in doubt, toggle these modes to be sure. Memorize these keystrokes: you will use them constantly in the Google online environment. Also when it appears that a keystroke you just attempted to use has not responded properly, press F5 to refresh the screen and try again.

After toggling the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode off, press Alt + g and then F, Google’s native keystroke combination to open the Folder view. Let me repeat this clearly: you need to press Alt and G together, and then F to make this keystroke combination work.

This brings you to the highest level of the Drive online folder structure. You should hear your screenreader say, “Folder in view,” and some number of folders between nine and twelve.

From the top of the list, Down arrow to My Drive (closed). This is the same folder that you can access on your PC with GDFD. If you were to Right arrow and navigate around using standard tree view keystrokes, you would see all the same folders.

Down arrow through a list of additional folders, which include: Computers, Shared with me (sometimes alternately labeled Items Shared with Me), Recent, Starred, Trash, and Storage. If you have an enterprise account, a Shared drive folder also appears. This Shared folder is also present for personal accounts if an enterprise account owner has shared a folder with the personal account owner.

The My Drive folder is by far the most important folder. All your subfolders and files are located here. If you use GDFD, you don’t need to learn a whole set of native Google keystrokes and new procedures, some of which are sometimes frustrating to use. This is because the My Drive folder is synced with GDFD, meaning that any changes you make in the GDFD My Drive folder will appear in the My Drive online folder, and vice versa.

The Shared with me (or Items Shared with Me) folder is where you access a file or folder that you have been invited to collaborate on. While you can work on it from here, I find it easier to create a shortcut for it that will appear in the My Drive folder. This will enable you to access it in GDFD, rather than having to find it online every time you want to open it. And once you have created a shortcut to My Drive, you will easily be able to manage it from within GDFD.

If you are like me and prefer doing the bulk of your Google Drive file management using the desktop version, thus minimizing your exposure to Drive online, this is the only folder you really have to know anything about in the online environment. This is because you must come here to access files and folders that others have invited you to collaborate on. There is no way to do this without going online.

Google Drive has many native keystrokes for navigation and file management. These are further discussed in Chapter 12.2.10 below. But next up is file sharing and collaboration.

12.2.4 Sharing Collaboratively

I will first cover how to become a collaborator when somebody else has invited you to work on a file or folder. I will then discuss how you invite others to collaborate.

12.2.4.1 Becoming a Collaborator on Somebody Else’s File or Folder

So, now your GDFD is set up, you know a bit about Drive online, and you have just received an email inviting you to collaborate on a shared Google file or folder. The subject field of the email will indicate the name of the sender, followed by “via Google Drive Folder shared with you,” and the folder name. When you open the email, you will be told that somebody has invited you to either contribute to, view or comment on a folder being shared with you. These refer to different levels of collaboration granted to you by the owner of the file or folder:

·         Contribute: The owner has granted you full editing rights, including authorization to add subfolders, edit documents, and delete and rename them.

·         View: You can open and view the files, but not revise them in anyway.

·         Comment: You can add comments (this is rarely done).

·         Once granted access, you could do all your work in Drive online, but I much prefer doing all this in GDFD. This involves adding a shortcut to your My Drive folder. I will show you two ways to do this: one starting from within the email you received, and another by going directly to Drive online, and bypassing the email.

·         To become a collaborator via the email you have received, steps are:

1.    Open the email you received from the owner to see the folder or filename.

2.    You will see two links, one with a more or less gibberish name and the other with the actual file or folder name. Press Enter on either of these to open Google Drive online. Alternatively, you could just navigate to the Shared with Me folder and find it there without opening the email. The usefulness of The email is that it notifies you that somebody has invited you to collaborate.

3.    If not yet logged into your Google account, log in here with your Gmail address and password.

4.    Press Insert + F7 to open the JAWS Links list or NVDA Elements list, and activate the Shared with me link. This link might also be called Items Shared with me.

5.    Toggle off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode.

6.    Up or Down arrow to the file or folder you have been invited to collaborate on. These are usually listed chronologically, so it should be near the top.

7.    Press Control + Alt + R to open the Add shortcut to Drive dialog, where you first land on the Suggested Tab.

8.    Right arrow to the All locations Tab and press Enter to select it.

9.    Tab once to My Drive and press Enter.

10. Tab to the Add Button and press Enter. Your screenreader should say, “Adding shortcut, shortcut added to My Drive.”

11. Open GDFD and verify that the shortcut is now in your My Drive folder.

If it does not appear, wait a few hours and go back in. It should be there then. I am not sure why this is inconsistent and when I asked Google Accessibility about this, they had no idea.

If it is there, you        can now access and manage this file or folder on your PC with GDFD, using the Windows keystrokes you already know from Chapter 2 for creating new folders, and selecting, copying, cutting, pasting, renaming, and deleting files and folders. Because this has been added as a shortcut, it does not take up any of your Google Drive storage space.

Here is a second way to create a shortcut to your My Drive folder that does not involve going in via the email: [23]

1.    Open your browser, type drive.google.com on the Address bar, and press Enter.

2.    You are now on the Google Drive page for your account. Press Insert + Z to turn off the Virtual PC cursor for JAWS, or press Insert + Spacebar to turn off NVDA Browse mode or Narrator Scan mode.

3.    Press Alt + g and then F to go to the Folder view.

4.    Down arrow to Shared with Me or Items Shared with Me and press Enter.

5.    Down arrow or first-letter navigate to the file or folder that is being shared with you to select it. Files and folders are sorted chronologically in this folder, with the most recent at the top of the list.

6.    Press Control + Alt + R to open the Add shortcut to Drive dialog, where you first land on the Suggested Tab.

7.    Right arrow to the All locations Tab and press Enter to select it.

8.    Tab once to My Drive and press Enter.

9.    Tab to the Add Button and press Enter. Your screenreader should say, “Adding shortcut, shortcut added to My Drive.”

10. Open GDFD and verify that the shortcut is now in your My Drive folder.

If you have an enterprise account at work, a colleague may share a folder with you via the Shared Drive folder rather than the Shared With Me folder. The Shared Drive option does not exist for personal accounts. You will know that a colleague is sharing with you in this way because the subject field of the email you receive will say that you have been added to the Shared Drive with the folder name indicated.

To access this shared folder, you don’t have to go online to find it. As mentioned above, if using an enterprise Gmail account, your GDFD account folder contains an additional subfolder entitled Shared Drive. Open this folder and you will find the folder shared by your colleague there. You are not required to go through the steps above on accessing the Shared with Me folder.

12.2.4.2 Inviting Others to Collaborate

Steps for inviting others to collaborate when you are the file or folder owner are:

1.    Place focus on the folder to be shared in the GDFD My Drive folder.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Share with Google Drive, and press Enter.

3.    This opens an HTML page where you might or might not immediately land in the Add people and groups edit combo box. If you hear the standard popping noise you hear on the web when you land in an edit field, start typing in the email address of the intended recipient or recipient.

4.    If you do not hear it, press E for edit until you get to this edit combo box, press Enter to get into it, and type in the recipient addresses.

5.    Tab to the Change permissions menu. The default setting is edit (full editing rights). Press the Spacebar to expand this list if you instead want to restrict to either viewing or commenting, Down arrow to your choice, and press Enter. If you do not press Enter, changing away from full editing rights will not stick.

6.    Tab to the Notify people checkbox (which is check by default), so recipients get an email alerting them of the request to share. Keep this checked.

7.    Tab to the Message edit box, and add an optional message if desired.

Tab to the Send button and press Enter to send the email to your collaborators.

12.2.5 Sharing Without Editing Rights

You can also share links for files and folders so that people can download these to their Downloads folder. This is called sharing without editing rights or sharing non-collaboratively. This means that any changes they make after receiving the files has no effect on your own files.

If the owner has sent you an invitation to access a folder without granting editing rights, do the following to download it to your computer:

1.    Activate the link in the email that you received from the folder owner. This will bring you to a web page whose title includes the folder name.

2.    Press B until you get to the folder’s name collapsed menu button, and press the Spacebar to expand it.

3.    Down arrow to Download and press Enter. Typically, when the download is finished, it is announced.

4.    Navigate to your Downloads folder where a ZIP file with the folder name appears at the top of the list, assuming you have not changed the default folder sort criterion to something other than most recent download on top.

5.    Open the ZIP file where a standard subfolder is located with the same folder name and with its contents inside.

6.    Select the subfolder, press Control + C to copy it, navigate to your preferred save location, and paste it there with Control + V.

7.    If some of the files contained in the folder are Google-formatted files, it is probably a good idea to save the folder to your My Drive GDFD folder.

When you are the owner, steps for sharing without editing rights are:

1.    Place focus on the file or folder to be shared within the GDFD My Drive folder.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Copy link to clipboard, and press Enter.

3.    Paste the link in the body of an email and send the message to the intended recipients.

12.2.6 Removing People from Shared Folders Owned by You

To remove access to a user with whom you have already shared a folder with editing rights:

1.    In GDFD, place focus on the folder.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Share, and press Enter.

3.    You land in the edit combo box listing those with whom you have shared the folder. Down arrow to the email address of the person whose access you wish to remove.

4.    You will hear Change permission submenu. Press Enter to open it.

5.    Down arrow through the options, which include Viewer, Commenter, Editor Organize, add, and edit files (this is checked if it is the current sharing status), Add expiration For viewer and commenter roles, Transfer ownership, and Remove access.

6.    Press Enter on Remove access (or one of the other options if you prefer to modify sharing access in one of those other ways).

7.    Tab to the Save button and press Enter. You will hear “access updated.”

12.2.7 Removing Yourself from a Folder Owned by Somebody Else

In GDFD, place focus on the shortcut to the shared folder, press Delete, and then press the Yes button to confirm. This only removes the shortcut in My Drive, but the folder is still shared. You might want to remove your collaborator status in order to clean up your Shared with Me folder. If you don’t do this from time to time, this folder may get crowded with files and folders you no longer want.

To remove yourself as a member of a shared folder, this must be done in Google Drive online. Steps are:

1.    Open a new tab in your browser, type drive.google.com, and press Enter.

2.    Press Insert + Z to turn off the Virtual PC cursor for JAWS, or press Insert + Spacebar to turn off The NVDA Browse mode or the Narrator Scan mode.

3.    Press Alt + G, and then F to open the Folder view.

4.    Down arrow to Shared with Me and press Enter.

5.    Down arrow to the folder to be removed from sharing status, and press the Delete key.

6.    You are asked to confirm that you want to remove the file or folder, and also told that collaborators will still have access.

7.    Press Enter on the Remove button.

12.2.8 Removing Others from a Folder Owned by You

To remove folder collaborators for a folder that you own:

1.    In GDFD, place focus on the folder that you own.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Share with Google Drive, and press Enter.

3.    Tab to the Add people and groups edit combo box, and Down arrow to the person you want to remove.

4.    Press Enter to select the person.

5.    Tab to the Change permissions menu and press the Spacebar to expand the list.

6.    Down arrow to Remove and press Enter.

12.2.9 Checking Your Storage Use

As mentioned earlier, you get 15 GB of storage space with a free Google account. This is shared across Google Drive, Gmail, and Google Photos. Knowing this breakdown can be useful if you are approaching your storage limit and need to delete something.

To get a quick idea of your overall storage use, open Google Drive online, toggle off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode, and Tab once. You will hear the number of GB’s used.

Open Google One to get a breakdown of how much you are using in Google Drive, Gmail, and Google Photos. To go there:

1.    In your browser, go to one.google.com.

2.    If you have multiple Google accounts, select the one you are interested in.

3.    Press H to go to the Storage and more with Google One level one heading.

4.    Press B to go to a button which reveals the amount of storage currently used. An example of what you might hear is, “Storage 13% used 2.08 GB of 15 GB button.”

5.    Press Enter on this button, and then L until you get to a list of three items.

6.   Down arrow to hear the storage capacity used for each of the three categories: Google Drive, Gmail, and Google Photos.

7.    There are links below each of these. Press Enter on one of these to access the full list of files and folders currently using storage in that category.

If you are nearing your storage capacity, Google will probably bother you with constant notifications to buy more storage. At this point, you probably want to get serious about removing unwanted files and folders. Unless you have accumulated tens of thousands of email messages because you never delete them, the amount of storage used by Gmail is negligible.

While you can delete Google Drive files and folders and Google photos here, it is much easier to do this in GDFD and your smartphone’s Google Photos apps, respectively. If you think lots of photos are being saved to your Google account and you are not sure why, you can adjust the Google Photos app settings so that photos are not automatically uploaded.

12.2.10 Summary of Useful Online Google Drive Keystrokes

I strongly prefer managing my Google files and folders in GDFD rather than in the online environment, but this is my personal preference. You may wish to make up your own mind. Below is a list of keystrokes for exploring the online environment:

·         Alt + G and then F: Folder view.

·         Control + Alt + R: Add shortcut to Drive dialog.

·         Alt + G and then L: Toggle between Grid and List view.

·         In the My Drive tree view, Right and Left arrow to move between folder levels, and Down and Up arrow to move within a tree view folder level. Press Enter on a folder to access its files and subfolders.

·        Alt + A: With focus on a folder or file, opens a context menu with actions such as new folder, open, download, share, information, rename, and move to trash.

·         Delete: Remove a file or folder.

·         Alt + N: Opens the Create menu. Down arrow to create a new folder, Doc, Sheet, Slide or Form. While each of these actions have a shortcut key, with this menu, you don’t have to memorize any of these additional keystrokes.

·         To further acquaint your self with Drive Online, open the web page below and listen to this informative Freedom Scientific free webinar posted in September 2024:

·         Navigate and Manage Google Drive with JAWS

·         NVDA users will also find this webinar useful because all Google keystrokes mentioned are the same. The only difference relates to being sure you are in NVDA’s Focus mode.

12.3 Googledocs

Googledocs is the Google equivalent of Word. While it lacks some of the advanced features of Word, all basic features and quite a few intermediate or advanced features are present. Many reading and editing keystrokes are the same as with Word. Carrying out some formatting tasks may also be more intuitive with Googledocs. Googledocs is a particularly useful tool for collaboration between people jointly working on documents. It allows multiple users to edit a document simultaneously, making it possible to collaborate with others in real-time. Documents are autosaved as you draft them, a feature that some users consider an advantage, while others do not. I consider the inability to disable autosave to be the most significant shortcoming of Googledocs. Consequently, I personally would never use it for composing large documents, or documents of any degree of complexity, fearing that I might save my mistakes and have to waste significant time fixing them.

To open Googledocs, on the Address bar of your browser, type “docs.google.com” minus the quotes, and then press Enter.

Do three things to make Googledocs accessible with a screenreader:

·         Press Control + Alt + Z to enable screenreader support.

·         Press Control + Alt + H to enable Braille support. Do this even if you do not use Braille. Otherwise, the Say All command will not work.

·         With JAWS, press Insert + Z to turn off the Virtual PC cursor. With NVDA press Insert + Spacebar to switch from Browse mode to Focus mode.

When you enable screenreader and Braille support the first time, these will stay set in future sessions. By contrast, you will need to switch off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor each time you open Googledocs. With NVDA, Googledocs opens in Focus mode, but there will be times when you want to switch to Browse mode.

Note that sometimes refreshing your browser screen by pressing F5 helps if the app seems to be misbehaving.

12.3.1 Opening a Googledoc

Assuming you are signed into Google, the quickest way to open a blank Googledoc is to open your browser, and in the Address bar, type “docs.new,” minus the quotes, and then press Enter. If you are already in a Google app window (Drive, Sheets, etc.), this is the most reliable way to make this work because it is clear you are signed in.

Without opening a browser, you can also open a blank Googledoc from within the Google Drive for Desktop app. With Windows 11, from inside the GDFD My Drive folder:

1.    Press Alt to open the Windows 11 menu.

2.    You land on the New button which is collapsed. Press the Spacebar to expand it.

3.    Down arrow to Googledoc and press Enter.

The quickest and easiest way to open an existing doc is from within GDFD. Within your My Drive folder, simply navigate to the filename for the doc and press Enter.

You can also open an existing doc from within Googledocs. Steps are:

1.    Open a new tab in your web browser, type in “docs.google.com,” minus the quotes and press Enter.

2.    With your JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode still on, press B several times to go to the Open file picker button, and press Enter.

3.    Press Insert + Z to turn off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor, or Insert + Spacebar to turn on the NVDA Focus mode.

4.    Down arrow to the doc that you wish to open, and press Enter.

It is also easy to open a Word File in Googledocs from within GDFD. With focus on the Word document, press the Applications key, Down arrow to Open with Googledocs, and press Enter. If you are using Windows 11 and do not detect this option in the context menu, open Show more options and you should find it.

12.3.2 Text Reading and Basic Editing

All reading keystrokes (Left/right arrow to read characters, Control + Right/Left arrow to read words, etc.) are the same as in Word. So too are text selection keystrokes. Control + B, Control + I, and Control + U are the same for bolding, italicizing, and underlining text, respectively.

Control + Alt + 1 through Control + Alt 6 work for creating headings in Googledocs. In Word for headings four and lower, you must assign keystrokes yourself. TO change text to Normal style in Googledocs, press Control + Alt + 0 (in Word, the equivalent is Control + Shift + N).

With both JAWS and NVDA, Insert + F also works for checking font and paragraph formatting.

Keystrokes are slightly different than in Word for aligning text:

·         Control + Shift + L: left align.

·         Control + Shift + E: center align.

·         Control + Shift R: Right align.

·         Control + Shift J: Justify.

12.3.3 Menu Overview and Navigation

To open the Googledocs menu, be sure that your JAWS Virtual PC cursor is off or that your NVDA Focus mode is on. Then press Alt and F together to land on the File menu. Each menu area has a shortcut key (these are listed below) that you can memorize if you like. At a minimum, remember Alt and F together so you can get onto the menu bar. You can then Right and Left arrow to move between menu categories.

When you press Alt + F, your screenreader should say “File menu, one of nine.” If instead, you hear, “New tab, one of 19 or 20,” you have opened your browser menu. Press Escape and try again.

To access commands for any of the menu categories, Down or Up arrow. You will find that there are quite a few submenus. Press Enter or Right arrow to expand them, and Left arrow to collapse them.
