Listed below are the menu categories, their respective shortcut keys, and some of the most important commands within them:

File menu (Alt + F): share, new, open, make a copy, email, Add shortcut to Drive, move, send to trash, download, rename, page setup (margins, orientation), print.

·         Edit menu (Alt + E): find and replace, paste without formatting.

·         View submenu (Alt + V): nothing very significant here.

·         Insert menu (Alt + I): images, tables, charts, breaks, headers, footers, page numbers, comments, footnotes, table of contents.

·         Format menu (Alt + O): paragraph styles, line spacing, alignment, bullets and numbering, header and footer format.

·         Tools menu (Alt + T): spelling and grammar, accessibility settings.

·         Help menu (Alt + H): list of keystrokes, command search.

·         Accessibility menu (Alt + A): speak various format items, navigate to next/previous heading, and many others.

It is sometimes buggy to bring up the menus. if pressing Alt + F or any of the other shortcuts fail to bring up the menu categories, there are a few things you can try. First, refreshing the page by pressing F5 frequently helps. Second, try adding the Shift key to the key combination: that is, Alt + Shift + F rather than just Alt + F to bring up the File menu.

Sometimes, you succeed in opening the menus by pressing Alt + F or one of the other menu bar shortcuts, but Right arrowing fails to keep you on the menu bar, instead moving you to commands within the various menus. When that happens, press Control + Shift F which toggles between Compact and normal menu controls. Be sure you are using Normal controls.

12.3.4 The Main toolbar

All the font and paragraph formatting commands can be found in the Main toolbar. Because you can pretty much find everything here for basic formatting, it can be very helpful, especially for beginners. That said, as we will see below, the Format menu has strong intuitive appeal for some commands.

To open the Main toolbar, press Alt + F (or any of the menu shortcuts), and then Tab a few times. You will hear, Main toolbar, Undo (Control + Z) button. Right or Left arrow between the commands.

Among the most useful items on the Main toolbar are: font name, size and color, bulleted lists, numbered lists, line spacing, clear formatting and a few others. If shortcut keys exist for these commands, they are identified. Some of the most useful ones I have found here include:

·         Spelling and grammar: Control + Alt + X.

·         Decrease font size: Control + Shift + Comma.

·         Increase font size: Control + Shift + period.

·         Numbered list: Control + Shift + 7.

·         Bulleted list: Control + Shift + 8

12.3.5 Document Formatting

As is the case with both JAWS and NVDA in Word, press Insert + F to reveal some aspects of font and paragraph formatting. The amount of information revealed is less extensive than in Word. For example, when I pressed Insert + F on a heading 1 using JAWS, I heard, “Font is bold Arial 16 point, Paragraph formatting centered.” In NVDA, you also hear foreground and background color information. In Word, I would also have heard style and line spacing information.

12.3.5.1 Font Settings

The Main toolbar menu is the best place to change most font settings. To do this:

1.    Select the text you want to format.

2.    Press Alt + F together or any other menu shortcut to go to the menu bar.

3.    Press Tab twice to go to the Main toolbar.

4.    Right arrow to the Font list and Down arrow through the choices. The current font for the selected text is at the top of the list and it is checked. Below that are some other commonly used font types. Additional font types are further down the list. Unfortunately, you cannot first-letter navigate to your choice.

5.    Press Enter on your choice

To change font size, press Control + Shift + Comma and Control + Shift period to decrease and increase font size, respectively. On the Main toolbar, you can also Right arrow two or three times past the Font list to the Font size combo box, Down arrow to your choice, and press Enter. If you can remember them, using the two shortcut keys for increasing and decreasing font size are obviously much quicker.

Continue Right arrowing to the Text color button menu, and Down arrow to go through the foreground color options. Press Enter on your choice. One Right arrow past this is the Highlight color button menu where you can change the background color. This could be useful for students wishing to highlight text.

Unfortunately, you are obliged to make each font setting change separately. Unlike with Word, there is no dialog you can Tab through to make several changes all at once. Therefore, with the exception of using the shortcuts to increase and decrease font size, it is a bit slower to make font changes in Googledocs than in Word.

12.3.5.2 Paragraph Settings, Including Bulleted and Numbered Lists

These are most efficiently changed in the Format menu. It is quicker to use the Format menu where these settings are found within several submenus. To access them open the Format menu using the shortcut Alt O. Then Down arrow to the various submenus. You can move even more quickly if you use the single shortcut letter to open the submenus, which are included in parentheses below:

·         Align and indent submenu (A): Right arrow to expand, Down arrow to your alignment choice (left, center, right, and justify), and press Enter. You can instead use the shortcut keys Control + Shift + L for left, Control + Shift + E for center, Control + Shift R for right, and Control + Shift J for justified. Continue Down arrowing to Increase and Decrease indentation. If you press Enter on one of these, indentation will be adjusted by one-half inch. Indentation shortcuts are Control + Right and Left bracket to increase and decrease indentation, respectively. Down arrow one more time and press Enter to open the Indentation options dialog. Tab to Left where the default is 0.5 inches and type a new value if you want to change this. Tab once to Right where the default is 0 inches and type a new value if you want to change this. Tab once to Special indentation where the default is No special indentation. To change this, Down arrow to the other two options which are First line indentation and Hanging indentation. First line is important if you would like to indent the first line of each paragraph. Press Enter to select this, and Tab once where the default is 0.5 inches, something you will rarely want to change. to save any new Indentation options, Tab to the Apply button and press Enter.

·         Line & paragraph spacing submenu (L): Right arrow to expand. Among the line spacing options are Single, 1.15 (the default), 1.55 inches, and double. Continue Down arrowing to Add space before paragraph or Add space after paragraph. Default before and after paragraph spacing for normal text is 0 point. If you add before or after paragraph spacing, the default is 10 point. Down arrow one more time to Custom spacing, where you can change before and after paragraph spacing values if desired.

·         Bullets and numbers submenu (T): By far the quickest way to create bulleted and numbered lists is to use the shortcut keys (Control + Shift 8 for bullets and Control + Shift 7 for numbers). These will add the default bullet format which is a round black dot for bullets, and simple numbering followed by a period. Within this submenu, you can change to other formats (hollow bullets, Roman numerals, etc.).

These paragraph settings options are also present on the Main toolbar, but it is less efficient to make these changes there.

12.3.5.3 Headings and Styles

As mentioned in Chapter 3.4, headings and styles are powerful tools for ensuring consistent document formatting, as well as for aiding navigation.

Adding headings to a Googledoc is very easy. To apply a heading style to a single line of text, from anywhere on that line, simply press Control + Alt + 1 through Control + Alt 6 to apply any of those heading level styles to that line. For example, if you press Control + Alt + 2, your screenreader will announce, Heading two style applied.” Press Control + Alt + 0 to apply the Normal style, or remove a heading style. To apply a style to more than a single line of text, you must first select the lines.

Updating a heading style within a document is also relatively easy. I would say that it is perhaps more straightforward than in Word. Using level two headings as an example, steps are:

1.    Select the text of one of the current level 2 headings in your document and make whatever font and paragraph changes you wish to make.

2.    Press Alt O to open the Format menu.

3.    Down arrow to the Paragraph styles submenu (P), and Right arrow to expand it.

4.    Down arrow to the Heading 2 submenu, and press the Right arrow to expand it.

5.    Down arrow to Update heading 2 to match, and press Enter.

6.    Navigate to one of the other level 2 headings in the document and press Insert + F to verify that the heading style has been correctly updated.

Changing default styles is much quicker and easier in Googledocs than in Word. In Word, there are more steps to change a single default style. You also have to change them one at a time. To change one or more default styles in Googledocs:

1.    Update one or more styles in a current document using the steps listed above.

2.    Press Alt O to open the Format menu.

3.    Down arrow to the Paragraph styles submenu (P), and Right arrow to expand it.

4.    Up arrow once or twice to the Options submenu and Right arrow to expand it.

5.    You land on Save as my default styles. Press Enter. Your screenreader will announce, “Your default styles have been saved.”

There are two other options in this submenu of interest:

·         Use my default styles: Choose this option to change the styles of the current document to your default styles.

·         Reset styles: Choose this option to change your defaults back to the factory defaults.

·         Factory default styles are all Arial, black text on a white background, single spaced and left aligned. Point size and before and after paragraph spacing vary. Here are the defaults for heading levels one through three and normal text:

·         Heading 1: 20 or 16 point, bold, 0 point before and after paragraph spacing.

·         Heading 2: 14 point, bold, 2 point before paragraph and 0 point after paragraph spacing.

·         Heading 3: 13 point, bold, 2 point before paragraph and 0 point after paragraph spacing.

·         Normal: 12 point, regular, 0 point before paragraph and 8 point after paragraph spacing.

·         Note that these might vary slightly from one computer to the next, as well as between web browsers and their versions. For your own computer, check by opening a new Googledoc, inserting headings and normal text and checking the various format settings. If you download a Googledoc as a Word file, these formats should be retained. But it is always a good idea to doublecheck.

·         With regard to navigating headings in Docs, native Google keystrokes exist for moving heading by heading. But they are unwieldy and inefficient. Use the JAWS and NVDA methods below instead.

·         With JAWS, you can use the layered command for turning on Quick keys to Navigate headings and heading levels efficiently. Turn off the Virtual PC cursor. Then press Insert and Spacebar together, followed by G. JAWS will say Quick keys. Similar to Word, press H and Shift H to go to the next and previous heading. Press 1, 2, 3, etc. to go to the next level 1, 2, 3, etc. heading. Press Escape to turn off Quick keys and return to Edit mode.

·         If you also have NVDA installed on your computer and want to use this layered JAWS keystroke, you must first disable the Control + Alt + N hotkey to open NVDA. This is because Control + Alt + N is part of the native Google keystroke configuration for headings navigation, and this results in a conflict. To do this:

7.    Press Windows + M or Windows + D to go to the Desktop.

8.    Press N to go to the NVDA Icon, but do not press Enter on it.

9.    Press Alt Enter to quickly open the Properties dialog.

10. Tab twice to the Shortcut key edit box, and delete Control + Alt + N.

11. Leave the edit field blank if you are not interested in assigning a new NVDA hotkey. Or to assign a new one, type in the single letter. Control + Alt is automatically added. Be sure the key chosen does not conflict with an existing key assignment.

12. Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

13. Press Enter on the Continue button.

14. You should now be done. However, if you do not have administrative rights, you will also have to Enter the administrator’s password after pressing the Continue button.

·         At present, it is not possible to bring up the JAWS headings list in Docs. Workarounds are to either switch to NVDA or download the file as a Word document.

With NVDA, press Insert and the Spacebar to switch to Browse mode, press the same keys as above with JAWS to navigate by heading and heading level. This is the same way to use quick key navigation with NVDA in Word.

Also with NVDA, while in either Browse or Focus mode, you can open the Elements list (Insert + F7 and then access the headings list. However, as I mentioned in Chapter 3.4.1, the NVDA headings list expresses heading levels in a confusing way.

12.3.5.4 Margin Settings

Margin settings are found in the Page Setup dialog in the File menu. Default dimensions are one inch top, bottom, left and right. To change these:

1.    Press Alt and F together to open the File menu.

2.    Up arrow twice to Page Setup and press Enter.

3.    Tab to the Top edit field and type in your new setting, for example.75 for three-quarter inch.

4.    Tab to the Bottom, Left, and Right edit fields, and type in dimensions here.

5.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

These are your new margin settings for this document only, The Set as default button is found one tab past the Right margin edit field, but you would probably not want default margin dimensions to be other than one inch all around.

Other settings in the Page Setup dialog you can change are orientation and page size. Defaults are portrait orientation and 8.5 by 11 inch page size.

12.3.6 File Menu Commands

Many important commands are found in the File menu which is opened by pressing Alt and F together. The most crucial thing to know is that, because Googledocs are autosaved, if you do not give the file a name, it will still be saved, and with the name Untitled document. To give the file a meaningful filename, use the Rename command.

Below are useful File menu commands, listed in the order in which they are encountered as you Down arrow through the menu:

·         New submenu: Open a new tab containing a blank Googledoc or template.

·         Open: Open recent Googledocs or Word files into Googledocs that are stored in your Google Drive folder by Down arrowing to your choice and pressing Enter.

·         Save as Googledocs: This menu item will appear if you are working on a Word file that you have uploaded to Googledocs. Press Enter and the file will be saved as a Googledoc with the same file suffix and a GDOC extension. This now becomes the active file.

·         Make a copy: Because Googledocs are autosaved, use this command to preserve a previously saved document that you do not want to alter and edit the copy. Its filename will be “copy of” and the original filename.

·         Share submenu: The first option here is Share with others. Press Enter to open the Share dialog where you can add email addresses of people with whom you would like to share the file, designate levels of editing privileges and send an email informing them that they have been granted sharing privileges. They will then be able to find the file listed in the Share with me folder in Google Drive online.

·         Email submenu: Press Enter on Email this file to address a message and add it as an attachment in various formats, including Word, PDF, RTF, and TXT.

·         Download submenu: Download the file in Word format to your Downloads folder. Other formats include PDF, RTF, TXT, PDF, and ePub.

·         Rename: This is the Google equivalent of Save as. Give your file a meaningful name here. Otherwise it will be saved with the name untitled document. While you can designate a save location in this dialog, it is easier to simply save it without designating a location, and then moving it to its desired location from within GDFD.

·         Move to trash: Use this to delete the file. Deleted files can be restored within 30 days from the Google Drive online Trash folder.

·         Version history submenu: This submenu has two options. The first option is Name current version. You can name the current version and then continue working with the file, which will be autosaved as you proceed. The second option, See version history, provides a list of earlier file versions going back in one hour intervals. If you land on one of these, you can Tab to the More options button, expand it, and save a copy.

·         Language submenu: Open this and Down arrow to other languages you would like to work in while composing your document.

·         Page setup: Among other things, you can change margins here (see Chapter 12.3.5.4 above).

·         Print: Opens the Print dialog where you can change several print-related settings and send your document to a printer. You can also use the universal shortcut key, Control + P, to open the dialog.

12.3.7 Help Resources

Useful help resources can be accessed via the Help menu (the shortcut key is Alt H). Among these are:

·         Press Control + Slash to open a new tab containing a list of shortcut keys. After pressing Control + Slash, press Insert + Z with JAWS to turn on the Virtual PC cursor, or Insert + Spacebar to return NVDA to Browse mode. In this new tab, shortcut keys appear under the following headings: Text formatting,, Paragraph formatting,, With objects,, Editing,, Navigation,, Menus,, and Comments.

·         Press Alt and the Slash keys together to search for and execute commands, saving you the effort of having to locate them in the menus. After typing in your command search term, Down arrow to the command you wish to execute. This is the equivalent of the Microsoft Office Tell Me feature with Alt Q (see Chapter 13.3.1 ).

·         Visit Google Workspace User Guide to Accessibility - Google Workspace Learning Center, and navigate to the Googledocs heading. There are a number of links under this heading to informative web pages related to editing, reviewing, and accessibility.

12.3.8 Other Useful Tools and Features

12.3.8.1 Spellcheck

The Spellcheck submenu is found in the Tools menu. You can also use the shortcut key combination, Control + Alt X, to start this utility.

In the submenu, you can make adjustments by checking and unchecking the Show spelling suggestions and Show grammar suggestions checkboxes, if you only want to proof your document for one of these. The default setting is to check for both.

To start spellchecking, press Control + Alt X. Elements of the Spellcheck dialog are listed below in their tab order:

·         You first hear the incorrectly spelled word and a proposed corrected spelling. Unlike with Word, you do not hear these spelled out letter by letter. You can press Insert and 5 twice on the Numpad to spell them out if you like. Also unlike in Word, only one correction choice is proposed, rather than several options. If the correction option proposed is not the correction you want, you must Escape out of Spellcheck and manually correct. To accept the proposed correction, press Enter or Spacebar on this button and proceed to the next spelling or grammar error.

·         Ignore button: Press this to reject the proposed correction and proceed to the next proposed correction.

·         Accept button: An alternative way to accept the proposed correction.

·         More options button menu: Press the Spacebar to expand and Down arrow through the options, which include: Accept all (with the number of occurrences found in parentheses), Ignore all (with the number of occurrences found in parentheses), Add to personal dictionary, and View personal dictionary.

·         Previous suggestion button: Return to the last correction and change your choice if desired.

·         Next suggestion button: Proceed to the next proposed correction.

·         Close button: Close Spellcheck. Alternatively, press the Escape key anywhere in the dialog to return to the document.

12.3.8.2 Headers and Footers, Including Page Numbering

To insert page numbers to a header or footer, do the following:

1.    Open the Insert menu (Alt I).

2.    Down arrow to the Page numbering submenu and Right arrow to expand it.

3.    Up or Down arrow through the options which include: Page number and header starting on the first page, Page number and footer starting on the first page, and More options.

4.    If you want to start page numbering on the first page, choose one of the first choices. To examine other options, press Enter on More options which opens a dialog with the following tabs.

5.    Tab to the Header radio button. Up or Down arrow once if you wish to insert page numbers in a footer instead of a header.

6.    Tab to the Show on first page checkbox, and uncheck it if you do not want page numbers to appear on the first page of your document.

7.    Tab to the Start at radio button. If you want to adjust how page numbering is changed from the last page of a previous section, Down arrow to that radio button. If there are no previous sections, this radio button is dimmed out.

8.    Tab to the Start at Edit field, where the default is page 1. To change this, type in a different page number.

9.    Tab to the Apply button and press Enter to save your changes.

By default, page numbering appears right aligned. I do not know how to change this to left or center alignment without sighted assistance. That said, right header alignment is the requirement for most academic styles.

To add a header or footer that is exclusively text to your document:

1.    Open the Insert menu (Alt I).         

2.    Down arrow to the Header and footer submenu and Right arrow to expand it.

3.    Up or down arrow to Header or Footer and press Enter.

4.    The cursor lands at the left margin. Begin typing text here if you want your header or footer text to be left aligned. If you want text to be right aligned, press the End key and type it in. Centering text does not appear possible without sighted assistance.

5.    Press the Escape key to return to the main body of your document.

To remove a header or footer, repeat steps one through three above for inserting text, press Control + A to select all, and then press the Delete key to remove the text and/or page numbering.

If you would like to create a header or footer with left aligned text and right aligned page numbering, first insert page numbering, and then add header or footer text using the steps outlined above.

I think header and footer creation and editing is better handled by Word. If I were to create headers or footers in Googledocs, I would download the file in Word format and use the procedures discussed in Chapter 3.3 to verify that text and page numbering alignment is correct.

12.3.8.3 Realtime Collaboration

If you are sharing a Googledoc with others, and you all have full editing rights, you can simultaneously edit it. Editing actions of collaborators will be announced. You will be notified when individual collaborators are entering and leaving paragraphs to examine them. If you find the level of verbosity to be distracting, you can disable these notifications. Steps are:

1.    Open the Tools menu (Alt T).

2.    Up arrow to Accessibility and press Enter.

3.    Tab to the Turn on collaborator announcements checkbox and press the Spacebar to uncheck it (it is on by default).

4.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

 12.4 Googlesheets

Googlesheets is the Google equivalent of Excel. Many reading and editing keystrokes are the same as with Excel. It is a particularly useful tool for collaboration between people jointly working on spreadsheets. It allows multiple users to edit simultaneously, making it possible to collaborate with others in real-time. A typical example is a shared database where multiple users need to enter and update data on an ongoing basis. As is the case with Googledocs, spreadsheet files are autosaved while you work on them.

To open Googlesheets, on the Address bar of your browser, type “sheets.google.com” minus the quotes, and then press Enter.

Similar to Googledocs, you need to do three things to make Googlesheets accessible with a screenreader:

·         Press Control + Alt + Z to enable screenreader support.

·         Press Control + Alt + H to enable Braille support. Do this even if you do not use Braille.

·         With JAWS, press Insert + Z to turn off the Virtual PC cursor. With NVDA press Insert + Spacebar to switch from Browse mode to Focus mode.

When you enable screenreader and Braille support the first time, these will stay set in future sessions. By contrast, you will need to switch off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or the NVDA Browse mode every time you start a new session, and sometimes during the same session when you move back and forth between windows.

Note that sometimes refreshing your browser screen by pressing F5 helps if the app seems to be misbehaving.

12.4.1 Opening a Google sheet

Assuming you are signed into Google, the quickest way to open a blank Googlesheet is to open your browser, and in the Address bar, type “sheets.new,” minus the quotes, and then press Enter. If you are already in a Google app window (Drive, Docs, etc.), this is the most reliable way to make this work because it is clear you are signed in.

You can also open a new blank sheet from inside the My Drive folder of Google Drive for Desktop (GDFD), To do this with Windows 10:

1.    Press Alt to open the Upper ribbon where you land on the Home Tab.

2.    Tab to the New item dropdown in the Lower ribbon, and press Alt + Down arrow to expand it.

3.    Down arrow to Googlesheets, and press Enter.

With Windows 11, from inside the GDFD My Drive folder:

1.    Press Alt to open the Windows 11 menu.

2.    You land on the New button which is collapsed. Press the Spacebar to expand it.

3.    Down arrow to Google sheet and press Enter.

The quickest and easiest way to open an existing sheet is from within GDFD. Within your My Drive folder, simply navigate to the filename for the sheet and press Enter.

You can also open an existing sheet from within Googlesheets. Steps are:

1.    Open a new tab in your web browser, type in “sheets.google.com,” minus the quotes and press Enter.

2.    With your JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode still on, press B several times to go to the Open file picker button, and press Enter.

3.    Press Insert + Z to turn off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor, or Insert + Spacebar to turn on the NVDA Focus mode.

4.    Down arrow to the sheet that you wish to open, and press Enter.

It is also easy to open an Excel File in Googlesheets from within GDFD. With focus on the Excel file, press the Applications key, Down arrow to Open with Googlesheets, and press Enter. If you are using Windows 11 and do not detect this option in the context menu, open Show more options and you should find it.

12.4.2 Navigation and Basic Editing

Most basic navigation keystrokes are the same between Googlesheets and Excel. These include:

·         The four arrow keys to navigate between adjacent cells.

·         Control + And the four arrow keys to move over filled and unfilled data ranges.

·         Control + Home to go to cell A1 from anywhere in a sheet.

·         Control + End to go to the cell that is the intersection of the last column and last row with at least one cell containing data.

Many editing keystrokes are also similar, including:

·         = sign to begin a formula.

·         F2: edit cell

·         Formulas are written similarly: Example: =sum(a1:a10) to sum the data range A1 through A10.

·         Cut (Control + X), copy (Control + C), and paste (Control + V).

·         Although the same keystrokes are used for row selection (Shift + Spacebar) and column selection (Control + Spacebar) as in Excel, there is an important difference. In Googlesheets, if you press Shift + Spacebar one time in a row containing data, only the filled data range is selected. You must press it a second time to select the entire row. You must also press Control + Spacebar twice to select an entire column.

12.4.3 Menu Overview

To open the Googlesheets menu, be sure that your JAWS Virtual PC cursor is off or that your NVDA Focus mode is on. Then press Alt and F together to land on the File menu. Each menu area has a shortcut key (these are listed below) that you can memorize if you like. At a minimum, remember Alt and F together so you can get onto the menu bar. You can then Right and Left arrow to move between menu categories.

When you press Alt + F, your screenreader should say “File menu, one of ten.” If instead, you hear, “New tab, one of 19 or 20,” you have opened your browser menu. Press Escape and try again.

To access commands for any of the menu categories, Down or Up arrow. You will find that there are quite a few submenus. Press Enter or Right arrow to expand them, and Left arrow to collapse them.

Listed below are the menu categories, their respective shortcut keys, and some of the most important commands within them:

·         File menu (Alt + F): share, new, open, import, make a copy, email, Add shortcut to Drive, move, send to trash, download, rename, print.

·         Edit menu (Alt E): paste special, delete rows and columns.

·         View menu (Alt V): show, freeze.

·         Insert menu (Alt I): insert rows and columns, new sheets, comments.

·         Format menu (Alt O): numbers, alignment, wrapping, font size.

·         Data menu (Alt Shift D): sort, filter, pivot tables.

·         Tools menu (Alt T): accessibility settings, spelling.

·         Accessibility menu (Alt A): verbalize to screenreader (for reding row and column titles).

It is sometimes buggy to bring up the menus. if pressing Alt + F or any of the other shortcuts fail to bring up the menu categories, there are a few things you can try. First, refreshing the page by pressing F5 often helps. Second, try adding the Shift key to the key combination: that is, Alt Shift F rather than just Alt + F to bring up the File menu.

·         Sometimes, you succeed in opening the menus by pressing Alt + F or one of the other menu bar shortcuts, but Right arrowing fails to keep you on the menu bar, instead moving you to commands within the various menus, and making it hard to know where you are. When that happens, press Control + Shift F which toggles between Compact and normal controls. Be sure you are using Normal controls.

12.4.4 Main toolbar

Similar to Googledocs, many important commands can be found in the Main toolbar. Because you can pretty much find everything here for basic formatting and editing, accessing commands here can be very helpful, especially for beginners. To open the Main toolbar, press Alt + F (or any of the menu shortcuts), and then Tab a few times until you hear, Main toolbar, Undo (Control + Z) button. Right or Left arrow between the commands. If shortcut keys exist for these commands, they are identified. Some of the most useful ones here include: Format as currency ‑, Format as percent ‑, Decrease decimal places ‑, Increase decimal places ‑, More formats ‑, Font list ‑, Decrease font size (Control + Shift + Comma) ‑, Font size, Increase font size (Control + Shift period) ‑, Borders ‑, Horizontal align ‑, Vertical align ‑, Text wrapping ‑, Insert comment (Control + Alt M) ‑, Create a filter, Filter views ‑, and Functions.

12.4.5 Constructing a Table

I will not build a table step by step as I did in Chapter 5.2 on Excel. Nor will I cover procedures that are exactly the same as in Excel pertaining to spreadsheet navigation, creating, editing, and copying formulas. I will instead discuss how to find the commands in the Googlesheets menus for building simple tables and how to use them. These commands include:

·         verbalize to screenreader: the equivalent of the Excel Define name command.

·         Insert and delete rows and columns.

·         Cell formatting for numeric values.

·         Merge cells

12.4.5.1 Verbalize to Screenreader

·         The Verbalize to screenreader command is the Googlesheets equivalent of the Excel Define name command. This is very useful because column and row headers are announced as you navigate within a table, thus greatly assisting in interpreting cell data. This command is found in the Googlesheets Accessibility menu. Steps for activating it are:

1.    Place your cursor on the cell that is the intersection of the column and row whose headers you want announced as you move around in the table body. I will use cell A2 as an example here.

2.    Press Alt A to open the Accessibility menu.

3.    Down arrow once to the verbalize to screenreader submenu, and Right arrow to expand it.

4.    Down arrow to Verbalize row 2 on column changes, and press Enter.

5.    Repeat steps two and three above to reopen the Accessibility menu and the verbalize to screenreader submenu.

6.    Down arrow to Verbalize column A on column changes, and press Enter.

What does this wording mean? Verbalize row 2 on column changes” means that as you Left and Right arrow in the body of the table, column headers in Row 2 will be spoken after hearing the cell data. Verbalize column A on row changes” means that as you Up and Down arrow in the body of the table, row headers in Column A will be spoken after hearing the cell data.

Once verbalization has been turned on, when you return to the verbalize to screenreader submenu, and Down arrow, options to Stop verbalizing row 2 and Stop verbalizing column A will appear. Press Enter on one of these if you want to do this.

12.4.5.2 Inserting and Deleting Rows and Columns

Commands for inserting and deleting rows and columns are found in the Insert and Edit menus, respectively. But you can find all relevant options by first selecting them (Shift + Spacebar twice to select a row and Control + Spacebar twice to select a column), and then pressing the Applications key.

After selecting a row, you will find Insert one row above, Insert one row below, and delete row in the context menu.

After selecting a column, you will find Insert  one column left, Insert one column right, and delete column in the context menu.

As is the case with Excel, press Shift + Down arrow several times to select multiple cells, and then repeat the steps above to insert or delete multiple rows. Press Shift + Right arrow several times to select multiple cells, and then repeat the steps above to insert or delete multiple columns.

To speed things up, memorize the following four key sequences that are Insert and Edit menu shortcuts

·         Alt I R R: Insert  a row above (the current row becomes blank).

·         Alt I C C: Insert column to the left (the current column becomes blank).

·         Alt E D D: Delete current row.

·         Alt E D E: Delete current column.

12.4.5.3 Cell Formatting

Choices similar to Excel are available for formatting cells with numeric values (see Chapter 5.2.5 on how these are handled in Excel). To change how numeric values appear in Googlesheets, first select the cell or cells you wish to format. Then press Alt O to open the Format menu, Down arrow to the Number submenu and Right arrow to expand it. The most commonly used numeric value options and their default formats are listed below:

·         Automatic: Simple numbering with no decimals unless you manually type them in.

·         Number: Numbering with comma separators and two decimals (example: 1,000,000.00).

·         Percent: Percentage sign and two decimals (example25.00%).

·         Currency: Dollar sign with two decimals ($1,000.00).

·         Currency rounded: Dollars rounded to nearest dollar (example: $12.86 rounded up to $13).

·         Date: Two-digit month/two-digit day/four-digit year (example: 07/04/2023).

·         Time: Hour:minutes:seconds AM or PM (example: 5:37:00 PM).

·         Date time: The above two combined (example: 07/04/2023 5:37:00 PM).

Numeric values can be customized through the options at the bottom of the submenu, including:

·         Custom currency: Many international currencies, with different formats for these currencies (example: six different formats for dollars including dollars with no decimals, starting with USD, etc.).

·         Custom date and time: Includes various ways to express months, days and years. Unfortunately, date customization is confusing and provides poor audio feedback on how changes appear visually.

·         Custom number format: numbers of decimals, comma separators, negative values.

·         Using the following shortcuts can make you more efficient:

·         Alt O N C: Dollars with two decimals

·         Alt O N P: Percentages with two decimals

·         Alt O N D: Two-digit month/two-digit day/four-digit year.

12.4.5.4 Merging Cells

People often center the title of their table, using the Merge command. Assuming the text of the table’s title is in cell A1, do the following:

1.    With focus on cell A1, hold down the Shift key and Right arrow to the last column in the table. For example, if columns extend to column G, hold down Shift Right arrow until you get to cell G1. As you select cells across the row, Googlesheets will tell you which cells are selected.

2.    Press Alt + F and Tab two times to Open the Main toolbar.

3.    Right arrow to the Merge cells button and press Enter. You hear, “A1 through G1 selected. Merged selection A1 through G1 selected.”

4.    To center the text, press Control + Shift + E.

·         If you navigate to a merged cell, your screenreader will say the text in the cell and which cells have been selected.

·         To remove cell merging, with focus on the merged cell, return to the Main toolbar and Right arrow. Your screenreader will now say,: Merge cells Toggle button Pressed.” Press Enter to unmerge the cell. Also press Control + Shift + L to be sure the text is left aligned in the newly unmerged cell.

12.4.6 Multiple sheets

To navigate to the next sheet in Googlesheets, press Alt + Down arrow or Control + Shift + Page down. To navigate to the previous sheet, press Alt + Up arrow or Control + Shift + Page up. After a lot of verbosity about numbers of rows and columns is rattled off, You may eventually hear the sheet name,. Unlike with Excel, pressing Insert + T does not reveal the sheet name.

·         Press Alt Shift K to get a list of sheets. Then Up or Down arrow to the sheet you want to open, and press Enter. First-letter navigation is not possible. This is a big inconvenience if your spreadsheet contains a large number of sheets. However, you can press Home and End to go to the first and last sheet in the list, respectively.

·         Regarding the various actions you can take related to multiple sheets, press Shift + F11 to create a new sheet. You can also perform this action via the Insert menu. New sheets are placed just after the sheet where you initiated this action. This contrasts with Excel where new sheets are placed before the initial sheet.

Pressing Alt Shift S opens a context menu where you can perform various actions related to multiple sheets. In the order in which they appear as you Down arrow, here are the most useful actions:

·         Duplicate: This inserts a copy of the current sheet just before it. Its title is “copy of,” followed by the current sheet name.

·         Copy to submenu: The two options include Copy to new spreadsheet and Copy to existing spreadsheet.

o   Copy to new spreadsheet opens a dialog where you can open a link to the new spreadsheet. Its filename remains “Untitled spreadsheet” until you rename it.

o   Copy to existing spreadsheet also opens a dialog where you can select an existing Googlesheets file and insert it. It will appear as the last sheet in the file where it has been inserted. Its title will be “copy of” with the original sheet name.

·         rename: Similar to Excel, default sheet names are generic “Sheet 1, Sheet 2, etc.” Be sure to rename them. Otherwise, you will quickly lose track of which sheet is which.

·         Move right: Activate this to move the sheet one position down the list. You will hear the sheet name followed by its movement, for example, “USA, moved from position 4 to position 5.” Unfortunately, you can only move sheets one position at a time which can be tedious in spreadsheets with lots of sheets. This option does not appear if you are situated on the last sheet in the list.

·         Move left: Same as above in the opposite direction. This option does not appear if you are situated on the first sheet in the list.

·         Delete: Delete the current sheet. You are given a heads up prompt. Tab to the OK button and press Enter to confirm sheet deletion.

·         All of the above is pretty intuitive and quickly grasped. But as mentioned, in a file containing a large number of sheets, navigating between sheets and moving them around is tedious. In such situations, working with JAWS and Excel is more efficient.

12.4.7 Sorting and Filtering Data

Both sorting and filtering commands are found in the Data menu, whose shortcut key is Alt D.

12.4.7.1 Sorting

Column data can easily be sorted alphabetically, numerically, and by date. To sort alphabetically:

1.    In the column you would like to sort by (I will use column A as an example here), place the cursor on one of the cells in that column containing data. Do not place the cursor on the column header.

2.    Press Alt D to open the Data menu.

3.    Down arrow once to the Sort submenu and Right arrow to expand it.

4.    Submenu choices are: Sort sheet by column A - A to Z, or Sort sheet by column A – Z to A. Press Enter on your choice.

Steps for sorting column data numerically and chronologically are the same. Submenu choices for both remain A to Z and Z to A. For numeric sorting, A to Z sorts with the smaller values at the top of the column and larger numbers at the bottom. For chronological sorting, A to Z sorts with older dates at the top of the column and more recent dates at the bottom. For both numeric and chronological sorting, any cells with words or blanks rather than numbers will appear at the bottom of the column.

12.4.7.2 Filtering

As mentioned in Chapter 5.6, filtering allows you to temporarily hide some data in a sheet so you can isolate those data that you want to examine more closely. This is especially useful for working with large datasets. In other words, you are “filtering out” the data you are not currently interested in.

I will use the same file referenced in Chapter 5.6 that I used for demonstrating filtering with Excel: “Quarterly Sales By Employee.xlsx.” You may wish to open it in Googlesheets. To do this, first copy the Excel file to your GDFD folder. Then with focus on the Excel file, press the Applications key, Down arrow to Open with Googlesheets, and press Enter. If you are using Windows 11 and do not detect this option in the context menu, open Show more options and you should find it.

This worksheet contains quarterly sales data for employees in five fictitious electronics stores in the Boston area. Before initiating filtering, delete any rows above the column headers to ensure reliable and consistent results. For this file, I have deleted the first row which had the title of the table. The Sheets shortcut to delete the current row is Alt E D D.

Column headers in this workbook now go across row 1 and include:

·         Store (column A): The five stores (Boston, Cambridge, Quincy, Watertown, and Newton).

·         Employee (column B): The first names of three employees in each of the stores, for a total of 15 employees.

·         Quarter (column C): Quarters one through four of a particular year.

·         Product (column D): Three products sold in each of the stores (iPhone SE, Samsung TV, and HP laptops).

·         Quantity (column E): The number of each of these products sold by an employee in a particular quarter.

·         Price (column F): The unit price in dollars for each of the products.

·         Sales (column G): The formula for price times quantity expressed in dollars.

As an example, I will filter to narrow focus to just the Cambridge and Newton stores. To turn on filtering, the cursor can be anywhere on the sheet, provided that there are no rows above the column header row. Once again, this is why I deleted the first row which contained the table title. In addition, there can not be any empty rows between the column header row and the data rows. Steps for filtering are:

1.    From anywhere in the data sheet, press Alt D to open the Data menu, Down arrow to Create a filter, and press Enter.

2.    Navigate to the column header row 1 where you should now hear “Has filter drop down.”

3.    Place your cursor on the cell containing the column header you first want to filter. I will start in cell A1 where the column header “Store” appears.

4.    Press Control + Alt R, which opens a dialog. It is announced that you are in a context menu and on the Sort command.

5.    Tab Several times to the Clear button and press the Spacebar.

6.    Tab to the Filter edit box (more on what this is in a moment).

7.    Down arrow where unchecked checkboxes appear for each of the five Boston area stores. They are all unchecked because I cleared them a moment ago. Press Enter on the check boxes that you want to appear, in this case, Cambridge and Newton. You must press Enter, and not Spacebar.

8.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

You immediately hear some useful information, including how many rows currently appear and the total number of rows,, in this case, “72 of 180 rows displayed.”

My focus is still in cell A1 where I initiated this filter. If I Down arrow and Up arrow back to cell A1, my screenreader now announces, “Has filter dropdown with applied filter,” indicating that I have applied a filter to data in that column. If I Down arrow one row, it says A38 because rows 2 through 37 are now hidden.

I could now carry out additional filtering for these two stores, for example narrowing down to just one or two quarters or one product. To do that, I would position the cursor on the appropriate column header (Quarter or Product), and repeat steps four through eight above.

The Filter edit box mentioned above is useful for first-letter navigation if you have to make your selections from a long list of possible values. In this example, I only have five stores to select from, but if I had to select from a list of 50 or 100 stores, first-letter navigation is obviously faster than Down arrowing through all the choices. If I type C in the Filter edit box, I land on Cambridge and I can then press Enter to check it. I then backspace out the C and type N for Newton, and press Enter to check that check box.

To keep filtering on, but unhide all the store rows:

1.    With the cursor on the column header for the stores (cell A1), press Control + Alt R, to open the Filter dialog.

2.    Tab to the Select all button and press the Spacebar, which rechecks all the check boxes

3.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

4.    Down arrow to find out that all the rows have been restored.

To completely turn off filtering, press Alt D to open the Data menu, Down arrow to Remove filter, and press Enter. You no longer hear “Has filter dropdown” as you move along the column header row.

Filtering works very nicely in tandem with multiple worksheets because you can copy filtered data to new sheets and perform further analysis on the filtered data

12.4.8 Additional Topics

12.4.8.1 Adjusting Column Width

To adjust the width of a column, you must select the column first by pressing Control + Spacebar twice. After pressing it the first time, you hear the range where data are present. Pressing Control + Spacebar the second time actually selects the entire column, and your screenreader will tell you this.

Googlesheets expresses column width in pixels. The default is 120 pixels. There are 96 pixels in one inch, so this default equals 1.25 inches. Similar to Excel, you can change column width both manually and by autofitting.

To manually change column width:

1.    Press Control + Spacebar twice to select the column.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Resize column, and press Enter. This opens a dialog where you either land on the first of two radio buttons or in an edit field. The default of 120 pixels is mentioned.

3.    Tab to the edit field and type in a new value, keeping in mind that 96 pixels equals one inch.

4.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter. You will be told that the column has been resized to this value.

To autofit column width:

1.    Press Control + Spacebar twice to select the column.

2.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Resize column, and press Enter.

3.    In the dialog, Tab to the radio buttons and Down arrow to Fit to data.

4.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter. You will be told that the column has been fit to data.

5.    To find out what this new autofitted pixel value is, return to the Resize dialog and Tab to the edit box to see it.

12.4.8.2 Wrapping Text

How to do this in Excel was covered in Chapter 5.8.2. As mentioned there, text wrapping increases row height, causing text to appear on multiple lines within that cell. Use the Text Wrapping feature when preparing spreadsheets for a sighted audience. Let’s say you have some notes in some of the cells, and you don’t use text wrapping. One of two things will happen. If there is content present in the adjacent cell to the right, this text will be cropped. If instead there is no content to the right, this text will spill onto multiple cells to the right. A sentence or two may extend as far as seven or eight cells to the right, which does not look good.

Another situation appropriate for text wrapping relates to column headers. If your column headers have text that is wider than its overall column width, this will also be cropped to the right or spill into cells to the right and look bad. Text wrapping will increase the height of that cell, as well as all other cells on the column header row, improving its visual appearance.

While it is possible to wrap text for a single cell, I will do it for all cells in a column. The first thing you should do is manually adjust column width using the steps outlined in the previous section. I will use the example of three inches, which translates to 288 pixels.

Steps are:

1.    Select the column and manually adjust its width to 288 pixels.

2.    Press Alt O to open the Format menu.

3.    Down arrow to the Wrapping submenu, and Right arrow to expand it.

4.    Down arrow to Wrap and press Enter.

12.4.8.3 Hiding and Unhiding Columns and Rows

As mentioned in Chapter 5.9.1 on Excel, in large sheets, using this feature aids efficient navigation by temporarily hiding columns or rows so you can quickly skip over them to get to columns or rows that interest you. I will use the same example as in the Excel chapter on this topic. Let’s say you are working on a spreadsheet with monthly data for an entire year. It is now December, and you want to input data for that month’s bills. You would like to temporarily hide all the columns from January through November. If you do this, only three columns will remain visible: column A with the bill names, column M with December data, and column N with Annual Totals.

Steps for hiding the February through November columns (columns B through L) are:

4.    With your focus anywhere in Column B, hold down the Shift key and Right arrow to select across to column L.

5.    Press Control + Spacebar twice to select these columns.

6.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow twice to Hide, and press Enter.

7.    Down arrow to Hide columns B-L and press Enter.

When you want these columns to reappear, steps for unhiding them are:

4.    With your focus on Column A (the column just to the left of the hidden columns), hold down the Shift key and Right arrow once to column M (the column just to the right of the hidden columns with December data).

5.    Press Control + Spacebar twice to select these two columns.

6.    Press the Applications key, Down arrow to Unhide columns, and press Enter.

Follow a similar process to hide and unhide rows. Selecting multiple rows involves holding down the Shift key, Down arrowing to the last row you want to select, and then pressing Shift + Spacebar twice. After selecting rows, steps for hiding and unhiding them via the Applications key are the same as for columns.

12.4.8.4 Freezing Panes

As mentioned in Chapter 5.10, freezing panes is the sighted equivalent of the Define Name command, or its Google Sheets equivalent, Verbalize to screenreader. If you receive a Google sheet from a collaborator, if you press Control + Home and land somewhere other than cell A1, chances are good that Freeze panes is turned on. For example, if you press Control + Home and land in cell B2, row 1 and column A are probably frozen. To be sure, Up arrow once to cell B1, and if that row is frozen, your screenreader will say, “Inside frozen rows.” Down arrow, and it will say, “Outside frozen rows.” You will receive similar audio feedback for frozen columns when you arrow in and out of them. This audio feedback is a nice feature that you do not get with Excel.

The Freeze submenu is located in the View menu. To access it, press Alt V, Down arrow twice to the Freeze submenu, Right arrow to expand it, and Down arrow through the options, which include:

·         No rows: Press Enter on this to unfreeze all rows. Your screenreader will say, “Unfroze all rows.”

·         One row: Select this to freeze just the current row. For example, if focus is on row 1, only that row will be frozen. You will hear, “Froze one row.”

·         Two rows: Select this to freeze the current row and the one under it. For example, if focus is on row 1, rows 1 and 2 will be frozen. You will hear, “Froze two rows.”

·         No columns: Press Enter on this to unfreeze all columns. Your screenreader will say, “Unfroze all columns.”

·         One column: Select this to freeze just the current column. For example, if focus is on column A, only that column will be frozen. You will hear, “Froze one column.”

·         Two columns: Select this to freeze the current column and the one under it. For example, if focus is on column A, columns A and B will be frozen. You will hear, “Froze two columns.”

12.4.8.5 Realtime Collaboration

Similar to Googledocs, if you are sharing a Google sheet with others, and you all have full editing rights, you can simultaneously edit it. Editing actions of collaborators will be announced. You will be notified when individual collaborators are entering and leaving sheets. If you find the level of verbosity distracting, you can disable these notifications. Steps are:

5.    Open the Tools menu (Alt T).

6.    Up arrow to Accessibility and press Enter.

7.    Tab to the Turn on collaborator announcements checkbox and press the Spacebar to uncheck it (it is on by default).

8.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter.

12.5 Reading Google Slides Presentations

I am not presenting a full description of how to work with Google Slides because, as of the writing of this third edition, it is not accessible for screenreader users to make presentations to audiences. When delivering a presentation in the Slide Show view, only slide titles can be detected by screenreaders, while the Remaining slide content cannot be read. This accessibility shortcoming makes the application pretty much useless for most screenreader users. A possible exception may be skilled Braille users who can type up notes and read them separately in hard copy or on a Braille display as the Slide show advances.

The current workaround is to prepare the presentation with Slides, download it to your computer as a PowerPoint file, and present it with that application. But if PowerPoint is already available to you, the obvious question is why waste your time learning Slides? Spend your time more productively by learning PowerPoint instead.

Google is aware of this fundamental accessibility flaw and hopefully they will fix it sometime in the not too distant future. For this reason,

I limit my discussion to reading a Google Slides presentation if you receive one from others. To do this,, you need to do three things. First, be sure that screenreader support is enabled (Control + Alt + Z), and that Braille support is disabled (Control + Alt + H). If you have used Docs and/or Sheets before, chances are that that both are already enabled. For most other things you do in Slides, Braille Support should be enabled. But to read a presentation, you must disable it. And as with other Google apps, toggle off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor (Insert + Z or the NVDA Browse mode (Insert + Spacebar).

Read the full text of a presentation in the Filmstrip view. The shortcut to open this view is Control + Shift Alt + F, all held down together. If you find this key combination awkward, open it through the Accessibility menu. Press Alt A, Down arrow to Go to Filmstrip, and press Enter. Now Down arrow, Right arrow, or press Page down to go to the next slide where its entire content will be read. Up arrow, Left arrow, or press Page up to go to the previous slide and read it.

12.6 Google Mail, Also Known as Gmail

Google Mail, or Gmail, is the Google equivalent of Outlook. It has several advantages over Outlook. First it is free, so that is a big plus. Second, you can use it on any computer. This can be useful in a pinch when you are not around your own computer, and thus don’t have access to a desktop application like Outlook.

But Gmail has some weaknesses relative to Outlook. Some of the most basic operations like reading and deleting messages, and dealing with attachments require a few more keystrokes than Outlook. While only one or two additional keystrokes per task, if you read and delete lots of messages daily, the numbers quickly add up. Being comfortable with web browsing is a pre-requisite for using Gmail online, while no such knowledge is necessary for using Outlook.

To access the app, go to gmail.com from your web browser. If not signed in already, type in your email address and password. The next time you go there, you will already be logged in.

Some people have several Gmail accounts, or have a work or school account that has been set up in the Google Workspace. I have a personal Gmail account and my Carroll Center work account is also a Google account. If you need to switch between accounts:

1.    Open Gmail.com.

2.    Press B several times to go to the Gmail Account button (which identifies your current account in parentheses). This button is collapsed so press Enter to expand it.

3.    Down arrow to the other account you want to open and press Enter.

4.    This opens a new tab with the Inbox for this account.

If you Down arrow and do not find the account, it may be that you have never logged into it before, or have not done so for a long time. Continue Down arrowing to the Add an account button and press Enter. Here you can type in that account’s address and password to open it.

Continue Down arrowing past the Add and account button where you will find the Sign out of all accounts option. This is useful if you want to assist another person on your computer and need to access their Gmail account. Without first signing yourself out, you cannot access other people’s accounts. Also, if using a computer that is not your own, it is extremely important to sign out when done to protect your privacy.

If you have several accounts, create a desktop shortcut for each account the same way you do it for any web page using the method laid out for creating shortcuts within Google Chrome (see Chapter 7.4.3.1). This way, you can

avoid the cumbersome process of switching accounts every time you open Gmail.

When you open your Inbox page and press Insert + T, the web page title includes the folder name (referred to as “labels” in Gmail), number of unread messages, your Gmail account, the name of the app, and the name of your browser (example: Inbox (20) – david.kingsbury@carroll.org - Gmail - Google Chrome).

12.6.1 Enabling Keyboard Shortcuts, Disabling Conversation Threads, and Changing the Number of Messages Displayed

These are changed in Settings: The first is crucial. The second reduces confusion, and the third depends on personal preference.

Similar to the other Google apps, you can use native Google shortcut keys for quick navigation and initiating tasks like creating and deleting messages. To use these native keystrokes, you must first enable them. You only have to do this once. Steps are:

1.    From the top of the page, press B several times to the Settings button, and press Enter.

2.    Tab to the See all settings button, and press Enter.

3.    Press Control + F with JAWS or Control + Insert + F with NVDA to open the Find dialog, type “keyboard,” and press Enter.

4.    Down arrow to the Keyboard shortcuts On radio button which you would normally press the Spacebar to select it. However, you must press Enter instead to make it stick. Do this, and then Up and Down arrow a few times back to it to be sure it has indeed been selected.

5.    Press Control + F with JAWS or Control + Insert + F with NVDA again, type “save,” and press Enter.

6.    Press Enter on the Save changes button to update settings.

Inbox messages are usually organized in conversation threads by default. If you are like me and find these confusing, you will want to disable them so each message appears by itself. To disable conversation threads:

1.    On this same See all Settings page, press Control + F with JAWS or Control + Insert + F with NVDA, type “conversation view,” and press Enter.

2.    Down arrow to the Conversation view off radio button and press Enter to check it. As above, pressing Spacebar does not seem to work.

3.    Press Control + F with JAWS or Control + Insert + F with NVDA again, type “save,” and press Enter.

4.    Press Enter on the Save changes button to update settings.

The default number of messages displayed in message lists (Inbox, Sent, Drafts, etc.) is 50. To change this:

1.    On the See all Settings page, press Control + F with JAWS or Control + Insert + F with NVDA, type “maximum,” and press Enter. This lands you on “Maximum page size.

2.    Down arrow to the Show combo box and press Enter to open it. Up or Down arrow to your choice. Options are 10, 15,20,25, 50, and 100.

3.    Press Escape on your choice.

4.    Press Control + F with JAWS or Control + Insert + F with NVDA again, type “save,” and press Enter.

12.6.2 Important Keystrokes

When you are ready to use Gmail with the native keystrokes enabled, the first thing you do after opening Gmail is to toggle off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor (Insert + Z), or the NVDA Browse mode (Insert + Spacebar). This must be done every time you start a new Gmail session.

Here is a list of commonly used native Gmail keystrokes:

·         X: From the top of a message folder page (Inbox, Sent, etc.), quickly go to first message in Inbox (X also selects and unselects messages).

·         Down and Up arrow: Go to next and previous message in the Inbox list.

·         Shift + 3: Delete message.

·         Enter: Open message.

·         N: Jump to message body and read in Say all mode.

·         Alt + Left arrow: After reading a message, return to Inbox with focus on the message just read.

·         C: Compose new message.

·         Control + Shift + C: Add CC field.

·         Control + Shift + B: Add BCC field.

·         Control + Enter: Send message.

·         G I: Go to most recent message in Inbox message list.

·         G T: Go to most recent message in sent items message list.

·         G D: Go to drafts.

·         G C: Go to contacts.

·         G N: Go to next page of messages.

·         G P: Go to previous page of messages.

12.6.2 Reading and Deleting Inbox Messages

To navigate through your list of Inbox messages, press G I which lands you on the most recent message at the top of your message list, telling you the message sender, subject, date and time, and a message preview. The letter X is the Google keystroke for selecting messages. This will be important later for at least one reason: selecting multiple messages for deletion.

To open this message, press Enter. To open any subsequent messages in the message list, Down arrow to the message and press Enter. Once opened, press N to get to the body of the message where your screenreader will read in Say all mode. You will hear some of the message header information before hearing body text.

To use standard screenreader keystrokes to read parts of the message (Up and Down arrow to read by line, Right and Left arrow to read by character, etc.), you must first turn the JAWS Virtual PC cursor back on (Insert + Z) or return to NVDA Browse mode (Insert + Spacebar). Note that this does not put focus in the message body, but somewhere higher up on the screen. You will need to Down arrow a number of times to get back to the body text. In my opinion, having to switch cursor modes and then Up or Down arrow a bunch of times to get to where you want to read the message is a major irritant compared to Outlook.

When finished reading the message, and with your JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode off, either press G I to return to the Inbox with focus on the most recent message at the top of the message list, or Alt + Left arrow to return to the Inbox with focus on the message you just opened. This distinction is important. If you have just read the 25th message in your Inbox and now want to navigate to the 26st one, you do not want to return to the top of the Inbox and then have to Down arrow 26 times. But there will also be times when you want to quickly get back to the top of the list to see your most recent message.

To delete one or more messages while in the Inbox:

1.    In the Inbox list, press X on the first message to be deleted (X also unselects).

2.    Down arrow to any other messages to be deleted and press X.

3.    Press Shift + 3.

The messages are moved to Trash. There is no announcement that they have been deleted. Focus lands on the message just below the last one that was deleted.

The default number of messages displayed on a page is 50. This can be changed to a maximum of 100 in Settings. Press G N to go to the next page of messages and G P to go to the previous page. Pressing G I will always move you back to the most recent message in your Inbox. Pressing G T will do the same in the Sent folder.

12.6.3 Composing Messages

To compose a message:

1.    Press C which places focus at the To field.

2.    Address the message to the recipient or recipients (more on addressing messages below).

3.    Neither the CC or BCC fields automatically appear. Press Control + Shift + C to add the CC field and/or Control + Shift + B to add the BCC field. If you forget these keystrokes, you can Shift + Tab back before the To field to find these. Type in addresses.

4.    Tab to the Subject field and type the text.

5.    Tab to the message body and type your message

6.    Press Control + Enter to send the message. You should hear, “message sent.”

Here’s a bit more information on addressing messages to recipients. As you type, addressee names may populate based on your emailing history. If you hear the correct recipient address, press Tab to lock that address in, placing your focus just after that address where you can type in an additional address if you want to send a message to multiple recipients. .

. If you type the first letter or two of the address, you can also Down arrow to find other addressees beginning with those letters and lock them in as above. To confirm you have inserted the correct address or addresses, Left arrow to hear them.

To reply to a message:

1.    Open the message from your Inbox.

2.    Press R to reply to the sender or A to reply to all recipients.

3.    Focus is placed at the top of the message body. Type your message.

4.    Press Control + Enter to send.

To forward a message:

1.    Press F. Focus is placed in the To field, Add recipients here.

2.    Tab to the message body. Type in text if desired.

3.    Press Control + Enter to send the message.

12.6.4 File Attachments

To attach one or more files to a message:

1.    Compose the message.

2.    Within the Compose dialog, Tab past the message body field to the Attach files button and press Enter.

3.    This opens the standard Attach files dialog. Shift + Tab back several times and select one or more files.

4.    Press Enter when done.

5.    Tab once to the Send button and press Enter to send the message.

Regarding attachments you have received, you can download to your Downloads folder, your Google Drive folder, or open in one of the Google apps if it is an appropriate format like a Word, Excel, or PowerPoint file.

To access an attachment you have received:

1.    Open the message.

2.    Press Insert + Z to switch the JAWS Virtual PC cursor on, or Insert + Spacebar to turn on NVDA Browse mode.

3.    Press G to quickly get to the Attachments graphic.

4.    From here, Down arrow or press B to get to one of the following three buttons and press Enter to activate your choice:

a.    Download button: Download to your Downloads folder.

b.    Add to Google Drive button: Add the file to Google Drive.

c.    Edit button: If the file is compatible with one of the Google apps, such as Microsoft Word, Excel or PowerPoint, open and edit it in Docs, Sheets, or Slides, respectively. As soon as you open the file, it will automatically be saved in Google Drive.

If you have received multiple attachments, you can access each of the individual files with the same choices as above. There will also be a Download all attachments button. Activating this will download a ZIP file to your Downloads folder. Its name will include the subject line of the message you received.

12.6.5 Some Other Actions

Folders are called “labels” in Gmail parlance. To access labels, use the following native shortcuts with your JAWS Virtual PC cursor and NVDA Browse mode off:

·         G I: Go to Inbox.

·         G T: Go to sent items.

·         G D: Go to drafts.

·         G C: Go to contacts.

Any message that you have not sent is automatically saved as a draft. You can press G D to go to the Drafts folder, complete it and then send it. Also go here to periodically delete drafts you no longer want. Because of this autosave behavior, there is a strong likelihood that you will save lots of unintended drafts. Therefore, it is a good idea to clean out this folder from time to time so you can more easily find the drafts you actually want to complete and send.

There is no quick key combination to go to the Trash folder. But you can access it by typing GL TRASH, and pressing Enter. GL provides a list of labels, but Down arrowing does not reveal Trash, so you must type it.

In the Trash folder, you can return a deleted message to your Inbox by Down arrowing to the message, pressing the Applications key, Down arrowing to Return to inbox menu, and pressing Enter.

12.6.6 Other Useful Gmail Features

Here are a couple of Gmail features that you can use in complimentary fashion with Outlook if that is your primary email client.

12.6.6.1 Accessing Gmail Contacts and Exporting Them to Outlook

When you have had correspondence with a person, their email address is automatically entered into your list of contacts. To access and edit them, go to: contacts.google.com.

There is a single heading on this page indicating how many contacts you have. Down arrow through them to hear the person’s name and email address. There is a checkbox before each contact for selecting them. You can then Tab to an Edit button, press Enter, and add some information like, company name, phone number and a few others.

Only about twenty contacts are listed on this preliminary page. You can search for individual contacts by toggling off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or the NVDA Browse mode. Then press Slash, type in the contact name, and press Enter to find one or more search results.

Perhaps the best way to get a full list of your contacts is to download a comma separated values (CSV) file to your computer. Steps are:

1.    From the top of the page and with the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or the NVDA Browse mode on, press X to get to the checkbox for the first contact, and press the Spacebar to select it.

2.    Up arrow a few times to the Selection actions button and press Enter.

3.    Toggle the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or the NVDA Browse mode off.

4.    Down arrow to All and press Enter to select all contacts.

5.    Press Enter on the More actions button.

6.    Down arrow to Export and press Enter.

7.    A list of download options appears, including: Google CSV, Outlook CSV, and vCard (for iOS Contacts). Up or Down arrow to your choice. Choose the Google CSV or Outlook CSV option if you simply want a spreadsheet with the contacts listed.

8.    Tab to the Export button, and press Enter.

9.    Navigate to your Downloads folder to access the file.

10. Open the CSV file in either Excel or Googlesheets.

There will be far more columns than interest you, but you can find contact names, organizations and email addresses without any difficulty in this CSV file.

If you download an Outlook CSV file, you can import them into Outlook. This is useful if you have just added Outlook to a new computer, or want to supplement current Outlook contacts with the fuller list of Gmail contacts accumulated over time.

Before doing this, you need to delete most of the CSV file columns, keeping just the First name, Last Name, Email address, and perhaps the Company and Job title columns. There are three different email address columns. Just keep the first one and delete the other two. Then save the updated CSV file.

To bring these contacts into Outlook:

1.    Open Outlook, press Alt + F to open the File menu, Down arrow to Open and export, and press Enter.

2.    Down arrow to Import/export and press Enter.

3.    Down arrow to Import from another program or file, and press Enter.

4.    In the Import a file dialog, press Enter on Comma separated values.

5.    Tab to the Browse button and press Enter.

6.    Shift + Tab back to the standard list box and tree view to locate the CSV file, and press Enter on it.

7.    Tab to a set of three radio buttons and Up or Down arrow to your choice: Replace duplicates with items imported, Allow duplicates to be created, and Do not import duplicate items. The third radio button is probably your best choice if you think that your current Outlook contacts are pretty much up to date and don’t want them replaced.

8.    Tab to the Next button and press Enter.

9.    In the Select destination folder: Tree view, press C until you get to Contacts, and press Enter.

10. Tab to the Finish button and press Enter.

All the imported contacts should now appear in your Outlook Contacts folder.

12.6.6.2 The Vacation Responder

You have probably received auto-reply messages from people when they are on vacation. Here are the steps for preparing such messages with the Gmail Vacation Responder feature:

1.    Open gmail.com.

2.    With the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or NVDA Browse mode remaining on, press B several times to go to the Settings button, and press Enter.

3.    Down arrow to the See all settings button, and press Enter. If you don’t find it, try tabbing instead.

4.    Search for “vacation” to find the text “Vacation responder.”

5.    Down arrow to the two radio buttons for Vacation responder On and Off, and select the On radio button.

6.    Down arrow to the First day edit field, delete all prefilled text, and type in the first day in MM/DD/YYYY format, and press Enter. Be sure to type it in exactly this way. It does not seem very flexible.

7.    Down arrow the Fixed end date checkbox, and check it if there is a fixed end date.

8.    Down arrow to the End date edit field, and type it in the same way as in the Start date field.

9.    Down arrow to the Subject edit field, and type in something like: “Out of Office Reply.”

10. After this field, there is a long list of formatting buttons. Press E to quickly jump past these to the Vacation responder edit field and press Enter to get into it.

11. This is the message body that recipients will see for the duration of your vacation. Provide information about the start and end dates of your vacation, and who to contact while you are away. When finished, press Escape.

12. Press B to go to the Save button and press Enter. You will be redirected to your Inbox page.

12.7 Google Calendar

The Google Calendar is a nice alternative to the Outlook Calendar. It has several advantages over the Outlook Calendar, including:

·         It is free, the only requirement being to have a Gmail account.

·         It is quick and easy to learn. With just a handful of keystrokes, most of which are intuitive and easy to remember, you can handle all basic event scheduling and editing functions.

·         Screenreader verbosity is minimal. By contrast, I find Outlook annoyingly verbose.

To access the Google Calendar, open a new tab in your browser, type “calendar.google.com,” minus the quotes, and press Enter. You may need to log in with your Gmail account the first time, but your browser usually remembers you in subsequent sessions. If you are going to use the Google Calendar with any frequency, create a desktop shortcut for this web page using the steps outlined in Chapter 7.4.3.

12.7.1 Calendar Navigation

As with other Google Workspace apps, turn off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor with Insert + Z, or the NVDA Browse mode with Insert + Spacebar so that you can use native Google keystrokes. Below is a list of the native keystrokes I consider most essential for navigation

·         T: Today view.

·         A: agenda view.

·         G: Go to date.

·                           D: Day view

·         W: Week view

·         M: Month view

·         P or K: Previous period, depending on your current view (for example, if in Day view, previous day, if in Month view, previous month, etc.).

·         N or J: Next period, depending on your current view (for example, if in Day view, next day, if in Month view, next month, etc.).

·         After opening the Google Calendar and turning off the JAWS Virtual PC cursor or the NVDA Browse mode, press T and then A to place the Calendar in the Agenda view for today. In the Agenda view, Down and Up arrow from event to event, and Right and Left arrow to the next and previous day, respectively. Days without scheduled events will be skipped over.

·         You can also press G which opens the Go to date edit combo box. You can manually type in the date you want to navigate to, using the MM/DD/YY format. This edit combo box is pretty smart.
