To see the array of choices, after navigating to the Accessibility category and pressing Enter, Tab to the Screenreader alerts list box. Then Down arrow through the choices and check or uncheck as desired. Press Escape when finished.

13.4 Scheduling, Hosting, and Recording Zoom Meetings

Managing meetings involves scheduling through the desktop app, inviting participants, and hosting. You will also want to know how to record meetings. Because of the 40 minute time limit on free accounts, if you plan on regularly hosting meetings, you will want to have access to a pro account.

You can initiate instant meetings, as well as schedule meetings for later. I will start with instant meetings.

13.4.1 Instant Meetings

Steps for starting an instant meeting are:

1.    Open the desktop Zoom app, and press Control + Tab until you get to the Home tab

2.    Tab to the Start a new meeting with video off button, and press Enter. This brings you into the active meeting window. For the moment, you are the only participant.

3.    To invite others, Tab to the Meeting Information button and press Enter.

4.    Tab to the Copy Link button and press Enter.

5.    Prepare an email to invitees, paste the link into the message body, and send it.

When invitees activate the link, this will bring them into the meeting. After the meeting is concluded, the link is no longer valid.

13.4.2 Scheduled Meetings

In September 2024, Zoom introduced a merged calendar feature that made the process of managing meetings (scheduling, starting, etc.) extremely complicated and frustrating, at least for screenreader users. Disable this feature to make the processes for scheduling and managing meetings more tolerable. Steps are:

1.    Sign into your Zoom account at: https://zoom.us/signin#/login

2.    Activate the Visit Settings link.

3.    Open the Mail and Calendar tab. JAWS users can press the apostrophe key to navigate by tab, and then pressing Enter on the one they want to open.

4.    Open the Meetings tab.

5.    Press H to go to the Merge Meetings and Calendar tabs heading.

6.    Down arrow to the Merge Meetings and Calendar tabs toggle button and press Enter to toggle it off. Your screenreader should say, “Your settings have been updated.”

Now that the Merge calendars feature has been disabled, steps for scheduling a meeting are:

1.    Open the Zoom app from your desktop, and Control + Tab several times to the Meetings tab.

2.    Tab to the Schedule meeting button, and press Enter.

3.    You first land on Schedule meeting. You can Down arrow to two other choices: schedule from Outlook and schedule from Google Calendar. We will stick with the first choice: Schedule meeting. Press Enter on this.

4.    You land in an edit field prefilled with the text “Topic [your account name] Zoom Meeting.” Type over this with the title of your meeting.

5.    Tab to the Start date edit combo box, prefilled with today’s date. To change the date, press the Spacebar which opens a date picker grid. Right arrow to move forward day by day, or Down arrow to move forward one week. Press the Spacebar on your choice.

6.    Tab to the Start time edit combo box, prefilled with a time 30 minutes ahead of the current time. Type in the desired start time, being sure to add a colon and AM or PM, as in 1:30PM. AM and PM can be upper or lower case.

7.    Tab to the End time edit combo box, prefilled with a time 30 minutes after the start time you just inserted. Fill this in the same way as you did for the start time.

8.    The next tab is the Recurring meeting checkbox which is unchecked by default. Leave it unchecked and see below for an easy way to schedule them.

9.    The next tab is for the time zone. This is automatically set using your computer’s clock.

10. Tab to the Waiting room checkbox. For Pro accounts this is unchecked by default, but may be checked for free accounts. Unless you have an explicit reason for wanting a waiting room and you are comfortable managing them, uncheck this checkbox.

11. Tab to the Calendar radio button which initially lands on the Outlook calendar. Up or Down arrow to the Other calendars radio button to select this if you do not want to schedule meetings in the Outlook or Google calendar environment. This is my preference. After you do this the first time, it tends to remain there for subsequent meetings that you schedule.

12. Tab to the Advanced meeting options dropdown. Usually you will not change any of these settings, but press the Spacebar to expand. You can tab through the various checkboxes which include: Allow participants to join anytime; Mute participants upon entry; Automatically record meeting on the local computer; and Approve or block entry for users from specific countries/regions.

13. Tab to the Save button and press Enter.

After activating the Save button, your screenreader usually indicates that the meeting has been scheduled, and that you can Tab a few times to copy the invitation to the Clipboard. You are now ready to invite participants to your meeting. You can do this immediately, or wait until later.

For a long time now, gaining proper focus at this point has been inconsistent. Tabbing a few times may only result in silence, or may behave properly. If you Tab and only hear silence, press Escape a few times, or even Alt + F4 which may or may not close the Zoom desktop app. One way or another, you eventually gain proper focus so that you can do the following:

1.    Tab several times to the Copy meeting invitation information button and press Enter to place this information on the Clipboard.

2.    Open Outlook or whatever other email application you are using and prepare a message, entering the participant email addresses in the To field, and meaningful text in the Subject field.

3.    In the message body field, press Control + V to paste the meeting information there. This includes: name of the person or account holder sending out the invitation, start time, topic, URL, meeting ID, and meeting passcode. If you are using a pro account, a list of phone numbers are also listed that can be used by those joining the meeting via telephone.

4.    Send the message to your invitees.

If you would prefer to send out invitations closer to the meeting date, steps are:

1.    Open the Zoom app from the desktop.

2.    Press Control + Tab to get to the Meetings tab.

3.    Tab to the Meeting topics list, Down arrow to the meeting and press Enter or the Spacebar to select it.

4.    Repeat steps one through four above for preparing and sending an email message to invitees.

It is also possible to integrate the scheduling and invitation processes with the Outlook and Google calendars. These topics will not be covered here.

You can also delete or edit meetings that you have scheduled. To do this, select the meeting using the steps above. Tab to either the Delete or Edit button, and press Enter. If deleting, Tab through the steps to confirm the deletion. I usually don’t bother deleting meetings I have scheduled for specific times, instead just allowing them to expire at midnight of the scheduled day. However, I do take the time to delete recurrent meetings that I no longer need.

To edit a scheduled meeting, Tab through the various fields in the dialog to change the topic, date, time, and/or duration. When finished, Tab to the Save button and press Enter to preserve your changes.

What is the validity of a Zoom link if scheduled for a specific date and time? The link can be used from the moment it is created until midnight of the scheduled day. For example, if it is now May 10 at 1:00 PM and I schedule a meting for May 15 at 3:00 PM, I can use that link any time from now until midnight on May 15, and for as many times as I want until then.

This brings me to the topic of scheduling recurring meetings. I find that checking the Recurring Meeting checkbox mentioned above and carrying out the associated steps is overly complicated for screenreader users. Fortunately there is a much easier way. Given that links associated with start dates are valid until midnight of the specified dates, I simply set start dates that are either the final date of the planned recurrence or a few days past it. To remind invitees and myself that this is what I have done, I include this information in the meeting title. For example, I may set the start date as December 1, 2024 and entitle the meeting as, “Acme Board Meeting (Starts the First Monday of Evry month at 10 AM, Link Valid Thru November 2024).

I understand that Zoom links may be valid for a maximum of 365 days, so to be safe, I don’t schedule recurring meetings beyond this. I instead schedule a new meeting and reinvite participants when the earlier one has expired.

13.4.3 Hosting Meetings

Meetings hosted by persons with free accounts have a 40 minute time limit. They then abruptly end. While the meeting link still works, the host is required to restart the meeting and all participants will need to rejoin. Unless you know that an upcoming meeting will be quite short, you will want to schedule and host meetings with a pro account. If you are a meeting participant, time limitations are a function of the host’s account type, not your own account type.

As a participant, you join the meeting by activating the link in the email sent to you by the host. When hosting, you start the meeting through the Zoom app on your PC, either in the Meetings tab or the Home tab. Steps for starting a meeting you are hosting from within the Meetings tab are:

1.    Open the Zoom app from your desktop.

2.    Press Control + Tab to get to the Meetings tab.

3.    Tab to the Meeting topic list (one tab past the Schedule meeting button), and Down arrow to the meeting you want to start. If there is more than one meeting in the list, you must press Enter or Spacebar to select it.

4.    Tab to the Start button and press Enter.

This opens the Zoom meeting window. You are now in your meeting. Hopefully, the participants will begin showing up soon.

Steps for starting a meeting you are hosting from within the Home tab are:

1.    Open the Zoom app from your desktop.

2.    Press Control + Tab to get to the Home tab.

3.    Tab to the Join button.

4.    You land in a list box where you Down arrow through your scheduled meetings. You will hear the meeting topic and meeting ID.

5.    Press Enter on the meeting you want to start.

6.    Tab to an edit field where you can type in your name if it is not already there.

7.    Tab to the Don’t connect to audio check box and make sure it is not checked.

8.    Tab to the Turn off my video and check or uncheck as desired.

9.    Tab to the Join Button and press Enter.

10. You should then hear “connecting.” If all goes well, you have now started your meeting.

As a host, you have a wide latitude of options for managing individual participants, as well as for managing the entire group. The Participants panel, accessed with Alt U, is very important for hosting meetings. From here, you can check on participant status, as well as manage individuals or all participants.

When you navigate to the Participants list, you will hear the number of participants in your meeting. However, I have not found that identification of the number of meeting participants is consistent. Sometimes you hear it, sometimes you don’t. This may occur if the number of participants rapidly changes as people join the meeting. Down arrow through the list to hear the name or phone number, and status of each participant. Participant status items include muted/unmuted, video on/off, host or co-host, hand raised, screen sharing, and recording locally or to the cloud.

Meeting participants appear in the following order in this list:

1.    You. Press Home from anywhere in the list to quickly return to the top of the list to check your own status.

2.    Hosts and co-hosts.

3.    Unmuted participants (sorted alphabetically).

4.    Muted participants (sorted alphabetically).

5.    Phone numbers with no names.

When participants raise their hands, they are moved directly below the host in the list order. Once their hands are lowered, they return to their original position in the list.

To manage an individual participant, first Down arrow in the Participants list to that person. If the person’s hand is raised, Tab once to the Lower hand button and press Enter to lower their hand. If the person’s hand is not raised, the first Tab is Mute/unmute the participant.

Tab again to the More options for (participant name) button dropdown. Press Enter or the Spacebar to expand the dropdown. Down arrow through the options. I have not listed all of them, but among the most important are:

·         Chat: Press Enter to open an edit field, type in your chat text, and press Enter to send the chat to this individual.

·         Make host: Transfer hosting responsibilities to somebody else. Press Enter once, and Enter again to confirm.

·         Make co-host: Same steps as for hosting. Only available for pro accounts.

·         Rename: Press Enter, type in a new name, and press Enter. This is often done for participants calling in by phone to give them a recognizable name. You as host might also rename yourself if you are hosting from one of your organization’s pro accounts. For example, my Carroll Center pro account name is “CCBZoom7.” I rename myself so participants know who I am.[26]

·         Allow to record local files: Participants must ask for the host’s permission to record. This is where hosts do this.

·         Put in waiting room: Temporarily remove a participant from the meeting, and come back here to bring them back into the meeting.

·         Remove: Hopefully, you will never be bothered by unruly and abusive “Zoom bombers.” But if you are, this is where you eject them from the meeting. They cannot return to the meeting with the same username.

·         Report: You can report abusive participants to Zoom so that the company can block or cancel their accounts.

Continue tabbing to the More options to manage all participants button dropdown, and press Enter or the Spacebar to expand it. Down arrow through the options which are checked or unchecked, depending on current status. Press the Spacebar to enable or disable them. These include:

·         Ask all to unmute.

·         Mute participants upon entry. This may be done to guard against audio that can disrupt speakers.

·         Allow participants to unmute themselves. Hosts may disable this to prevent unintended disturbances from people who are unaware that they are unmuted.

·         Allow participants to rename themselves.

·         Play sound when someone joins or leaves: Hosts may find this chime disruptive, especially after a meeting is in full swing. I often turn it off a few minutes into the meeting.

·         Enable waiting room: Hosts often keep people in the waiting room in the few minutes before a meeting begins to check that audio and video is working properly.

·         Lock meeting: You can close the meeting to new entrants. For example, to instill discipline about timeliness, a teacher might require that all students be in the meeting no later than ten minutes after the scheduled start time. Anybody attempting to join after that interval would be blocked from joining.

As host, you can also mute all participants by pressing Alt M.

13.4.4 Recording Meetings

With a free account, you can record meetings that are then downloaded to your computer. This is referred to as “recording locally.” With a pro account, you can record locally, as well as upload recordings to the Cloud. I will limit my discussion to local recordings.

When recording, both audio and video files are generated. Hosts and co-hosts can make recordings. Participants must be granted permission. See the previous section on how a host does this.

Making recordings is easy. You only need to know two keystrokes:

·         Alt R: Start and end a local recording.

·         Alt P: Pause and resume recording.

Zoom will inform participants that the meeting is being recorded, as well as when the recording has been ended. Participants who wish to unmute themselves and speak need to Tab to and press Enter on the Got it button to acknowledge they are aware that the meeting is being recorded.

You can go to the Participants panel to see who is doing the recording.

Recordings are only available after a meeting has ended. If you have initiated a recording, you will be informed that the meeting is being converted when you leave the meeting. Your screenreader will indicate percentages during conversion. This can take a long time. For long meetings (one hour or more), the audio and video files are quite large. Your Wi-Fi speed and amount of screen sharing are also variables. In my experience, file conversion has sometimes taken as long as 30 minutes. However, you can be doing other things on your computer at the same time. Just make sure that you keep your computer powered on long enough for the conversion to finish.

By default, recordings are saved in a folder called “Zoom” located in your Documents folder. If you are signed into OneDrive, the default download folder will appear in the Document subfolder of your OneDrive folder. If you are not sure where it is located, find it as follows:

1.    Open the Zoom app from your desktop.

2.    Control + Tab to the Home tab.

3.    Tab several times to the Setting button (just after the account dropdown button), and press Enter.

4.    Tab once to the list of Categories.

5.    Down arrow to Recording and press Enter.

6.    Tab once to hear the file path. It will say something like, “Local Recording, Store my recordings at: C:\Users\your user account name\ Documents\Zoom.

7.    In the Zoom folder, recordings are saved in subfolders for each meeting. The subfolder name is composed of: a time stamp for the meeting (date and time); the meeting name given by the host; and the meeting ID number. The following files are found in each meeting subfolder:

·         An audio file formatted as M4A, with a title beginning with the word “audio” and followed by a bunch of numbers.

·         Chat.txt: If there were any chats during the meeting, this plain text file with the list of chats appears.

·         playback.m3u: a playlist file for playing all individual MP4 files of the meeting. You will rarely, if ever, use this file.

·         A video file formatted as MP4, with a title beginning with the word “video” and followed by a bunch of numbers.

As mentioned above, for long meetings, these will be large files, especially the video files. When I want to share them with other people, I first rename them and then share them via Dropbox without granting editing rights (see Chapter11.1.2.1).

Even when using a pro account, I prefer to save recordings locally. For recordings saved online with pro accounts, the host receives an email with a link to the web page from where recordings can be downloaded. However, you might not have that email address loaded into your email client. For example, the email for my work account is CCBZoom7@carroll.org. I have no interest in adding this account to my Outlook only for this purpose, so I only do local recordings.

13.5 Important Settings That Can Only Be Changed Online

As mentioned above, not all settings can be changed in the desktop Zoom app. The full array of settings can only be changed online, and several of these may be important to you. You can access your online settings by activating the following link and logging in with your Zoom email and password:

Sign In - Zoom

You can get to this same login page through the PC desktop app as follows:

1.    Open the Zoom app from your desktop, and Control + Tab to the Home tab.

2.    Tab several times to the dropdown button with your account name on it, Down arrow to My Profile, and press Enter.

3.    Log into your Zoom account.

To access your account settings, use the Find command (Control + F with JAWS, or Control + Insert + F with NVDA or Narrator), type in “settings,” and press Enter. You land on Settings menu. Press Enter. The most important settings that can only be enabled and disabled online are Chat, Screen share, and certain types of sounds heard when participants join and leave meetings. Press H a number of times to get to these headings (some are level 3 headings, others are level fours). Under each of these is a brief description of the setting, and a toggle for enabling and disabling it.

13.5.1 Chat

Here you can allow meeting and webinar participants to send chat messages (note that if you disable this, the following two options will no longer appear).

·         Private chat: Allow meeting participants to send direct messages to other participants and allow webinar panelists to send direct messages to other panelists.

·         Auto saving chats: Automatically save all in-meeting chats so that hosts do not need to manually save the text of the chat after the meeting starts.

13.5.2 Screen sharing

Here you can allow host and participants to share their screen or content during meetings. If this is disabled, participants will need to be switched to host or co-host status before they can share their screens.

13.5.3 Sound Notifications

Two types of sound notifications exist for announcing when a person enters or leaves a meeting: a chime for those entering via their Zoom account on a computer or smartphone, and an audio recording announcing names of people entering or leaving who are calling in by landline phone. Both can be disruptive. The announcement for landline callers is especially distracting, and can become intolerable in large meetings. The chime can be turned off in the Other Participants dropdown during meetings. The landline announcement can only be turned off in online settings. To adjust online sound settings:

1.    Navigate to the level 4 heading: Sound notification when someone joins or leaves.

2.    Down arrow once to the toggle button. If you leave it unpressed, no sound notifications will be made.

3.    If you press the toggle on, Down arrow to Play sound for, and press the Spacebar on either of the following two radio buttons:

a.    Everyone: The chime sound can be heard by the host and all meeting participants. Note that the host and participants will hear a chime and telephone recording regardless of what audio device they are using.

b.    Host and co-hosts: The chime sound can only be heard by the meeting host or co-hosts.

4.    Continue Down arrowing to the level 4 heading entitled “When someone joins by phone.” Under this, I strongly recommend that you uncheck the Ask to record their voice to use as the notification checkbox. It can be extremely disruptive during meetings.

5.    If you have made any modifications, also press the Save button just below this checkbox to update your settings.

Other settings that you may prefer to make the default here, but can also change in the desktop app settings, are:

·         Participants video: Start meetings with participant video on. Participants can change this during the meeting.

·         Allow participants to join before host: Allow participants to join the meeting before the host arrives

·         Mute all participants when they join a meeting: Automatically mute all participants when they join the meeting. The host controls whether participants can unmute themselves.

·         Email Notification: When attendees join meeting before host

13.6 Additional Considerations

13.6.1 Generating AI Summaries

For those with Pro accounts, Zoom introduced a feature for creating written meeting summaries in 2023. These are emailed to the host after the meeting is over, and consist of a short meeting summary, detailed notes, and a listing of decisions taken. Who said what is also noted.

At least for now, these summaries contain lots of inaccuracies and should never be considered definitive. Nor are they intended to substitute for transcripts. Nevertheless, they can be a valuable aid for creating minutes and refreshing memories on what was discussed.

Only hosts can initiate AI summaries. Steps are:

1.   With focus in the Meeting Controls or Zoom Meeting window, Tab a number of times to the More meeting controls button menu and press Enter.

2.    Down arrow to Start Summary and press Enter. You will hear “Meeting Summary with AI Companion is on,” which is misleading, because it has not yet been activated.

3.    Tab once to hear the following explanation of the feature: “Meeting Summary uses AI technology, which may include third-party models. Zoom does not use any audio, video, chat, screen sharing, attachments or other communications-like content (such as poll results, whiteboard and reactions) to train Zoom’s or third-party AI models.  We’ll send the meeting summary to invitees after the meeting ends (based on the settings configured for this meeting). Anyone who receives the meeting summary may save and share it with apps and others. The account owner can access the meeting summary.  AI-generated content may be inaccurate or misleading. Always check for accuracy.”

4.    Tab to the Got it button and press Enter to truly start the summary.

5.    Several minutes after the meeting has been ended, go to the email inbox associated with the Zoom account where you should be able to find the message with the meeting summary. Note that if this has been a long meeting, it may take as much as 15 or 20 minutes for the email to arrive.

At any time during the meeting, you can go back to the same place to stop the summary . After stopping it, you will hear “Meeting Summary is off.”

13.6.2 Keeping Track of Your Zoom Meetings in the Outlook and Google Calendars

If you are receiving lots of Zoom invitations, keeping track of them can be a big challenge. You may have had the unsettling experience of frantically plowing through your inbox to find a Zoom invitation for a meeting that is starting in just one or two minutes. In Outlook, you can do a couple of things to avoid such unpleasantness. Either create a custom folder called “Zoom Meetings” and move all your meeting notification messages there, or better yet, put them in your Outlook or Google Calendar. If you are comfortable using either of these calendars, it is preferable to transfer them there because you will receive a notification shortly before the meeting. And if one of these calendars is synced with your smartphone, you will receive the notification there too. If you simply put the message in a custom folder, you will need to figure out some way to remember when it starts.

To create a custom folder in Outlook and copy or move messages there, see Chapter 4.4.1.

The Outlook and Google calendars are covered in Chapter 4.8 and Chapter 12.6, respectively. Step-by-step instructions will not be repeated here. Instead, discussion here is limited to ways to access links for joining meetings when you have saved them in one of these Calendars.

If Zoom meeting notifications are sent to you as calendar invitations, all you need to do to transfer the invitation to your calendar is to focus on the message in your inbox, press the Applications key, Down arrow to Accept, and press Enter.

Meeting organizers often place the URL for the Zoom link in the Location field in the Calendar’s meeting dialog. These are not active links. To retrieve them:

1.    Navigate to the meeting in your Outlook Calendar folder (remember to Tab to it, not Down arrow), and press Enter.

2.    Tab or Shift + Tab to the Location edit combo box.

3.    Press the Home key to be sure you are at the start of the edit combo box, press Control + A to select the URL, and then press Control + C to copy it to the Clipboard.

4.    Open your browser. Assuming you land in a new tab, paste in the URL by pressing Control + V, and then press Enter to join the meeting.

If instead the meeting organizer places the link in the body of the email message inviting you, the URL can be activated directly from the text field in the Meeting dialog in your Calendar folder. The URL will open in your default web browser.

If you receive a Zoom invitation, but it is not sent as a Calendar invitation, you will need to manually copy and paste the URL in your Calendar folder. Create an appointment using the steps in Chapter 4.8.2. You can then paste the URL in the Location edit combo box or in the body of the edit field in this dialog. When it is time to join the meeting, follow the steps listed above to access the URL.

13.6.3 Visual Considerations, Including Tools for Centering your Face With the Video Camera

For sighted people, Zoom is primarily a visual medium. Blind folks, myself included, sometimes forget this. Keep the following in mind:

·         Add a picture to your profile. Everybody is expected to have an image of themselves on-file. You can do this from the Settings menu.

·         In meetings where the majority of participants are sighted, video will usually be turned on. To verify, Down arrow through the Participants list and you will see that most people have their video turned on.

·         Before turning on your own video, be sure that the background in your room is not cluttered and that nothing embarrassing is within camera range. Dress appropriately from at least the waist up. You might also opt to use a virtual background. These can be added in your Zoom desktop app settings.

·         For evening meetings, remember to turn the lights on in your room.

·         Be sure you know where your computer’s built-in camera is located. For most laptops, it is in the top center above your screen, but don’t just assume this. Also be sure that the camera is angled correctly to capture your face.

A couple of tools exist to aid you in centering your face in the camera lens.

First, Vispero introduced a great feature called Face in View with JAWS 2024. You can use it to check your video appearance during remote meetings. It is quickly activated and easy to use, thus addressing the vexing problem of wondering whether or not you are properly positioned in front of your camera.

To open Face in View, use the layered keystroke Insert and Spacebar together, followed by F and then O. You will hear if your face is centered and what your brightness level is. Use this same keystroke combination to close it. Do this before you get into meetings, or when you are in meetings, but with your video turned off. It will not function while video is on because it needs access to the camera to get its bearings. For a full discussion of Face In View, see Chapter 1.2.4.3.

Second, you can download a free app called “Can You See Me” at:

Can You See Me: because sometimes it's just easier to ask a robot!

It is very easy to use. Just open it, attempt to center your face relative to your computer’s camera and press Enter. You will hear your face’s position relative to the left, right, top and bottom of the webcam. “Towards the top and in the middle" is a good result. If lighting is insufficient, this will also be indicated. When satisfied, exit the app by pressing the Escape key.

13.6.4 Participating in Zoom Webinars

As mentioned earlier in this chapter, free and pro accounts are the two most common Zoom account types. User interfaces are pretty much the same for participants in meetings hosted by people with these types of accounts. However, you will notice several important differences if you join a Zoom webinar meeting.

In Zoom webinars, there are two categories of meeting invitees - panelists and participants. Prior to the webinar, hosts send separate invitations with different links to those they have grouped in these two categories. If the host categorizes you as a participant, you will not be allowed to unmute yourself before first being asked to do so by the host. Nor will you be able to access the Participants list. Panelists can mute and unmute themselves whenever they wish. They are also able to view lists of panelists and participants.

The iPhone app interface is also different for participants. The More button does not appear, and the Raise hand button is found on the main screen of the meeting.

13.6.5 Zoom on the iPhone

Many people prefer participating in meetings using their smartphones rather than their computers. However, you should probably avoid hosting meetings on your iPhone. Experienced hosts counsel not to do this because it is difficult to manage participants using this interface.

Download the Zoom app from the App Store and log into it with your email address and password. To join a meeting:

1.    Double tap on the link in the email sent by the host to your email app on your iPhone.

2.    You may first land on a screen with the prompt “To hear others, please join audio.” Double tap on the Wi-Fi or cellular data button to join the meeting.

3.    If the meeting is being recorded, you will be informed of this. Double tap on the Got it button to be able to unmute yourself during the meeting.

For participating in meetings, the iPhone app has an easy-to-use interface. From the top of the screen, the most important elements of the iPhone meeting screen are as follows”

·         The active speaker’s video or avatar. An avatar is a graphical representation of a participant, such as their profile picture. An avatar is displayed when the currently speaking participant (or host) has their video turned off.

·         Leave button: Double tap to leave the meeting.

·         Mute/unmute my audio button: Double tap to toggle your microphone on/off. Keep it toggled off if you are not speaking. Also keep in mind that if you are unmuted and move the phone around in your hand, other participants could hear this and it would be disruptive.

·         Start/stop my video button: Double tap to toggle your video on and off.

·         Participants button: Double tap to bring up the Participants screen. Flick right or left to see who else is in the meeting and their current status (muted/unmuted, hand raised, etc.). Double tap on the Close button at the top left to return to the main meeting screen.

·         More button: Double tap to see additional options such as Chat and Raise hand.[27]

13.7 Tips for Conducting Successful Zoom Meetings

Since the advent of the pandemic, numerous lessons have been learned about how to conduct Zoom meetings. Here are a few of the most important ones for participants and hosts.

As a meeting participant, commit to memory the keystrokes listed in Chapter 13.1 above. The most important of these being Alt A for muting/unmuting, Alt U for navigating to the Participants list, and Alt Y for raising and lowering your hand. To save yourself lots of Alt + Tabbing to get back to the active meeting window, adjust your settings to make the Alt A and Alt U keystrokes into universal shortcuts. To save yourself additional Alt + Tabbing, the Shift + Control + Alt + Keystroke quickly returns you to the active meeting window.

Develop a healthy paranoia about whether you are muted or not, frequently double-checking your status in the Participants list. When not speaking or anticipating doing so soon, keep yourself muted.

To safeguard against others hearing your screenreader when you are typing or when notifications arrive, use headphones. If you are unmuted, sometimes others will hear your screenreader, sometimes they won’t. This varies. But if waring headphones, they will never hear your screenreader, unless you are sharing your computer audio.

Also regarding headphones, to ensure good audio, use headsets with a good microphone. Ask some of those meeting participants whose audio sounds especially good to recommend hardware to you.

Here’s a tip it might be better for me not to mention. I like to have Audio ducking switched on, particularly during long and sometimes boring meetings. When the topic being discussed doesn’t interest me, I mute myself and tidy up my inbox or take care of other chores. Audio ducking enables me to hear my screenreader at full volume while the Zoom speakers temporarily recede into the background. Although Audio ducking works on your iPhone, you can multitask in this way more easily on your computer.

Sighted people love to chat during Zoom meetings. Many blind people can’t stand this because the constant screenreader verbiage drives them crazy. While the bulk of chat is, well, just that, fairly meaningless “chit-chat,” some of it conveys useful information. URL’s to relevant web pages are often posted. I have attended the occasional meeting where hosts did a good job of integrating chat comments and questions into the general discussion.

Check through the chat listings periodically during meetings. Use either the Save chat command or JAWS Speech History (see Chapter 13.5.1) to capture chats that you want to retain. The JAWS Alt Windows S keystroke is also a good friend for disabling alerts and silencing chat whenever it gets too distracting.

When hosting larger meetings involving lowering participant hands and/or managing chats, assign responsibility for meeting facilitation to a different person than the Zoom host. If the meeting chairperson or facilitator also attempts to host the Zoom meting, he or she will soon be overwhelmed juggling these tasks.

Also for large meetings, and especially for meetings of relatively long duration, consider adding co-hosts. Sometimes the combined responsibilities of monitoring raised hands, chat, and keeping people muted can be too much. Dividing up these chores can result in smoother meetings and reduce stress.

Start any important meeting you are hosting at least ten to fifteen minutes early to check that there are no audio, video, or connectivity glitches. For similar reasons, arrive early if you plan on being a presenter.

At the start of meetings, inform participants of the “rules of engagement.” Remind them to mute themselves when they are not speaking so that extraneous noise is minimized. Let them know if they can intervene simply by speaking up, or whether you prefer that they raise their hands or put questions and comments in the Chat. Throughout the meeting, periodically remind participants to remain muted when they are not speaking.

Develop a script in your head on the mechanics of your rules of engagement, including on how to mute/unmute and raise hands with the various devices participants may be using. Such a script could be as follows: “To mute and unmute yourself on a PC, press Alt A, Star 6 on a landline phone, double tap the Mute/unmute button on an iPhone, and Command Shift A on a Mac. To raise your hand on a PC, press Alt Y, Star 9 on a landline phone, double tap on the More button on an iPhone and flick right to get to the Raise hand button. Press Command Shift Y on a Mac.” Periodically remind participants about these keystrokes during the meeting.

If you are using a shared pro account with other members of your organization, be sure to enter the expected meeting duration when scheduling meetings. This will help prevent scheduling conflicts. If you have ever tried to join a meeting when such a scheduling conflict has occurred, you may have witnessed the resulting chaos. Such conflicts can wreck two meetings at once and get people very angry with each other. If scheduling a recurring meeting, enter the day and time of the meeting in the Topic edit field (for example, “Staff Meeting Every Monday from 9:00 to 10:00 AM”).

With a Pro account owned by your organization, your meeting name will be the name the organization has assigned to it. For example, my Carroll Center Pro account username is “CCBZOOM7.” In such circumstances, remember to Rename yourself at the beginning of meetings so everybody knows who you are.

Prior to meetings, consider disabling the Chat function, especially for meetings predominantly composed of blind and visually-impaired people. Blind folks often consider Chat to be an annoying distraction. However, as mentioned above, sighted folks tend to love it, and if properly managed, some chat messages can enrich meetings. Remember that Chat can only be disabled online. It is not possible to do this through the desktop app.

If you anticipate sharing your screen during a meeting, first close all sensitive and extraneous windows. Consider creating desktop shortcuts for files or web pages you plan on opening during your presentation. This will make you appear organized and reduce the possibility of mid-presentation glitches.

Finally, think about whether you want to enable security-related features like the waiting room, the ability to join before the host, and locking the meeting once everyone has arrived. The waiting room feature gives you more Control + Over who you admit, but increases the hosting workload. Locking meetings prevents additional, potentially uninvited guests from joining. However, any late invitees will be unable to enter the meeting. also, if participants are forced to leave because their wi-fi gets temporarily disconnected, they will not be able to reenter the locked meeting.

13.8 Participating in and Creating Microsoft Teams Meetings

Microsoft Teams is a communications platform that combines chat, meetings, video calls, file sharing, and more into a single app. You may be asked some day to participate in a Microsoft Teams meeting. Anybody with a PC can participate in a Teams meeting. However, scheduling and hosting meetings can only be done by those with Microsoft 365 accounts. There are several different types of Teams accounts, including free, Home Essentials, Business, and enterprise accounts. The range of things you can do varies by account type.

I will only cover participating in and scheduling meetings with free accounts. “Free account” here means a Microsoft 365 home account for which you have paid nothing beyond $69 for an individual account or $99 for a family account. Important free account meeting limitations are:

·         60 minute limit on meetings for more than two people (one on one limitation is 30 hours).

·         Meetings cannot be recorded

·         Meetings can not be scheduled through the Outlook Calendar.

·         I should also note that, if you search for help by Googling questions, I have found this to be frustrating and misleading. The general assumption seems to be that people are using paid accounts, As a result, some recommended processes do not work with free accounts. These thing said, you should have no problem participating in Teams meetings, regardless of account type, but there are limitations on the actions you can perform when scheduling and hosting meetings.

13.8.1 Participating in Meetings

Here are the most important Teams keystrokes for participating in meetings:

·         Control + Shift + M: Mute/unmute

·         Control + Shift + O: Video on/off

·         Control + Shift K: Raise/lower hand

·         Control + Shift + L: List of participants with hands raised.

·         Control + Shift + E: Share content (same as screen share in Zoom).

·         Control + Shift H or Alt + F4: Leave meeting.

When you enter a meeting, you land on the Meetings Control + Toolbar, where you can find pretty much everything you need. Left arrow through the items, and if a shortcut key exists for the action, it is identified. They are listed below in the order encountered, that is, from right to left:

·         Share content (Control + Shift + E) Button: Press Enter to open a dialog. You first land on the Include computer sound checkbox. Spacebar to share screenreader sound and other audio. Shift + Tab once to the Active Windows list, Spacebar to expand, and Down arrow to the window you want to share. First in the list is the name of the active meeting. Press Enter on your choice. To end screen sharing, Spacebar on the Stop screen sharing button on the Meetings Control + Toolbar.

·         Mute (Control + Shift + M) Button: Toggle audio on and off.

·         Turn camera off (Control + Shift + O) Button: Toggle video on and off.

·         More button menu, more actions: Spacebar to expand. Among the options are Devices (change microphone and camera), and a few others. For paid accounts, recording meetings is found here.

·         Change your view button menu: Nothing much of importance here for screenreader users.

·         React Button Has Popup dialog: React to messages with emojis.

·         Raise Button, raise your hand (Toggle hand up and down.

·         People Button, show participants: Tab to the Attendees tree view, Down arrow through participants and see their status (audio, video, etc.) Hosts can open a context menu for muting individuals and a few other options.

·         Chat Button, show conversation: Last item on the Meetings Control + Toolbar. Press Home to get there quickly.  Press Enter on the Chat button, which lands you in an edit field. Type in your chat, and press Enter to send it. To access meeting chats, Shift + Tab to the list of chats and Up and Down arrow through them. They are listed chronologically, with the first meeting chat text at the top of the list, including the author and time of the chat. Unlike Zoom, you can use standard Windows keystrokes for selecting and copying individual chats to the Clipboard, and then pasting them into a text editor.

·         Note that if a participant shares his or her screen, this opens a new window whose title is “Shared content Meeting now Microsoft Teams.” To return to the Meetings Control + Toolbar, press Alt Tad, whose title is just “Meeting Now Microsoft Teams.”

13.8.2 Creating Meetings

There are two types of meetings: instant meetings and scheduled meetings.

13.8.2.1 Instant Meetings

These can be set up very quickly. Steps are:

1.    Open Teams and press Control 4 for the Calendar tab (if unresponsive, press Insert + Z to turn on Quick keys).

2.    Tab to the Meet now button and press Enter (but Shift + Tabbing is quicker).

3.    This opens a dialog where you first land in the Meeting name edit field. Edit as appropriate.

4.    Tab to the Get a link to share button and press Enter.

5.    Prepare an email to attendees, paste the link into the message, and send.

6.    Back in the dialog, Tab to the Start meeting button and press Enter to get into your instant meeting.

13.8.2.2 Scheduled Meetings

Scheduled meetings are more common. Steps for scheduling a meeting are:

1.    In Teams, press Control 4 to go to the Calendar tab.

2.    Tab to the New meeting button and press Enter (shortcut key: Shift Alt N).

3.    Type in the meeting title.

4.    Tab to the Start date field and type in the date in MM/DD/YY format.

5.    Tab to the Start time field and type in the time (you can also Up or Down arrow in 30 minute increments).

6.    Tab to Repeat and check this if it is a recurring meeting. Otherwise leave it unchecked.

7.    Tab to the Save button and press Enter.

8.    You will be prompted about how to share. Choices are copy link and through the Google calendar. Choose the Share link option.

9.    Prepare an email to invitees and paste the link into the body of the message. Note that only a link is generated, so include meeting details (date and time) in the body of the email.

10. Send the message to invitees.

I suggest not choosing the Google Calendar option because it can easily confuse invitees. It will generate a Google Meet link, which is different than the MS Teams meeting link. Invitees may have difficulty figuring out which link to use to join the meeting.

13.8.3 Navigating the Calendar to Find Your Scheduled Meetings

After you have scheduled a meeting, you need to know how to find it so you can join your own meeting when it is time. Steps are:

1.    Press Insert + Z with JAWS or Insert + Spacebar with NVDA to toggle Browse mode on, and then press Control 4 to open the Calendar.

2.    Right and Left arrow to move forward and back a day.

3.    Tab or Shift + Tab to select a meeting.

4.    Press the Applications key and Down arrow through the options:

a.    Edit

b.    Open meeting chat

c.    Join online: Use this to join a meeting you are hosting.

d.    Copy link

e.    Share

f.     Delete

Unfortunately, with a free account, there really isn’t much you can do to manage a meeting you are hosting such as muting or lowering hands. Similar to Zoom, anybody serious about hosting should get access to a paid account in the workplace or at school.

Finally, you can access Teams meetings on your iPhone. Here is a link to an informative article on this topic from Vision Ireland:

Navigating Teams on iPhone and iPad with VoiceOver

Chapter 14 Exploring Artificial Intelligence

Ever since the general release of Chat GPT in late 2022 by the Open AI company, the world has been abuzz about all things AI. Its significance has been compared to the electric lightbulb, the atomic bomb, and other technologies with the capacity to make our lives dramatically better or worse. AI works through large language models to generate results. Rather than attempt to provide an overview in my own words, below is an excerpt from a response using Google’s AI platform called Gemini:

Prompt: Please provide a general introduction of AI and LLMs.

Response: Artificial intelligence (AI) is a wide-ranging branch of computer science concerned with building smart machines capable of performing tasks that typically require human intelligence. AI research has been highly successful in developing effective techniques for solving a wide range of problems, from game playing to medical diagnosis.

Large language models (LLMs) are a type of AI that are trained on a massive amount of text data. They can be used to generate text, translate languages, write different kinds of creative content, and answer your questions in an informative way.

LLMs are a powerful tool that can be used for a variety of purposes. However, it is important to be aware of the potential risks associated with these technologies and to use them responsibly. End of response.

There are now a multitude of AI-related apps out there in the world and new ones are popping up all the time. Some have both free and subscription-based paid versions. Many are available on both computers and smartphones. I will only focus on the free versions of Chat GPT, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, Notebook LM (also a Google product), and Be My Eyes. For each of these, I will discuss:

·         How to create an account (if required), and how to access each of these apps.

·         How to prepare a prompt and access responses.

·         How to access recent activity or history, if available.

·         Getting detailed descriptions of images with apps which currently have this feature.

·         Uploading files from your PC so you can summarize and/or ask questions about them. And again, only for the free app versions that allow you to do this.

Before discussing the various AI apps, I must mention the important caveat that at least some of what I describe below may soon become outdated due to the continuing rapid pace of AI development. Great new apps may emerge that work better or provide useful features not offered by the current set of apps.

And here’s a totally unedited summary of this chapter created by Notebook LM:

“This document provides a guide to using several free artificial intelligence (AI) applications, including Chat GPT, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, Notebook LM, and Be My Eyes. The guide details how to create accounts, prepare prompts, access responses and history, describe images, and upload files for analysis within each app. Specific instructions are given for both PC and iPhone versions where applicable, highlighting features and addressing accessibility for screen reader users. The author also notes the rapid pace of AI development and the potential for future updates to alter the functionality described. Finally, limitations of the free versions of these apps are discussed.”

I couldn’t have summarized it any better! Let’s start with

Chat GPT.

14.1 Chat GPT

To open Chat GPT, go to:

https://chatgpt.com/

Create an account with your email and a 12-character password, or log in with your Google or Microsoft account. While you can create chats without an account, logging in allows you to access several useful features including chat history, file uploading, and syncing across devices.

14.1.1 Chat GPT on the PC

Chat GPt on the PC is web-based, so after logging in, create a desktop shortcut or favorite/bookmark so you can access it quickly in the future. Standard screenreader quick navigation keystrokes like those for headings, heading levels, edit fields, and buttons work here.

To initiate a chat, in the edit field, type in your prompt and press Enter. You will hear “ChatGPT is generating a response.” When finished, you should hear “Chat GPT says,” followed by the response in Say All mode.

To ease navigation, chats are marked up with headings. Press H to wrap to the top of the page where a level 5 heading entitled, “You said” appears, Below this is the text of your prompt. Under that is a level 6 heading “ChatGPT said,” below which appears the response. The response may also have a series of headings. For example I prompted for an overview of tarantulas. The response was organized under a series of level 3 headings: physical characteristics, habitat, behavior, and so on. Although the heading level hierarchy may seem illogical, it still aids page navigation.

Navigate to the edit box to ask follow-up questions. Responses with the same set of heading levels appear. They are arranged chronologically on the page with the initial question at the top of the page and follow-up responses below.

There is a Copy button below each response that you can use to place it on the Clipboard for pasting into a text editor like Word. To copy all responses of a chat thread, select the entire page (Control + A), copy with Control + C, and paste it into a text editor with Control + V. Edit the text to remove unwanted clutter.

If logged into your account, buttons for several options appear on the page. The most useful ones are discussed below.

With the Attach files button, you can upload files to Chat GPT and ask questions about them, such as summarizing them. Note that Chat GPT is one of a select very few free AI tools which will do this. Google Gemini and Microsoft CoPilot require you to use the paid version at the lofty price of $20 per month. Google’s Notebook LM is the only other free AI tool that I know of with this capability.

When you activate the Attach file button, Down arrow through the choices which include:

·         Connect to Google Drive: You will need to sign into your account here before accessing files.

·         Connect to Microsoft OneDrive submenu collapsed: Expand it to access personal or school/work accounts.

·         Upload from computer

I have only tried out the third “Upload from computer” option. Activate this and the standard Open file dialog appears. Shift tab back through the dialog to locate your file, and press Enter on it to upload it.

A number of common file types are supported such as Word, PowerPoint and PDFs. I noticed that the free version will not support Excel files with the standard.XLSX extension, but when I converted a spreadsheet file to.CSV, it worked. However, I only attempted this with files containing a single sheet.

It also appears that the free version limits you to three file uploads per day, while the limit is much higher for the paid version. I consider this file upload capability to be a significant strength of this free app. To the best of my knowledge, Notebook LM is currently the only other free AI app with this capability.

If you are signed into your account, you will be able to access your chat history. If you have the Chat GPT smartphone app, chat history is synced across devices so you can access Chat history on both your PC and smartphone.

From the top of the page, Chat History appears as a level 2 heading, below which appear level 3 headings for Today, yesterday, the previous 7 days, 30 days, and further back. Under each of the chronological headings appear links for individual chats. Press Enter on one of the chat history links to open it. Just after opening it, Down arrow once or twice to an unlabeled button. Press Enter to expand it. Here you can Down arrow through the four options which include share, rename, archive, and delete if you want to perform one of these actions.

Below that appears the level 5 and 6 headings mentioned above, the Copy button, and so on.

A Voice mode button also appears if you would like to dictate your prompts and hear responses with a high quality synthesized voice. This is a great feature which makes chats truly conversational and allows you to avoid lots of finger flicking. However, on the PC version, I have so far noticed that you can not access the text there. This is possible with the smartphone app, so I recommend you do Voice mode chats there instead if you would like to be able to copy the chat text to your Clipboard. If you perform Voice mode chats on your smartphone, text will be available across devices in the Chat History.

14.1.2 Chat GPT on the iPhone

To initiate a chat, navigate to the New message text field and dictate or type in your prompt. Flick right once to the Send button and activate it. You will receive haptic feedback while the response is being generated. VoiceOver then speaks the response in Say all mode.

To manage the chat, activate the Chat GPT 3.5 popup button near the top of the screen. Flick right to the Manage chat button which is collapsed. Double tap to expand it and find the following options: Share, Rename, Archive, and Delete.

Access Chat history by activating the Menu button at the top left of the screen. Chat history is organized chronologically with headings for past dates and buttons naming the chat threads. Activate any of these to read and manage them as described above.

In addition to standard chat text creation, you can use Voice Mode

a great feature called Voice mode can be used with the iPhone app. It enables you to have a conversation with a natural-sounding voice rather than by typing prompts and having VoiceOver read responses back to you. Among other things, it is quicker for generating a chat thread because you don’t have to be continually searching for the New message button, dictating prompts, and then finding the Submit button. The process feels natural and seamless.

Voice mode supports multiple languages. One amazing thing is that you can switch languages in mid-conversation. Just speak your prompt in French or Spanish, and the response will come back in that language.

You can find the Switch to Voice mode button just below the New message text field. The first time you activate it, a screen listing several synthesizer voices opens. Double tap on any of these to hear a sample, select the one you want, and activate the Confirm button at the bottom of the screen. You can return here later to switch to a different voice.

When you activate the Switch to Voice mode button, you will be prompted to start speaking. When finished, double tap on the Close button. This switches you back to VoiceOver. You are also informed of the duration of your conversation in minutes and seconds. It is not immediately obvious how you exit the screen displaying the last response. There is no Close or Back button. Double tap somewhere on the text of this response and you will be returned to a screen where the full conversation string is displayed in the lower part of the screen. The other standard buttons now reappear in the top part of the screen.

Like other text-based chats, the transcript of the conversation is saved in your Chat history.

14.2 Microsoft Copilot

Microsoft is a major investor in the Open AI company which developed Chat GPT. Copilot uses Chat GPT 4. There are several ways to access Copilot, both paid and free. There are also personal and enterprise-level accounts. I will only cover the personal version that is bundled into 365 accounts and the free web-based version accessed through Edge.

For best results, you should sign into your Microsoft account to use Copilot. To create a Microsoft account, activate the following link:

Create or Sign Into Your Microsoft Account

14.2.1 Copilot with Personal 365 Accounts

Effective on January 16, 2025, Microsoft integrated Copilot into all existing 365 personal accounts. Key elements of these accounts include:

·         The cost for new individual and family accounts will increase by $30 per year, going from $70 to $100 for individual accounts, and from $100 to $130 for family plans.

·         For existing accounts, the $30 increase will be applied upon annual license renewal. Account holders will have the option to waive Copilot if they do not wish to pay the higher annual license cost.

·         For family 365 accounts, only the principal account holder will have access to this plan.

·         Account holders will be subject to a credit of 60 prompts per month. These will renew on the first calendar day of each month. Unused credits will not carry over to the following month.

What are things you can do with Copilot? Here is what Copilot said when I asked for some examples:

Word:

·         Automated Formatting: Quickly format documents with consistent styles and layouts.

·         Content Suggestions: Receive intelligent suggestions for improving your writing and enhancing clarity.

·         Document Summarization: Generate concise summaries of lengthy documents for quick review.

Excel:

·         Data Analysis: Perform complex data analysis with easy-to-understand results and visualizations.

·         Automated Formulas: Generate accurate formulas based on natural language inputs.

·         Data Cleaning: Identify and correct errors or inconsistencies in datasets automatically.

PowerPoint:

·         Slide Design: Create visually appealing slides with automated design suggestions.

·         Content Generation: Generate slide content based on brief descriptions or bullet points.

·         Presentation Insights: Receive real-time feedback on presentation flow and impact.

Outlook:

·         Email Drafting: Compose emails using prompts and context-aware suggestions.

·         Meeting Summaries: Automatically generate summaries of meetings with key points and action items.

·         Task Management: Organize and prioritize tasks directly from email content and calendar events.

To invoke Copilot so you can create prompts:

·         In Word, press Alt + I

·         In Excel and PowerPoint, press the ribbon shortcut Alt H F X.

·         In Outlook, while in the body of an email you are preparing, and only in a Microsoft account email (outlook.com, Hotmail.com, live.com), press the ribbon shortcut Alt H F X.

With Excel, you are first required to have Autosave enabled. If you have disabled it, you will hear “AutoSave is turned off. I only work with files that have AutoSave turned on. Turn it on to continue.”

If you have not removed Autosave from the Quick Access toolbar, the quickest way to turn it on is to press Alt followed by 1 on the number row. If you have removed it, you may wish to add it back. See Chapter ?? on how to manage the Quick Access toolbar.

To reenable it permanently in Word, Excel, or PowerPoint:

1.    Press Alt F T to open the Options categories in the application.

2.    Press S to first-letter navigate to the Save category.

3.    Tab once to the AutoSave files stored in the cloud by default checkbox, check it, and press Enter.

4.    Alt F4 out of all open windows in the application and reopen for Autosave to take effect.

Note that if you want to create prompts related to existing Word, Excel, or PowerPoint files, they must first have been saved in OneDrive.

Using Word as an example, steps are:

1.    Open Word and press Alt + I. You will hear, ”“Draft with Copilot: Create prompt, 0/2000,” indicating that there is a 2,000 character limit to prompts.

2.    Type your prompt, Tab to the Generate button, and press Enter. Copilot says “working on it” while it is being processed, and also indicates when it is ready.

3.    When ready, press F6 several times until you hear “edit,” indicating that you are in the pane with the draft results.

4.    In Word, headings are usually added, sometimes limited to just level 1 headings, other times with additional heading levels. After reviewing the draft, press F6 one more time to the pane where follow-up actions appear, including prompting for refinements or modifications, like, dislike, keep, and discard.

To refer to a file for purposes of generating prompts related to that file:

1.    Navigate to the file in OneDrive. As mentioned above, this only works with files stored in OneDrive.

2.    Press the Applications key, Up arrow to Copy as path and press Enter. Thus placing the file path on your Clipboard.

3.    In the application, open Copilot, and after composing your prompt and indicating what you would like Copilot to do with the file, paste the file path.

4.    Tab to the Generate button and activate it.

5.    When Copilot indicates it is ready, press F6 several times to go to the pane with draft results.

14.2.2 Copilot on the Web with Edge

14.2.2.1 Generating Chats

To create a prompt and generate responses with Copilot, open Edge and press Control + Shift + period. Your screenreader should say, “Side pane is now showing Copilot.” You should also land in an edit field where you can type your prompt and then press Enter.

It takes several seconds for the answer to be generated during which the screen is silent. When the response is generated, your screenreader will read it in Say All mode.

The web page has a series of level two headings with your chat history. You will first hear “You said,” below which appears your prompt. Under this appears another level two heading which says, “Copilot said,” below which is the response.

The oldest chat is at the top of the page, and the newest one is at the bottom. The quickest way to hear your most recent chat again is to go to the bottom of the web page (Control + End) and press Shift + H or Shift + to go back a heading, and then put it in Say All mode.

Some chats may have level three headings. For example, if you ask for a recipe, level three headings may also appear for ingredients and instructions.

At the bottom of the response, you may find buttons or links where you can go to learn more about the topic, or find source citations.

·         There is also a Copy message button you can use to copy the individual prompt and response text to your Clipboard. You can then paste it into a text editor such as Word or Notepad.

There are also Good and bad response buttons you can activate to give feedback.

To ask follow up questions, from anywhere on the screen, press E to quickly return to the edit field, press Enter to get into it, and repeat the above steps. Unlike traditional browser search engines such as Google or Bing where you can only prompt one thing at a time, AI apps such as Copilot remember the context of your prompts, so you don’t need to restate anything.

14.2.3 Copilot on the iPhone

In December 2023, a new AI Copilot app was introduced to the iPhone. It is easy to use with VoiceOver. Prior to that, a Bing AI app was available, but VoiceOver navigation was clunky and confusing, so I avoided using it.

When you install the Copilot app, you will be asked to sign into your Microsoft account. Chat history is synced across your devices.

The Copilot app fields and options are similar to those of the PC version. One difference is that a button is present for using GPT 4, the default being version 3.5. You are notified that generating answers may take a few seconds more, but keep in mind that Chat GPT 4 results are more detailed and reliable than those generated by the 3.5 version. Use your judgment about this choice depending on how important the question is. Is accuracy critical when asking for a description of hippos? Probably not. But if asking Chat GPT to write HTML code for a web page you are designing, you want the response to be as accurate as possible.

The Ask me anything field is near the bottom of the screen. Plunk your finger down there and you will quickly find it. Dictate or type your prompt, flick right a couple of times to the Submit button and double tap to activate it. Also notice that the Add an image to search button is just after the Ask me anything field. As on the PC, you can paste image files here and get them described.

After submitting a prompt, VoiceOver will say “generating results.” Once generated, VoiceOver will automatically read the response to you in Say all mode. As on the PC, the message prompt appears as a level two heading, so you can use the Rotor to quickly navigate to it.

Activate the Copy button found just below the response if you want to capture the text and use Edit on the Rotor to paste it into a notetaking app or the body of an email.

A More button is found near the top of the screen. Double tap this to find buttons for New topic, Chat history, Rename, Feeback, and Delete.

14.3 Google Gemini

Gemini is Google’s AI engine. To access it the first time, type gemini.google.com in your Address bar, and log in with your Google account.

14.3.1 Generating Chats.

To start a chat:

1.    Open Gemini, press E to get to the Enter a prompt here edit field, and press Enter.

2.    Type in a prompt, such as “please provide a detailed description of an African elephant,” and press Enter. You will hear “Gemini is typing,” and then Gemini replied.”

3.    Press Shift H once to get to your message prompt which is tagged as a level two heading. A Listen button is directly underneath. If you wish, activate this to hear the response in a synthetic voice from Gemini (rather than your screenreader voice).

4.    Below that is the text of the response.

To ask follow up questions, repeat the steps above.

After the response has been generated, each prompt you prepared becomes a level 2 heading, below which the response text appears.

There are additional buttons under each response. These are:

Good and bad response toggles.

Regenerate to generate a new response.

·         Share & export: Press the Spacebar to expand this where choices include exporting the text to a Googledoc and a Gmail message.

·         Show more options: Expand this for more choices, including double-checking the response, copy the text, text to speech, and report legal issues related to copyright infringement.

You can also get detailed descriptions of image files saved on your PC. I will not cover this topic because JAWS PictureSmart and Be My Eyes for Windows do this more efficiently.

14.3.2 Recent Activity

Near the top of the page, and just below the New chat button appear buttons for each of your recent chat threads, with the most recent one at the top. Press the Spacebar on one of these to open a new tab. The page is organized the same way as described above.

14.4 Notebook LM from Google

Notebook LM is a great tool for summarizing and extracting information from documents, audio and video recordings, and web pages. This is one of the few free AI apps you can use for synthesizing information from your own files. And it is the only free one I know of that can be used for extracting information from audio and video files, making it potentially very useful for generating a first draft of minutes from Zoom or MS Teams meeting recordings.

When first exposed to Notebook LM, the audio “deep dives,” as they are referred to. invariably grab everybody’s attention. These sound like fake podcasts. A guy and woman that I refer to as California surfer dudes” carry on banter on the uploaded source. Reactions run the spectrum from fascination, amazement, hilarity, feeling creeped out, or some mix of these. While some might see the deep dives as just a gimmick, I have sometimes found that they offer a perspective I had not considered. And they can also be customized to be a bit less over-the top, or asked to emphasize certain key points.

Regarding the text-based documentation that Notebook LM can also generate, it has significant potential practical value for helping with everyday tasks. Text-based products that can be generated include:

·         Briefing documents for summarizing documents and meeting recordings.

·         A set of frequently asked questions (FAQ).

·         Study guides consisting of a set of short questions and answers to formulate quizzes and aid in absorbing instructional material.

Notebook LM has both free and paid versions. The paid version is referred to as Notebook LM Plus. With the free Notebook LM, you can store up to 100 notebooks (think of a “notebook” as an individual project). Each notebook can contain up to 50 sources. Each of those sources can be up to 500,000 words long. All users start with up to 50 chat queries and 3 audio generations per day. When you approach your maximum number of notebooks, you can delete those you no longer need to free up space.

If you upgrade to Notebook LM Plus, you get at least five times more usage, with up to 500 notebooks and 300 sources per notebook. The daily query limits also increase, providing you with up to 500 chat queries and 20 audio generations per day. Unless you use it obsessively, the free version should easily suffice.

14.4.1 Creating a Notebook

The first step in creating a notebook is to upload the files or files you wish to work with. Among the supported file types are: PDF, Googledocs, Sheets and Slides, audio (MP3, M4A, WAV, and others), and MP4 video files. Note that the standard Word (DOCX)and PowerPoint (PPTX) formats are not supported, but these are easily converted into PDFs in the Word and PowerPoint Save as dialogs in their File type combo boxes. Image files such as JPg’s can also be converted into PDF’s and then uploaded to Notebook LM.

Steps for creating a new notebook are:

1.    Open Notebook LM, press B to go to the Create new notebook button, and press Enter.

2.    Press B to go to the Upload sources from your computer button, and press Enter.

3.    The standard Open file dialog appears. Shift Tab back to find your file, and press Enter on it.

Or instead Down arrow to the Choose file button and press Enter to access other options, including Google Docs, Google Slides, Website, YouTube, and Copied text.

Once you have uploaded the file, a number of other buttons appear. Activate the Copy summary button to place a one-paragraph summary of the file on your clipboard. A Notebook LM summary of this chapter appeared earlier and it was pretty good.

Once you have uploaded your source file (or multiple files because this capability also exists), a number of additional buttons appear. I will cover what I consider to be the most useful ones below.

14.4.1.1 Audio Overview

Under a level2 heading appear the controls for generating what I have referred to above as a fake podcast by two surfer dudes who act as hosts. Notebook LM refers to it as a “deep Dive conversation.” There is also a Customize button where you can open an edit box and perhaps ask it to be less chatty and a bit more formal. And below that is the Generate button. Activate this to process the podcast.

Unfortunately, there is no verbal notification to indicate when processing is completed. Pressing H to wrap to the top heading on the page and then Down arrowing brings you to the text: “Down arrow to the text, “Generating conversation… This may take a few minutes. No need to stick around.” And it definitely does take some time, depending on the size of the uploaded source files. I have experienced waits of ten to fifteen minutes.

When processing is completed, the above-quoted text disappears, and is replaced with the name of the audio presentation and a set of player controls, including a Play button and a slider for navigation.

There is also a See more options for audio player button menu which is collapsed. Spacebar on it to expand and Down arrow through the options which include a Change playback speed submenu, Download, and Delete.

If you choose Download, a WAV file will be sent to your Downloads folder. I often then convert it to MP3 format. This reduces file size by as much as 80 percent.

To get a feel for what deep dives sound like, I have generated a deep dive that gives an overview of the fourth edition of my book. You can find the audio file, “WSCP4 Overview by Notebook.LM.MP3,” in the Practice Files folder accompanying the book.

I converted the six-page introduction of my book to a PDF and then uploaded it to Notebook LM. The original audio recording was about seventeen minutes long, and has been edited it down to about seven minutes.

14.4.1.2 Briefing Doc

Activate the Briefing doc button to create an approximately two page overview of the file. This can be done with all the file types mentioned above, but it needs to be emphasized that, as far as I know, this is the only free AI app that is available for interacting with audio and video files. Consequently, it can be used to summarize meeting recordings. I have started doing this with Zoom meeting recordings which Zoom generates in both audio (M4A) and video (MP4) format. While there are some inaccuracies, I have so far found that Notebook LM does an excellent job of getting most things correct. As such, it can be a great aid in drafting meeting minutes.

Once the draft briefing doc is generated, and you have copied and pasted the text into an editor like Word, you will need to do substantial editing because the generated text appears as a single run-on paragraph. I have discovered a trick with Word’s Find and replace command for starting this cleanup process. The briefing doc designates logical sections with a colon after several words as a section title. So, I do the following in Word:

1.    Press Control + H to open the Find and replace dialog.

2.    In the Find field, type the colon sign.

3.    Tab once to the Replace field and type ^p. (The caret symbol is Shift + 6 on the Number row), the special character for a paragraph return. Note that the letter p must be in lower case.

4.    Tab several times to the Replace all button and press Enter. You will hear how many replacements were made.

5.    Press Escape to exit the dialog.

This creates new paragraphs starting on the line below where the colon appears, making any further editing a bit easier. I hope that in future iterations of Notebook LM Google generates text broken up into paragraphs so users will not have to edit quite so much.

14.4.1.3 Frequently Asked Questions

Activate the FAQ button to generate a set of questions and answers for the source file. As with briefing docs, a single run-on paragraph is generated After copying and pasting the text into Word, use the Find and replace command to break the text up into paragraphs by typing the question mark in the Find field and typing the question mark followed by caret P. This will conserve the existing question marks and follow them with new paragraphs on the next line. Then do additional editing cleanup.

14.4.1.4 Study Guides

Activate the Study guide button to generate a set of questions and answers that can be used to create tests and quizzes about the source file content. This is a great tool for teachers and students. As with FAQ above, use Find and replace to breakup the initial run-on single paragraph into multiple paragraphs, separated out where the question marks appear.

14.4.2 Accessing Existing Projects
