Once created and saved, notebooks are referred to as projects. On the Notebook LM landing page, previously-created notebook titles appear and they are all labeled as buttons. Navigating to where you can interact with them is a bit tricky. Steps are:

1.    Open Notebook LM and navigate to the button with the project name.

2.    Press the Spacebar and then tab once. Note that pressing the tab key at this point is absolutely crucial.

The window title should now include the project name. Down arrow to hear any summary you previously created.

Three tabs appear at the top of the page. Press Enter on one of them to select it,[28] and then Escape to exit what sounds like forms mode. Note that pressing Enter is more dependable than the Spacebar for selecting a tab. Actions you can do in each of the tabs include:

·         Sources tab: add additional sources to the project. Select all sources or just the ones you want for carrying out additional tasks.

·         Chat tab: copying a previously-created summary to the Clipboard, Generating an audio overview, typing in a follow-up query

·         Studio tab: loading a previously-created audio overview, generating new study guides, briefing docs, and FAQ.

14.4.3 Deleting Projects

You can delete projects you no longer want in your history. Steps are:

1.    From the top of the page, navigate to the Select project filter type button menu which is collapsed. Press the Spacebar to expand it.

2.    Filter or sort options are most recent, title, and shared with me. Press Enter on your choice.

3.    Press Escape to exit forms mode, and then T to go to the top left cell in a table where your projects are listed according to the sort option you chose..

4.    Press Control + Alt + Down arrow to move down the first column to the project you wish to delete.

5.    Press Control + Alt + Right arrow to move along the row to the Project Actions Menu button menu collapsed

6.    Press the Spacebar to expand it.

7.    Your first choice is Delete (the other option here is rename).

8.    Press Enter and confirm the deletion.

Even though the table is still present after deleting a project, you cannot navigate to additional projects you wish to delete. You must restart the process above and delete them one by one.

14.5 Be My Eyes

Be My Eyes has been around a long time on the iPhone for calling sighted volunteers to answer prompts about camera shots. in the Fall of 2023, the company introduced a revolutionary feature called Be My AI which used Chat GPT to generate detailed descriptions of photos taken on the iPhone. In early 2024, Be My Eyes for Windows was introduced for generating image descriptions on the PC. I will first discuss Be My Eyes for Windows, and then Be My AI on the iPhone.

14.5.1 Be My Eyes for Windows

In Chapter 1.2.4.1, I discussed JAWS PictureSmart, an AI tool that does an amazing job generating detailed image descriptions. If you are an NVDA user or do not have access to JAWS for other reasons, consider using Be My Eyes for Windows for accomplishing similar tasks. This is the PC version of the fantastic smartphone app whose Be My AI feature describes photos. You will first need to download the app.

14.5.1.1 Download and Installation

Download Be My Eyes for Windows at:

https://www.bemyeyes.com/be-my-eyes-for-windows

On that page:

1.    Activate the Download for Windows link. This may open a popup for downloading it in Danish. If this happens, tab to the Go to English button, and press Enter.

2.    Activate the Install Be My Eyes button.

3.    go to your Downloads folder, open the file entitled Be My Eyes Installer.exe, and complete the installation.

To open the app, press the Windows key, type the first few letters of Be My Eyes until you hear Be My Eyes app, and press Enter. You will first hear, “Describe my screen (Keyboard shortcut Alt + Ctrl + H) button. Tab to hear a list of other keyboard shortcuts, including:

·         Take picture using built in camera (Keyboard shortcut Alt + Control + J.

·         Describe picture from File Explorer (Keyboard shortcut Alt + Control + K.

·         Describe clipboard (Keyboard shortcut Alt + Control + L.

After opening the app, go to a window or screen you want described and use the shortcut Alt + Ctrl + H to generate a description of that screen or window. Or press Alt + Control + K to open a dialog where you can Select an image file such as a.JPG or.PNG file, and have it described.

·         When you invoke one of these shortcuts, you will hear, “Please wait, Be My AI is writing a message…” while results are generated.

·         The description will be read to you in Say All mode by your screenreader. You can then type follow up questions without navigating to an edit field. Unfortunately,

·        
Question to ask the AI Edit

·         Below this are two tabs: the Be My Eyes tab and the Settings tab. Press the Right and Left arrow to move between them

14.5.1.2 Reassigning Keystrokes

If you are a JAWS user, you will want to assign a different keystroke combination for taking pictures using the built in camera because the assigned keystroke conflicts with the keystroke for opening JAWS. Do this in the Settings tab as follows:

1.    Tab to the Customize keyboard shortcuts link and press Enter.

2.    Tab to the Take picture button and press the Spacebar.

3.    Type in a new Control Alt letter combination.

4.    Tab to the Finish button and press Enter.

Use the same steps to reassign any of the other keystrokes. For example, you might want to change one to make it easier to remember, such as changing the keystroke for describing an image file to Alt + Control + F, rather than K.

14.5.2 Be My AI on the iPhone

After downloading Be My Eyes from the App Store, you will first need to create an account and log in. You can use your Google account for this.

While in the app, you can take pictures and get them described. You can also get descriptions of existing pictures in the native Photos app and image files saved to cloud sharing apps on your iPhone.

photos and screenshots can be described with Be My AI. You can also copy the text of the description and paste it into a text editor app on your phone like Notes or Drafts, as well as download a JPG file to your computer.

14.5.2.1 Taking Photos, Generating Descriptions, Sharing and Saving

The Be My Eyes app has been around for a number of years, its main use being to give sighted volunteers access to your camera so they can help you with simple tasks that require visual assistance. To access volunteer assistance, you place focus on the Get Support tab, located at the bottom left of your screen. The second tab, the Be My AI tab, is the one that interests us here. Double tap on it to open this screen,

To take a picture and get it described, find the Take picture button, point your camera at what you want described, and double tap. You will hear the camera shutter click. VoiceOver will say “Analyzing, please wait,” and a chime-type noise will play while processing. When finished, VoiceOver will read the description in Say all mode.

An Ask more button now appears. You can Double tap on this and dictate follow-up questions in the edit field.

Also, if you place focus on the response text, and flick up or down, options for copying the text and sharing appear. To copy the text, double tap on this option, open a text editing app such as Notes or Drafts, and navigate to Edit on your Rotor to paste the description.

Although a slightly convoluted process, you can use the Share option to save the photo, something that was not possible with the first release of Be My AI. I did this by sending myself an email and accessing the photo on my PC with Google Chrome. Other ways may also work, but at least this one consistently works for me. Steps are:

1.    Place focus on the photo description, flick up or down to Share, and activate this.

2.    This opens a screen entitled “Share link to picture and description.” Activate the Share link button.

3.    Activate the Mail button.

4.    Place some text in the Subject field if you like, but this step is not required.

5.    Address the email to yourself and send it.

6.    Open the message in your PC’s email client and activate the link which opens a web page in your default browser. Regardless of default browser, the steps below work.

7.    Just before the text is a graphic link entitled “User message, picture. Open image in a new tab.” Activate this link.

8.    The title of this new tab is the filename which is a jumble of numbers followed with a.JPG file extension.

9.    Press Control + S to open the standard Save as dialog, rename the file to something more meaningful if you like, press Enter, and the file will download to your PC’s Downloads folder in JPG format.

14.5.2.2 Generating Descriptions for Images Already Saved on Your iPhone

If you have taken photos and screenshots on your iPhone, you can locate them in the native Photos app and get them described with Be My AI. You can also do this for images saved in cloud sharing apps like Dropbox, OneDrive, and Google Drive.

Steps for doing this for images saved in the Photos app are:

1.    Open the Photos app. Photos, screenshots, and videos are listed chronologically, with the most recent one at the bottom of the list.

2.    Double tap on the photo or screenshot to be described.

3.    Activate the Share button.

4.    Scroll down to the Describe with Be My Eyes button, and activate it.

5.    VoiceOver will say “please wait, Be My AI is writing a message.” After about five or ten seconds, the description will be read to you in Say All mode.

In the Message field below the description, you can ask follow up questions. With focus on the description, you can also flick up or down once to the Copy button and then paste this text into a text editor app. The Share option does not appear here. But keep in mind that the photo is already saved on your device.

Steps for getting a description of an image file saved in a cloud sharing app are slightly different than for the Photos app. Do the following:

1.    Open the cloud sharing app where the image file has been saved (Dropbox, Google Drive, OneDrive, etc.).

2.    Navigate to the photo you want described. When you land on it, VoiceOver should say “actions available.”

3.    Flick down a couple of times to Send copy of file, and activate.

4.     Scroll down to the Describe with Be My Eyes button, and activate.

5.    VoiceOver says “exporting,” and then “please wait, Be My AI is writing a message.” After about five or ten seconds, the description will be read to you in Say All mode.

As with the Photos app, you can also copy the message description to your Clipboard.

Chapter 15 Audio and Video Editing

This chapter discusses simple editing of audio and video files. Audacity is a free audio editor. REAPER is primarily an audio editor, but also the only one I currently know that can accessibly edit video. A personal license costs $60. In the third edition of this book, I covered a free option for video editing with a free app called Machete. Unfortunately, it no longer works. Some file conversion  may be required for editing audio with Audacity and is definitely required to render REAPER video projects into usable formats once editing is completed. A free and easy-to-use app called File Converter is also covered in this chapter.

Many blind and visually-impaired people record and edit audio, and some are real experts. Far fewer record and edit video. But both have their practical uses.

All blind and visually-impaired people should have strategies for making simple audio recordings. This comes in handy for recording short snippets of information on the fly like contact information, appointment dates and times, and instructions for performing daily tasks. For work and school, editing meeting and class recordings can be useful so you can delete unwanted segments and shorten recordings to just the content that you need. As for me, while first a trainee and later as an instructor at the Carroll Center, I have created countless audio files to serve as reference material while learning how to use JAWS and other assistive technologies, later editing out the “um’s and ah’s” and other unwanted noise.

Reasons for recording and editing video may be less obvious to blind folks. From my own experience, I can identify at least two reasons. At work, I am sometimes asked to prepare videos demonstrating technology at conferences and workshops where most of the participants  are sighted. Second, several years ago, my workplace launched a program to train screenreader users to conduct web accessibility testing. Testers usually need to communicate their findings to sighted clients. Being able to do this through videos can be very powerful. Most web developers are sighted. For them to see what is going on while a web tester is navigating a page can be a very effective tool for building awareness about how screenreader users navigate web pages, and for communicating the impacts of accessibility problems. Audio can also be effective, but sighted people rely on their eyes much more than their ears, so video in combination with audio may be more powerful for demonstrating problems and solutions. Video can also be a powerful communication tool for advocacy work on accessibility issues.

I will first cover Downloading and using File Converter. Then I will talk about audio recording and editing, and then follow with video.

15.1 File Converter

Download this app[29]at File Converter - Convert & compress everything in 2 clicks.

File Converter works with a wide variety of audio, video, text, and image file formats. Here, I will only talk about converting audio formats, but you can also convert image (JPG, PNG, etc.) or text-based files (Word or PowerPoint) to PDF.

Steps for converting an audio file with File Converter are:

1.    Navigate to the audio file to be converted on your PC.

2.    Press the Applications key, and if using Windows 11, Up arrow to Show more options and press Enter.

3.    Down arrow to the File Converter submenu and press Enter or Right arrow to open it.

4.    Down arrow to the desired audio format (presumably MP3 or WAV for audio or MP4 for video) and press Enter to convert it To the new format.

The converted file is save in the same folder and with the same file name prefix as the original file, but of course with the new audio or video file format extension. That’s all there is to it. It is quick and easy. I will reference back to this section at the appropriate places in the following sections on audio and video.

15.2 Audio Editing with Audacity

Audacity is a popular application that is fully accessible for all basic editing and playback tasks. It is free and easy to use, but only works with MP3 and WAV audio formats.

·         I should mention that at least two other accessible applications are popular among blind audio editors. First, there is REAPER which will be discussed later in this chapter, but only in the context of video editing.

·         Second, GoldWave can be purchased for a one-time price of $59 or an annual license of $19, and is available for a two-week trial period. It can be used to edit a wide array of audio file formats. Video files can also be converted to audio and then edited. I have used it for many years. Learn more at GoldWave - Audio & Video Editing Software.

Before discussing editing with Audacity, I will first talk about options for recording audio.

15.2.1 Recording Audio and tips for Good Results

Here I present an overview of recording possibilities. I do not provide step-by-step directions for making recordings, nor transferring recordings to your PC.

There are many accessible ways to record audio, including:

·         Apps on your PC such as the Sound Recording app which comes with Windows, the Zoom app for meetings, and Audacity.

·         Apps on the iPhone such as the native Voice Memo app and third party apps like RecUp for use with Dropbox (see Chapter 11.3.1).

·         Specialized devices for blind people such as the Victor Reader Stream and Braille notetakers.

·         Mainstream digital audio recorders manufactured by companies like Sony and Zenith. Some of these are accessible because they include audio feedback like speech or beeps to indicate recording status and folder locations for saved recordings.

Many audio file formats exist. To be able to edit them, be sure your recording device can produce at least one of the following common file types: Mp3, WAV, or M4A. The iPhone RecUp app and the Victor Reader Stream Second and Third Generations produce MP3 files. The MS Sound Recording app, the Zoom desktop app, and the iPhone native Voice Memo app produce M4A files. Audacity can produce MP3 and WAV files.

Also be sure you know how to access saved recordings on your computer if you want to eventually edit them. If you use a mainstream digital recorder, make sure you choose a model where it is possible to transfer recordings to your computer.

A limitation of using Audacity is that it can only edit MP3 and WAV files. If you anticipate that you will be frequently working with M4A files, you will need to convert them to either the MP3 or WAV format. Use File Converter to do this.

If recording audio that you later intend to edit, here are a few hints to make the editing process easier and more efficient:

·         Speak slowly and clearly, as well as slow down your screenreader speech. Remember that sighted people are not used to synthesized speech, so set it at a rate they can understand. Other blind folks may also be more comfortable at slowere speech rates.

·         If you are preparing a demo on how to do something with your screenreader, do not talk over the screenreader. Let your JAWS or NVDA finish before you resume speaking. If you fail to do this, that segment of the recording will be useless. You will need to record it again.

·         Leave a few seconds of silence just after a segment you know you will be wanting to delete when it is time to edit. If you are like me, and mumble lots of “ums and ahs,” leave gaps of silence after these to make them easier to remove later on.

·         Put your phone in Airplane mode so unwanted background noise does not pop in while recording. If recording on or near a computer, close all programs you do not need, and especially ones that make their own noises (example: Outlook chimes whenever new messages arrive).

·         Before doing long recordings, do some short test recordings to verify that your volume levels are correct. It can be frustrating to discover that your volume levels are out of whack only after you have wasted a lot of time on an otherwise perfect recording.

15.2.2 Installing Audacity

                        Audacity does not come built-in on your computer. Download the installation file from:

Windows Audacity

In your downloads folder, find the installation file and activate it. During installation, a shortcut for Audacity will be added to your Desktop.

15.2.3 Useful Keystrokes for Navigation, Playback, and Editing

Here is a list of useful Audacity keystrokes:

·         Control + O: Open file.

·         Spacebar: Play audio, but do not move cursor, also plays currently selected clip.

·         X: Play audio and move cursor

·         Home: Go to beginning of recording.

·         End: Go to end of recording.

·         Left arrow: Go back short amounts during playback.

·         Right arrow: Go forward short amounts during playback.

·         Shift Comma: hold down together to go back longer amounts during playback.

·         Shift Period: hold down together to go forward longer amounts during playback.

·         Shift Home: Select from cursor position to beginning of recording.

·         Shift End: Select from cursor position to end of recording.

·         Alt S I:Store beginning cursor position (my memory jog for I is initiate).

·         Alt S C: Store end cursor position (my memory jog for C is conclude).

·         Spacebar: Play selected snippet.

·         C: Play small snippets just before and after selection.

·         Delete: Delete current selection.

·         Control + 2: Slow playback by about 50 percent. (useful for repositioning cursor by very small amounts of time while micro-editing)

·         U: Go back a small amount and hear it.

·         I: Go forward a small amount and hear it.

·         Insert + Spacebar and then S or Insert + S: Mute JAWS or NVDA speech (useful when editing for avoiding hearing conflicting synthesized speech and audio at the same time).

15.2.4 Editing Audio

During initial installation, an Audacity folder was created in your local Documents folder if you were not signed into OneDrive. If signed in, the Audacity folder is a subfolder of your OneDrive Documents folder, that is, within your user folder, it is found at: OneDrive/Documents/Audacity. Also by default, any files you save after editing are located in this folder.

To open a file for editing press Control + O. Frankly, I find navigating between folders in the Audacity Open dialog very confusing. The tree view that you typically find in such dialogs is not present here. To avoid frustration, first move files you want to edit into the Audacity folder. Then it will be easier to Shift + Tab back to the list view and find your file.

Audacity has a classic menu bar with dropdowns for accessing commands. Press Alt to open the menu bar where you first land on the File menu. As with all such menus, you can Right and Left arrow to move to the various menus (File, Edit, Select, etc.). You can then Down or Up arrow to access commands.

The Audacity window is divided into three parts which you move through by pressing Control + F6. From the top of the window to the bottom, these are the Upper toolbar, the Track view, and the Lower toolbar.  The timeline of your audio file is visible in the Track view, and various navigation, editing, and audio file settings appear on the Upper and Lower toolbars. On the toolbars, move through them with Tab and Shift + Tab.

Several of the keystrokes listed above are especially useful for navigating the audio file timeline while in the Track view. Both the Spacebar and X will play and pause audio. However, there is one important difference. Pressing the Spacebar plays and pauses the audio but does not move the cursor. So, if you press the Spacebar once to start playback at the beginning of the recording, press it again to pause, and then press it a third time to resume, it will restart playback at the beginning, and not where you paused. Pressing X starts playback and moves the cursor. So, if you pause with X, and then restart with X again, playback resumes where you paused. As we will soon see, X is used to mark selection start and end points, while the Spacebar is not used for this purpose, but is still useful while editing.

·         Press Home and End to go to the beginning and end of the recording, respectively. Press the comma or Left arrow to go back short amounts during playback. Press the period or Right arrow to go forward short amounts during playback.

·         Hold down Shift  and Comma together to go back longer amounts during playback. Hold down Shift  and period together to go forward longer amounts during playback.

The simplest form of editing involves marking start and endpoints of a selection and then deleting the selection. I will first outline the steps for removing selections at the start and end of a recording, and then removing selections in the middle.

Steps for removing a selection at the beginning of a recording are:

1.    Press Home to be sure focus is at the start of the recording.

2.    Press X to begin playback.

3.    Press X again at the end of the snippet you wish to remove.

4.    Press Shift Home to select from that marker back to the beginning.

5.    Press the Delete key to remove the selection.

After pressing Shift Home to select the snippet, you could have pressed the Spacebar to hear the selection before deleting it. If you do not like your result, you can press Control + Z to undo your last keystroke for deleting the selection.

Steps for removing a selection at the end of a recording are:

1.    Navigate to the start position where you want to start the deletion and press X to mark it.

2.    Press Shift End to select from that start marker to the end of the recording.

3.    Press the Delete key to remove the selection.

Editing out selections in the middle of a recording involves pressing X to mark start and end points, as well as “storing” those two positions before deleting the selection. Steps are:

1.    Navigate to and press X to mark the start of your selection.

2.    Press Alt S I to store the start marker position (mnemonic: I for initiate). This can be found in the Selection menu on the menu bar.

3.    Navigate to and press X to mark the end of your selection.

4.    Press Alt S C to store the end marker position (also found in the Selection menu on the menu bar, mnemonic: C for conclude).

5.    Press the Delete key to remove the selected clip.

Before deleting a selection, you can first press the Spacebar to hear it. You can also press the letter C to hear about one second before and after the selection to preview what that range of the recording will sound like if you delete it.

Editing is this simple if there is a reasonable amount of silence at the boundaries where you want to edit out a clip. But there will be times when you need to be more granular in setting start or end markers. Perhaps there is only a few milliseconds between two spoken words and you want to delete the first word while keeping the second one. Or words have run together and you just want to do your best to find the boundary between Where one word ends and the next one begins.

In such cases several other keystrokes will help you zoom in on precise positions for setting start and end markers. When you are slightly past the position you would like to mark, press U to go back about one-half second. Or if you are slightly before press I. You can now be extremely precise in positioning your cursor by pressing Control + 1 or Control + 2 which increases the zoom level, thus enabling you to move by much smaller increments. Now each time you press U or I, you will hear the audio dramatically slowed down. Listening closely, you may be able to find the precise separation point between words or whatever other type of audio you are editing.

While you are performing these zoom operations, you should mute your screenreader (Insert and Spacebar together, followed by S with JAWS, or Insert S with NVDA) to avoid conflict between the synthesized speech (when pressing U or I) and the recorded audio.

For example, let’s say I have a segment of audio, “Um, Good morning” that runs closely together,  and I want to edit out the “um.” Using these zooming keystrokes, I can hopefully get the cursor to just the point where the M fades out , and just before the hard G in good morning begins.

When you are ready to save your edited audio file, you need to export it. As mentioned at the start of this section, the default save location is the Audacity folder. Steps for exporting a file are:

1.    Press Alt to open the File menu, Down arrow to the Export submenu and press Enter. The shortcut key to open this submenu is Control + Shift + E.

2.    This opens the Export Audio dialog in the Filename edit field, already populated with the existing filename.

3.    To save the updated file with the same filename, press Enter. You will be informed that there is already a file in the same location with this filename.

4.    Press Enter again to replace it,

5.    or if you want to save a second file with a new name, just preserving the original unedited file, type in a new filename and press Enter.

To know your position within a recording, press Control + F6 until you hear “Snap checkbox.” On the Lower toolbar. ” Tab once to Audio Position, where you hear time expressed in two-digit hours, two-digit minutes, and two-digit seconds format. An example where the position is at six seconds is “00 h 00 m 06 s.” Press F6 again a couple of times to get back to the recording. To check your position again during the same session, a single Control + F6 will bring you right to the Audio Position setting.

For longer recordings, it is useful to know how to change times and quickly get to them. This is done in the Start edit field, which is two tabs past the Audio position setting in the Lower menu bar. When you navigate there, you will find that it is prepopulated with your current position. Left and Right arrow until you land on the hour, minute, or second you want to change, and type over the current position with your desired new position. Now press Control + F6 a couple of times to get back to the Track view. When you resume playback by pressing X, the recording should start up at the new position.

To discover other potentially useful keystrokes, explore the drop down menus (especially the Edit and Play menus) and see what the shortcut keys are.

Also check out the Getting Started web page. You can access it in the Help menu or activate the following link: Getting Started - Audacity Manual.

Becoming a proficient audio editor requires lots of trial and error. But given the inherently repetitive nature of editing, with some practice, you should get the hang of it pretty quickly.

It is not easy to get a feel for audio editing solely by reading the text presented here. To get a better grasp, listen to the MP3 file entitled “Editing with Audacity Demo.MP3” in the Practice Files folder which accompanies this book.

15.3 Video Editing with REAPER

This section outlines an accessible approach for editing video files with REAPER which is primarily an audio editing application. The approach is restricted to very simple editing: that is, video clip selection, deletion, copying, cutting, and pasting. If your objective is to become an Oscar-winning cinematographer, please look elsewhere.

When asked to prepare video presentations at work, I quickly found I was severely limited by my inability to edit them. Without being able to edit, I was compelled to record over and over again. Yet I could never get my video recordings to even a barely acceptable level of quality. Any final product was just too embarrassing, with lots of “um’s and ah’s,” word mispronunciations, and technical glitches.

It is very difficult to find an accessible video file editor that can be used to delete unwanted selections in the middle of a video file. Accessible software for trimming is common enough, but trimming only relates to removing unwanted segments at the beginning and end of a video, not deleting clips in the middle. In the third edition of this book, I covered a free option for video editing with a free app called Machete. Unfortunately, it no longer works. REAPER is the only accessible app I know of that can be used for simple video editing. But before delving into REAPER, below is a discussion of video recording options.

15.3.1 .2 Recording Videos on Your PC and iPhone

I use the Zoom desktop app for recording videos of my computer screen. If you have a Zoom account and the desktop application installed on your computer, you can record video in MP4 format using the Screen share feature. Simply start an instant Zoom meeting (see Chapter 13.4.1) with yourself as the host and sole participant. Unmute yourself, and share the screen, including the computer sound if you want the recording to pick up your screenreader synthesized speech. Press Alt + R to start the recording, and Alt + R again to finish it. End the meeting to start the download. See Chapter 13.4.4 for a full discussion on recording meetings and accessing the resulting MP4 video files.

Here are some practical tips for making video recordings on your computer.

·         The tips listed above in Chapter 15.2.1 on making easy-to-edit audio recordings apply equally to video recordings. Speak slowly and clearly, slow down your screenreader voice rate to a speed comprehensible to all listeners, and leave pauses at boundary points where you anticipate deleting selections in order to make editing easier.

·         If you are using video to demonstrate something on your computer, every time you switch between windows, be sure the window is maximized. Otherwise, sighted observers will not be able to see the full screen. Do this by pressing Alt and the Spacebar together, followed by X. Do not press Windows + Up arrow which most people think is another way to maximize a window. It is actually a toggle. If you use this keystroke and cannot see the screen, you will often minimize windows that were already maximized. I once wasted a couple of hours before I figured this out.

·         If sharing the screen with a word document or Excel spreadsheet, hide the Navigation pane with the ribbon shortcut Alt W K. Otherwise, it will take up a big chunk of the screen.

·         If you plan on including headshots of yourself in your video, use one of the tools discussed in Chapter 13.6.2 on centering your face with the computer’s camera.

With your iPhone, you can record what is appearing on the screen, your own voice, and synthesized VoiceOver speech. Do the following before starting:

·         Toggle off the Screen Curtain. Otherwise, viewers will only see a black screen. The VoiceOver gesture is a three finger triple tap.

·         Turn on Do not disturb to prevent being interrupted by phone calls and notifications while you are recording.

·         As is the case with synthesized speech on the computer, slow down your VoiceOver speech rate so all listeners can understand it.

·         Wear a headset so VoiceOver and speech volume are roughly equivalent. If you do not wear a headset, your speech volume will be normal while VoiceOver volume will be barely audible. Make a few short practice videos and listen to them to verify that volume levels are acceptable.

As is the case for the PC, when you make mistakes while recording, and while switching screens and hearing noise you do not want in the final recording, pause a few seconds before continuing to speak.

15.3.2 Purchasing REAPER and Initial Setup

·         REAPER is a powerful application used by many blind audio enthusiasts, including podcasters. It enables multi-track editing and mixing. If you load a video file into REAPER, in editing the audio, you are simultaneously editing the video too. Therefore, if audio editing is accessible to screenreaders, which it is after a adding a couple of extensions (see below), this makes video editing accessible too.

·         REAPER has a generous 60-day free trial period, after which it can be purchased for a one-time charge of $60 for personal non-commercial use. Download the free trial version at:

·         REAPER Audio Production Without Limits.

If you own multiple computers, you may install the same license key on all of them, as long as you only use REAPER on one computer at a time.

After completing the trial period and purchasing REAPER, you will be sent a product license key by email which you copy and paste to authorize your permanent version. All of this is clearly explained during the authorization process.

As part of the installation process, a shortcut is added to your Desktop for opening REAPER. A folder entitled “REAPER Media” is also added to either your local Documents folder or to the Documents subfolder of OneDrive, this latter if you are signed into your Microsoft account.

To make REAPER screenreader-accessible, you will need to also download and install two extensions at:

·         SWS / S&M Extension

·         OSARA: Open Source Accessibility for the REAPER Application

Adding these two extensions helps to verbalize useful editing information such as cursor position and how this feedback is conveyed. Be sure to install reper first.

To make Osara work correctly:

1.    Open REAPER and press Alt to open the menu bar. REAPER has a classic dropdown menu structure.

2.    , Right arrow to Extensions, Down arrow to the Osara submenu, and press Enter to open it.

3.    Down arrow to Configure REAPER for optimal screen reader accessibility, press the Spacebar, and choose Yes.

4.    Close REAPER and reopen it for changes to take effect.

There is nothing you need to do with the other extension other than install it.

15.3.3 Starting a Project

Audio and video tracks are edited in  projects which you need to save if you are going to continue working on them beyond just a single session. You then insert the file or files that make up the tracks for that project. Saving the project involves creating a REAPER project file with an RPP extension. By default, the RPP file is saved to the REAPER Media folder mentioned above. When you have finished your preliminary or final editing and wish to listen to it with a standard media player app like Windows Media Player, you will render it to an audio or video file. That’s the overall process,

To create a new project and insert media files into it:

1.    REAPER has standard dropdown menus. Press Alt to land on the File menu, Down arrow to New project and press Enter. Or use the standard Control + N keystroke.

2.    Press Alt to open the menu bar again, Right arrow to the Insert menu, Down arrow once to Media file, and press Enter to open the Import file dialog. Make your life easier by putting any files you will be importing in the REAPER Media folder created during installation. Having all you’re project and media files in the same location speeds things up.

3.    This opens a standard Open file dialog. Shift tab a couple of times to the list view of the default REAPER Media folder. If you have placed your audio or video file here, Down arrow or first-letter navigate to it and press Enter to add it to your project.

4.    Press Control + Home to place the cursor at the start of the recording.

5.    Press the Spacebar to start playback.

6.    Now do your editing (see the next section).

As you edit, you will want to save your project file. And when finished editing, you will want to render the file in MP4 video format. Saving and rendering will be covered in the section after editing.

15.3.4 Basic Editing

The simplest type of editing involves selecting snippets, and then deleting, copying, or cutting them. Selecting snippets involves setting start and end markers, and for this, it is important to understand cursor behavior with REAPER. Pressing the Spacebar plays and pauses your video track. However, cursor position does not move with playback. If you press the Spacebar a second time, playback will snap back to the start of the recording (if you have not yet designated any markers), or back to a marker if you have already inserted one. To fix a cursor point so that you can then mark it, press Control + Spacebar when you pause so that the cursor remains focused at that point in the track.

In reality, when editing, you are editing the audio track, but I will just say “video” for the sake of simplicity here. These things said, here are the steps for selecting and then deleting a snippet:

1.    Press the left bracket to set a start marker for your selection

2.    Press the Spacebar to play the video, and press Control + Spacebar at the point where you would like to set an end marker.

3.    Press the right bracket to set the end marker.

4.    Press the Delete key to remove the snippet.

Often you do not know where to set an end marker until you have played just a bit past it. Rewinding by small segments is useful in these situations. To do this:

1.    After having set a start marker and having played just a bit past your intended end marker, press Control + Spacebar to pause the recording there.

2.    Press Control + Dash (the key one to the right of 0 on the Number row). to rewind a little bit just before where you want to set the end marker, and then press Control + Spacebar to reposition your cursor here. You can also press Control + Dash without pausing audio. Because you are hearing the audio as you move backwards, this can give you a better idea of where you are in the recording than pausing first.

3.    Press the Spacebar to play to the point where you want to set the end marker, and Control + Spacebar again.

4.    Press the Right bracket to set the end marker.

5.    Press the Delete key to remove the snippet.

You can also delete beginning and ending snippets of a recording with Shift + Home and Shift + End respectively.

You can easily combine files of a similar format together, one after each other, so long as any initial settings are identical. . The fancy word for this is “concatenate.” To insert one file at the end of a file already in a project:

1.    Press Control + End to go to the end of the first file in the project, and press the Left bracket to set a start marker.

2.    Press Alt to open the menu bar, Right arrow to the Insert menu, Down arrow once to Media file, and press Enter to open the Import file dialog.

3.    Shift tab a couple of times to the list view of the default REAPER Media folder, and select the file if this is where you placed it.

The second file is now pasted at the end of the first file.

Some other useful keystrokes include:

·         Control + Shift + J: Location of cursor (Go into View menu with Alt V, Up arrow to the Time unit for ruler sub menu, and select Minutes Seconds to change how cursor position is expressed ).

·         Control +J: Go to or jump command to navigate to a time position in the recording. Use MM:SS.XXX format for delineating minutes, seconds, and hundredths of seconds.

·         Alt + Spacebar: After getting just a bit before a selection, Play a bit before and after the selection to preview what it will sound like after deleting the selection.

·         Shift + Dash: Decrease Play rate by 0.6%.

·         Shift + Equal: Increase Play rate by 0.6%.

To hear a selection after having set start and end markers, while still in the selection, press Home to go to the start of the selection, and then Spacebar to play just the selection. But to make this work, you first need to make two adjustments In preferences which is organized in a tree view. Steps are:

1.    Press Control + P to open Preferences.

2.    If you do not first land there, press P until you get to the Playback section of the tree view.

3.    Tab to the Stop playback at end of loop if repeat is disabled check box and check it.

4.    Tab many times until you get back to Playback in the tree view.

5.    Press E until you land on the Editing Behavior section of the tree view.

6.    Tab to the Link loop points to time selection checkbox and check it.

7.    Tab to the OK button and press Enter to save preferences.

Sometimes, you may need to set a start or end marker at a very precise point in the recording. This is the case when there is little or no silence at the point where you want to set a marker. Zooming allows you to move by extremely small time increments to precisely position start and end markers.

I strongly suggest you use headphones while zooming. Otherwise, it can be difficult to hear what you need to hear. As mentioned above, it is also preferable to leave a second or two of silence at areas where you think you will want to edit later. Pinpointing the exact cursor location while zooming can be tricky and time-consuming, so try to minimize how many times you need to do this to make your editing more efficient and less tedious.

The keystrokes you need for zooming are:

·         Zoom In: Equal.

·         Zoom out: Dash.

·         Left/right arrow: Move bac/forward by very small increments.

·         How does this work and what do you hear? When zooming out by pressing the Dash key several times, you will hear the number of pixels decline, for example, “57.9 pixels/second, 48.2 pixels/second.” This indicates that you are zooming out because fewer pixels per second means that when you now press the Left or Right arrow, you will be jumping by larger increments.

When zooming in by pressing the Equal sign several times, the opposite happens. You hear the number of pixels increase, and then pressing the Left or Right arrow moves the cursor by smaller increments. Note that, the more you zoom in, the harder it may be to understand the audio. You may not hear understandable words, but will hear something like “Bwup bwup  bwup.” You are trying to locate the playback position with either a momentary silence or the least amount of volume so you can correctly situate a start or end marker. Like much else in audio and video editing, this takes repetition and practice, and using the Control + Z keystroke liberally to undo your edit when you don’t get it quite right.

·         Assuming you are attempting to set an end marker for purposes of deleting an unwanted snippet, steps for using zooming to edit are:

1.    Set your start marker using the steps detailed above.

2.    Press the Spacebar to play to just past the approximate position where you want to set an end marker.

3.    Press Control + Spacebar to stop playback and preserve the cursor position.

4.    Press = or – and then Left and Right arrow to test out zoom levels until you have one that seems understandable.

5.    Press Left or Right arrow to locate the precise point where you want to set the end marker, and press the Right bracket there.

6.    Press the Delete key to delete the snippet.

7.    Press Control + -: to rewind by small increments, and then press the Spacebar to hear your edit.

8.    If you are not satisfied with your edit, press Control + Z to undo the edit and repeat the above steps until you are happy with the result.

·         As mentioned above, this can be tedious and it might not be possible to get satisfactory results. So, whenever possible when recording, leave gaps of silence where you know you will want to edit stuff out.

15.3.5 Saving a Project and Rendering Output Files

To save the project file at any point while editing, press Control + S to open the standard Save as dialog and give it a filename. Press Control + S again to save any subsequent revisions. It is saved with a .RPP extension. By default, it is saved to a REAPER Media folder in either your local Documents folder or your OneDrive Documents folder.

The RPP file is a small file that, when reopened, gathers up any initial files inserted into the project. It does not contain the initial media files. Consequently, do not delete any initial media files you have included until you have completed the project, and no longer need them. Otherwise, the next time you open the RPP file, you will receive an error message that the files cannot be located.

After editing, to save a media file in a playable format (such as WAV for audio or MP4 for video), you will need to render it. WAV audio is the default rendered format.

Steps for rendering are:

1.    Press Alt to land on the File menu, Down arrow to Render and press Enter, or use the shortcut Control + Alt + R.

2.    Type an Output file name, minus any file extension.

3.    The default rendered format is WAV. If this is what you want, press Enter to save it to the REAPER Media folder. For video, continue on.

4.    Tab many times to Output Render to, to hear the file path, including the default file extension which is .WAV.

5.    Tab to the Format: Combo box for a list of file formats.

6.    Down arrow to MPEG-4/Windows Media, which is the twelfth file format in the list, and press Enter. The MP4 file will begin rendering (that is, being saved) to the REAPER Media folder. If the rendered file is large, this may take several minutes.

When you close REAPER and reopen it, you will notice that the last project you were working on is still there. To start working on a new project, press Control + N.

15.3.6 Recap of Useful Keystrokes

Just so you have them all in one place, below is a list of useful keystrokes that were mentioned above:

·         Control + Home/End: Go to beginning/end of recording.

·         Spacebar: Plays/pause, but second Spacebar snaps back to start of selection.

·         Spacebar to start playing and then Control Spacebar: Play and then pause, but retaining pause cursor point (necessary to set start and end markers).

·         Left and Right bracket: Mark start and end of selection.

·         Home/End: Go to beginning/end of selection.

·         Home + Spacebar: Play selection.

·         Escape: Unselect (removes start and end markers)

·         Delete: Delete selection.

·         Control + C: Copy selection

·         Control + X: Cut selection

·         Control + V: Paste selection

·         Control + Z: Undo

·         Control + Shift + J: Location of cursor (Go into View menu with Alt V, Up arrow to the Time unit for ruler sub menu, and select Minutes Seconds to change how cursor position is expressed ).

·         Control + J: Go to or Jump.

·         Left/Right arrow: Scrub short distances to pinpoint start and end marker positions.

·         Shift + Dash: Decrease Play rate by 0.6%.

·         Shift + Equal: Increase Play rate by 0.6%.

·         Shift + Home/End: Select from cursor to beginning/end of recording.

·         Control + Shift + Spacebar: Reports start and end time position and amount of time of a selection.

·         Control + -: Rewind a little bit

·         Zoom in : Equals

·         Zoom Out: Dash.

·         Control + Shift + J: Location of cursor

·         Alt + Spacebar: Play a bit before and after a selection to preview it.

·         Home + Spacebar: Go to the start of a selection and play it.

·         Shift + Dash: Decrease Play rate by 0.6%.

·         Shift + Equal: Increase Play rate by 0.6%.

15.3.7 Resources for Learning More About REAPER

Because I only focussed on simple video editing, the above discussion has only scratched the surface of all that you can do with REAPER when it comes to audio editing. Many resources exist for learning more about how to use REAPER with screenreaders. The best place to start is probably:

REAPER Made Easy: Free Training from The Global Voice

Also check out this REAPER Shortcut Key List.

The REAPER Accessibility Wiki  provides a list of useful links and Resources.

Hartgen Consultancy offers a set of tutorials for 80 pounds ($112 US equivalent) called

Reaping the Benefits! Using REAPER Audio Workstation, OSARA and JAWS for Windows

Finally, there is a Groups.IO discussion list for screenreader users humorously called REAPERS Without Peepers. It has over 900 subscribers and has been around since 2010. Many of the list members are extremely knowledgeable.

Chapter 16 Other Useful Topics

This final chapter discusses several other useful topics, including alternative ways to access this book beyond reading it in Word, including with Bookshare (for those of you with Bookshare accounts) and on two portable devices (the Victor Reader Stream and the iPhone using the Voice Dream Reader app), accessing assistance with the Remote Incident Manager application from the Pneuma Solutions company, Groups.IO assistive technology discussion lists, and what to do when things go wrong with your technology.

16.1 Alternative Ways to Access This Book

In addition to reading this book in Word on your PC, this section covers several other ways you can access the book, including:

·         With a Bookshare account, read it online or download it to your PC and read it with FS Reader if you are a JAWS user.

·         Also with Bookshare, open it with your iPhone with the Bookshare Reader or Voice Dream Reader app.

·         With a Victor Reader Stream, add the chapter files in Word format to the Text folder of your flash drive.

·         The following subsections cover downloading the book to your PC from Bookshare to read it with FS Reader, and importing it into the Voice Dream Reader iPhone app from Bookshare and cloud sharing apps such as Dropbox, Google Drive, or OneDrive.

16.1.1 On Your PC With Bookshare and FS Reader

If you have a Bookshare account and are a JAWS user, one great way to read The Windows Screenreader Primer on your PC is with FS Reader, Vispero’s utility for reading DAISY-formatted books with JAWS and Magic. Many thanks to Robert Resnick for making me aware of this possibility.

DAISY stands for “Digital Accessible Information System,” a widely-used format for making books accessible and easily navigable with assistive technology. Accessing the book involves downloading it from Bookshare in DAISY text only format, extracting it, and then opening it with FS Reader. Once opened, you will be able to efficiently navigate the book using standard JAWS web browsing navigation and reading keystrokes, plus a few other useful keystrokes specific to FS Reader.

Note that Bookshare currently has two Windows Screenreader Primer books, the second and third editions, and the only way to know which is the third edition is to open it and check on the title page. Be sure to download the third edition.

Steps for downloading DAISY books from Bookshare and accessing them on your PC with FS Reader are:

1.    After logging into your Bookshare account and searching for the book, press T to navigate to the table with your search results. Press Control + Alt + Down arrow to move down the first column to the book title.

2.    Press Control + Alt + Right arrow to move across to the Actions column, and press Alt + Down arrow to expand the list of actions.

3.    Down arrow to the combo box for download format options, and press the Spacebar to open it.

4.    Down arrow to DAISY text only, and press Enter to select it. Some other options are Word and ePub, but you want DASY text only for use with FS Reader.

5.    Tab to the Download button and press Enter. The download should take just a few seconds.

6.    Open your Downloads folder where a ZIP folder with the book title should appear at the top of the folder.

7.    Select it, press the Applications key, Down arrow to Extract all, and press Enter.

8.    Press Enter again and a new folder with the same name (minus the ZIP extension) will be created in your Downloads folder.

9.    Move that folder to either your local Documents folder or, if you are signed into your Microsoft account, to the Documents subfolder of your OneDrive folder. Moving it will make it easier to find when you open it for the first time in FS Reader.

10. Open FS Reader and press Control + O for the Open file dialog.

11. Shift + Tab twice to the list of folders, which will either be your local Documents or OneDrive Documents folder.

12. Down arrow or first-letter navigate to the folder name (T for The Windows Screenreader Primer), and press Enter to open that folder.

13. Press Enter on the first file in that list which should have a .OPF extension, the DAISY 3.0 format used by Bookshare.

The entire book is now loaded and you are ready to navigate through it.

A few things to note:

·         To open the book in future sessions, press Alt to land on the File menu, Up arrow to the book title, and press Enter. FS Reader remembers recently opened books.

·         Also when you open a previously-opened book, Bookshare remembers where you last were, and first lands you in that place.

·         Bookshare has formatted this DAISY book with a single level 1 heading for the title. Chapters are all level 2 headings, with sections as level 3 headings, and so on down to level 5, the lowest heading level in this book.

·         Press Control + F to find the text of a topic you want, and then F3 to go to the next occurrence of that text, These are the same keystrokes used with JAWS when searching for text on the web.

·         Press Control + B to set a bookmark for a place you would like to return to in the future. Press Control K for a list of your bookmarks, Down arrow and press Enter on the one you wish to navigate to. Or to delete a bookmark you no longer need, press Control K, Down arrow to it, Tab to the Delete button and press Enter. Bookmarks are automatically saved, so will still be there the next time you open the book.

·         Links in the table of contents do not work. However, navigating by heading is generally more efficient.

·         Links to external websites work, but oddly, they open in Internet Explorer rather than in your default browser.

·         Go to the  FS Reader Getting Started Guide to learn more about how to use this utility.

16.1.2 Voice Dream Reader App on the iPhone

If you have the Voice Dream Reader app on your iPhone, and you subscribe to Bookshare, you can easily import the book in DAISY format and read it there. If not a Bookshare subscriber, you can import the book in ePub format. Text navigation by heading and heading level is possible with both of these methods.

Steps for importing a book from Bookshare into Voice Dream Reader are:

1.    Open the Voice Dream Reader app on your iPhone and make sure you are on the Library screen.

2.    Double tap on the Add document button at the top right of the screen.

3.    Flick right to Bookshare and double tap. If this is your first time doing this, you will need to sign into your Bookshare account.

4.    If the book is already in your reading list or your Download history, double tap on one of those buttons to access the list. Otherwise, search for it.

5.    Flick right to the book title, and then Right flick just past its name to Download and double tap to initiate the import process.

6.    When finished, double tap on the Close button found near the top right of the screen. This will return you to the Library screen of the Voice Dream Reader app.

For ePub files, first add them to a cloud storage app such as Dropbox, Google Drive, or OneDrive so you can import them into Voice Dream Reader. As mentioned above, use individual chapter files, rather than the entire book in a single file. Although you can read Word files with the Voice Dream Reader app, heading navigation is only supported for files in EPUB format. EPUB is a digital book file format for use with e-readers, and compatible software is available for most smartphones, tablets, and computers. Its file extension is .ePub. Use the chapter files contained in the EPUB folder that you downloaded from the Carroll Center website.

In outlining the steps below, I will use Dropbox as my cloud sharing app, but these steps will also work with OneDrive and Google Drive for Desktop.

Steps for copying files from your computer to the Voice Dream Reader app are:

1.    Copy the chapter files from the EPUB folder on your PC to a folder of your choosing in Dropbox.

2.    Open the Voice Dream Reader app on your iPhone where you land on the Library screen.

3.    Double tap on the Add document button at the top right of your screen.

4.    Flick right to Dropbox and double tap.

5.    Navigate to the folder containing the EPUB files and double tap.

6.    Flick right to the name of the EPUB file you wish to transfer, and then Right flick just past its name to the Download button and double tap to initiate the transfer process. Repeat this for any other files you wisht to transfer. Multiple transfers are possible at the same time.

7.    When all files are downloaded, double tap on the Close button found near the top right of the screen. This will return you to the Library screen of the Voice Dream Reader app.

Now that the book is in Voice Dream Reader, either imported in DAISY format from Bookshare, or in ePub format from one of the cloud sharing apps, you can navigate through it by heading in two ways. Steps for the first way are:

1.    Double tap on the file in the list of files in your library.

2.    From the top of the screen, flick right to the Headings, bookmarks, and highlights button and double tap.

3.    Flick right or left to the Headings button and double tap to select it.

4.    Flick right to the Heading level picker and flick up or down to adjust it to the level you would like to navigate by, for example, level two.

5.    Flick right to see the list of level two headings.

6.    Double tap on the level two heading to which you would like to navigate, and you will get into the document at that point.

Steps for navigating by heading in the second way are:

1.    Repeat steps one through three above.

2.    Flick right to the Heading level picker and flick up or down to adjust it to one past the level you would like to navigate by. For example, if you want to navigate by level two headings, select three.

3.    Flick left to the Close button and double tap. This returns to the screen for reading the document.

4.    Flick right to the Navigation unit picker, and flick up or down to Heading.

5.    Double tap on the Play button to start reading the document. When you navigate to this button, you also hear “adjustable,” indicating you can do what happens in the next step.

6.    With focus still on the Play button, Flick Down vertically to go to the next heading at the designated level (in this example, level two) or flick up to go back one heading at this level.

The discrepancy of this second approach (that is, having to select one number past the actual heading level you wish to navigate by) is a bit strange and will hopefully be rectified in future updates of the app.

16.1.3 Victor Stream

You can copy this book in Word format to the Text Files folder of the Victor Stream, and navigate through it by heading. Use the files in the folder containing all the chapter files in Word format.

To copy Word files from your computer to a Stream, first select and copy the Word files located on your computer that you wish to read on the Stream. Then do either of the following:

·         Remove your SD card from the Stream and place it in the SD slot on your computer, if it has one. Many computers have these slots, but not all of them. Your computer should make a noise acknowledging that the device is connected.

·         or power off your Stream, and then connect your Stream to your computer, using the cable that came from the manufacturer. Now turn on your Stream again. Your computer should make a noise acknowledging that the device is connected.

To navigate to the Text Files folder on your Stream and paste the selected files that you have copied to the Clipboard

1.    On your PC, press the Windows key and, if using Windows 10, type “This PC” in the search box. Usually, typing just the first one or two letters suffices. If using Windows 11, access This PC using one of the options covered in Chapter 2.5.9.

2.    Depending on how your folder view is set up here, either Right arrow or Down arrow to Devices and drives. With Windows 11 22/H2, you first land on Devices and Drives. If it says “collapsed” here, press the Spacebar to expand it.

3.    Down arrow or Right arrow to the name of your SD card, and press Enter.

4.    Down arrow to the $VR Text Files folder, and press Enter.

5.    Press Control + V to paste the Word files in the $VR Text Files folder.

6.    Remove your SD card or USB cable from the computer.

To now read Word documents on your Stream and navigate by heading:

1.    Power on the Stream and press one on the Number pad to cycle through the folders until you get to the Text Files folder. If you do not hear this, press the top middle button to turn on Airplane mode, and then try again. This disconnects Wi-Fi, enabling you to access this folder.

2.    Press the Play button to listen to the first file in the folder. Alternatively, press the six or four button to move to the next or previous file, respectively.

3.    Press the Play button when you land on the file you would like to listen to.

4.    Press the same button to pause the recording.

5.    Press two on the Number pad to cycle through the options for navigating within the document. Among these are levels one, two, three, etc. for each of these heading levels.

6.    After choosing a heading level, press the Play button to resume the recording, and now press the six or four button to move to the next or previous heading at this level, respectively.

7.    When done, press one on the Number pad to exit this file, and then use your arrow keys (four and six) to navigate to another file. Repeat steps three through six above to listen to this file.

8.    If you want to leave this folder and access a different folder on the Stream, press one another time to exit the Text Files folder, and continue pressing one until you arrive at the folder you want.

I find it most useful to navigate by level two headings in the chapter files of my book, preferring to move by chapter sections rather than sub-sections. See what works best for you.

16.2 remote Incident Manager

Remote Incident Manager (RIM), from Pneuma Solutions, allows you to provide or receive remote computer assistance on both Windows PCs and Apple computers. You can use it with or without assistive technology. This tool is not just for technicians. You could of course use it to get assistance from an I T expert, but you could also use it to get help from a sighted friend or family member if you were having trouble with an inaccessible website.

The person providing assistance is called the “controller,” and the person receiving assistance is called the “target.”

The first step is for both the controller and target to download RIM and install it on their computers. Visit Get RIM to download the installation file, navigate to the Download for Windows link, and press Enter to download the installation file to your Downloads folder. From there, activate the installation file and follow the instructions. A shortcut will be added to your Desktop during installation.

The controller is required to create an account while the target does not need to do this. With a free account, Controllers can use RIM for up to 30 minutes over a 24 hour period. Pneuma Solutions also has several paid account options for larger amounts of time, described on the web page above.

Once downloaded and installed, steps for initiating a remote session are simple:

1.    Both the controller and target open Remote Incident Manager using the desktop shortcut.

2.    For the controller, navigate to the Keyword edit field, type in something short which will serve as the code that the target person eventually types in on their end. The beauty of this is that the keyword can be extremely simple. This is especially useful when assisting people who are not strong typists. I have used something as easy to type as triple A, all in lower case. The only keyword restriction is that it is not being used by somebody else up in the cloud at the same time.

3.    Tab to the Start button and press Enter.

4.    For the target, type the keyword in the Keyword edit field and press Enter.

The session now begins. The controller can see the target screen, as well as hear any audio if using a screenreader. The controller can use both keystrokes and a mouse.

Here’s the next great thing about RIM. The controller can bring up a context menu by pressing Shift Windows + Backspace. In my opinion, the two most useful options in this context menu are:

·         Flip the session: This allows the Controller to switch Control + Back and forth between the two computers.

·         close the session.

·         The ability to easily flip the session is a great feature. As a controller, you might want to give Control + Back to the target so that he/she can type in a password. And if I do this as a controller, I am now back on my own computer. Perhaps I want to look something up in a file on my computer. Better yet, I can copy files and folders from my computer, flip the session back so I Control + It, and then paste the files or folders to the target computer. Because I often share files with trainees, this is an incredibly valuable feature.

16.3 Groups.IO Discussion Lists, Including How to Receive Daily Digests

Subscribing to Groups.IO lists has become a central part of my ongoing assistive technology learning process. I check it out on pretty much a daily basis. I have learned many useful things from the various lists to which I subscribe.

Find out how to create an account at:

Creating a Groups.io account

Links to the home pages of some of the lists that I have found informative include:

·         For JAWS: main@jfw.groups.io and jfw-users@groups.io.

·         For NVDA: nvda@nvda.groups.io.

·         For Microsoft Office: M365@groups.io.

·         For news about assistive technology for the blind: tech-vi@groups.io. This is an announce-only list rather than a discussion list.

The list home pages provide information on the subject matter of the lists, numbers of members, previous discussion threads, and links for subscribing and unsubscribing.

If you are concerned about getting inundated with email messages, you can set parameters on how you receive messages. For those lists with lots of traffic, I much prefer receiving a daily digest from each list with links to the various message threads. That way, I only get one message per discussion list each day, and I can quickly see if a particular discussion thread interests me.

Daily Digest Insert

To specify your mode of email delivery:

1.    Open groups.io in your web browser. If you are not already logged in, do so with your email and password for your Groups.io account.

2.    You land on a page with your Groups.io lists arrayed in a table. Press T to navigate to the table, press Control + Alt + Right arrow to move to the second column, and press Control + Alt + Down arrow to the name of the discussion list for which you want to change your delivery mode.

3.    Control + Alt + Right arrow to the Delivery column where the current mode is identified (the default is individual).

4.    This is a link. Press Enter to activate it.

5.    The options on this page are radio buttons. Press A with JAWS or R with NVDA to go to the first radio button. Down arrow to the Daily summary radio button and press the Spacebar to check it.

6.    Press B several times to the Save button and press Enter to save your new choice.

Once you have saved this, you will receive a single email for this list at about 9:00 AM Eastern Standard Time every day.

Steps for quickly and efficiently navigating the Daily Digest email message in Outlook and message threads include:

1.    Open the Daily Digest message and press Insert + F7 to open the Links list or Elements list in JAWS or NVDA, respectively.

2.    Down arrow through the links. The third or fourth link will be the title of the message thread.

3.    Press Enter on a thread that interests you.

4.    This opens a web page in your default browser. Press H to get to the only heading on the page, below which the initial message in the thread appears.

5.    Each message begins with a separator. The key to go to the next separator is the minus sign  with JAWS and the letter S with NVDA.

6.    To move through a thread quickly and efficiently, put your screenreader in Say All mode, listen to a thread, and press the separator key to go to the next individual thread.

7.    When finished with the thread, press Alt + F4 to close the web page, and return to the email message to find another thread you would like to read.

At the bottom of each individual thread, you can find a Reply button. Activate this if you would like to draft a reply. You will land in an edit field. Type in your text, tab to the Send button, and press Enter. This will go to all list members and appear as the last message in the thread.

When you post a question, state the issue clearly in the subject line of your email message. Avoid overly vague wording like “Outlook Problem,” saying instead, “Contacts no longer pre-populating in the To and CC fields.” Also identify near the beginning of the message what software and versions you are using (example: Windows 11 23/H2, JAWS 2024, and Outlook 365).

16.4 When Things Go Wrong

Technology is quirky. Things inevitably go wrong. I will conclude this book by identifying some commonly encountered issues and possible ways to address them. Here goes!

16.4.1 JAWS or NVDA stops talking.

JAWS is a powerful software program that takes a lot of juice to run. Consequently, it goes silent from time to time. To get some speech back, first try turning on Narrator by pressing Control + Windows + Enter. I like to say that JAWS is very jealous and territorial, not wanting an upstart competitor to butt in on its turf. Turning on Narrator often wakes up JAWS. If that doesn’t immediately get JAWS talking, navigate to the Desktop and click on the JAWS icon. Hopefully, JAWS will start talking again. If this works, then press Control + Windows + Enter again to exit Narrator.

Although not yet as versatile as JAWS and NVDA, I consider Narrator an indispensable tool when things go wrong with the other screenreaders. I switch it on and off several times every day.

If attempting to activate Narrator fails to get speech back, it’s probably time to power off the computer by holding down the Power button until the computer is turned off. Then boot it up again to restore speech.

16.4.2 You open a window that you know has content, but when you Down arrow, you hear nothing.

If this happens in a Word document, first press Alt R W to get a word count, just to doublecheck that text is present and that you have not accidentally deleted it. There are several things you can try for fixing this. Proceeding from the least time-consuming to slightly more time-consuming measures, do the following:

·         Maximize the window by pressing either Windows Up arrow or Alt and the Spacebar together and then Down arrow to Maximize. If your screenreader indicates that maximize is unavailable, it is not the problem. If it only says, “maximize,” press Enter and that hopefully fixes the problem.

·         If using JAWS, press Insert escape to refresh JAWS.

·         If this is a web page, press F5 to refresh the page.

·         Alt + Tab away from the window, and then Alt + Tab back to it.

·         Close the application that is misbehaving and reopen it.

·         Close your screenreader program and reopen it.

If none of these work, power off your computer and reboot.

16.4.3 You receive the message “program not responding.”

This most frequently happens to me with Outlook. I naturally first try pressing Alt + F4 to exit the program. I try other things too, like pressing Escape. But invariably, the program does not close and I cannot resume working in that application. Short of rebooting the computer, open the Task Manager and close the program there. Steps are slightly different between Windows 10 and 11:

·         With Windows 10, press Control + Shift + Escape together, Down arrow to the offending program, Tab to the End task button, and press Enter.

·         With Windows 11, also press Control + Shift + Escape together, Down arrow to the program, press the Applications key, Down arrow to End task, and press Enter.

Now reopen the program, and it should work correctly. If the problem persists, reboot your computer.

16.4.4 You accidentally delete text.

In any application where you are in edit mode, immediately press Control + Z to undo your last keystroke. If you are working in Excel, and press a wrong key in a particular cell, immediately press the Escape key. Whatever you just typed will not replace previous cell content.

The above said, your best defense against losing substantial amounts of work is to save files early and often. If you do this and then make a serious editing mistake, just close your document without saving it, and reopen it. If you save frequently, the amount of work you lose in such situations will be minimal.

16.4.5 A file does not open in the program you want it to open in.

If you want to permanently change the default program for opening this file type, see Chapter 2.5.10.

If you want to open the file in an application other than the default one, place your focus on the filename. Then press the Applications key, Down arrow to the Open with submenu, and press Enter. Now Up or Down arrow to the desired application and press Enter.

16.4.6 I am unsure whether my issue has to do with my screenreader, the application I am in, or my own computer.

First try to narrow down the possibilities to isolate the problem. This will help you to better articulate your problem if you need to call tech support or post a question to a discussion list.

Let’s say you experience a problem while using JAWS. Try switching to NVDA or Narrator. If performance improves, chances are good that the problem is with your initial screenreader. If nothing changes, the problem is unrelated to your choice of screenreader.

If you encounter a problem on a website, try switching browsers. Here too, this might help you isolate it. If the problem first arises using Google Chrome, try Firefox rather than Edge. Chrome and Edge are both Chromium-based while Firefox is not, so there is a greater likelihood that performance will be different. Also try switching screenreaders. If the problem persists regardless of which screenreader and/or browser you switch to, then the problem almost certainly lies with the application itself or the specific website. At this point, you may wish to contact tech support for that application or website. You might also query a technology discussion list to which you subscribe, asking if others have had similar problems, and if so, what they did to resolve it.

16.4.7 I open a web page and my screenreader remains silent.

First try refreshing the web page by pressing F5, and wait a reasonable time for your screenreader to start telling you the number of headings, links, and so on, that are present on the page. Also try maximizing the page by pressing either Windows Up arrow or Alt and the Spacebar together and then X.

16.4.8 Quick key navigation fails to work on a web page.

Let’s say you open a web page, and then press H to navigate to the first heading, or you press E to get to the first edit box, but your screenreader only says H or E. Try any of the following:

·         Press F5 to refresh the page to see if it correctly loads this time.

·         You may have landed on the Address bar instead of the main body of the web page. Press F6 or Shift + F6 several times to see if you can get to the body of the page that way. You can also try Shift + Tabbing to return to page content.

·         Toggle screenreader focus modes off and on. With JAWS, press Insert + Z to toggle Virtual PC cursor mode on and off. Try Down arrowing to see if you can now activate links. Press H to see if you can navigate by heading. In some cases where accessibility problems exist, Down arrowing and pressing Enter on a word or set of words that are not expressed as links or buttons may activate them. If using NVDA or Narrator, press Insert + Spacebar to toggle Browse mode or Scan mode on and off, their respective equivalents to the JAWS Virtual PC cursor mode.

·         Close the web page and reopen it and see if it behaves properly this time.

·         Change web browsers and/or screenreaders to see if performance improves.

16.4.9 More Radical Solutions: Uninstalling, Reinstalling Applications, and JAWS Repair

Sometimes an application is seriously malfunctioning and the only practical remedy is to uninstall and reinstall it. Keep in mind that you will probably lose whatever customizations and settings changes you have made to the program.

Steps for uninstalling an application are:
